DSA Notes

Pehli baar seekh rahe ho? Perfect! 💪 Hinglish mein samjho — Easy se Advanced tak! 🚀

? all shortcuts  |  Ctrl + K search  |  T theme
🎓

Pehli Baar DSA Seekh Rahe Ho? Yahan Se Shuru Karo!

Sabse pehle basics samajh lo — phir problems easy lagenge! 💪

🤔

DSA Kya Hai?

Data Structures = Data ko organize karne ke tarike

Jaise ghar mein almirah, drawer, shelf hoti hai — code mein Array, HashMap, Set hote hain!


Algorithms = Problems solve karne ke steps

Jaise recipe follow karte ho — same steps, same result! 🍳

🎯

DSA Kyun Seekhein?

  • ✅ Interviews — Google, Amazon, Microsoft sab DSA poochte hain
  • ✅ Problem Solving — Dimag sharp hota hai
  • ✅ Better Code — Fast aur efficient programs likhoge
  • ✅ Confidence — Koi bhi problem solve kar paoge!
📦

Basic Data Structures — Pehle Yeh Samjho!

📋 Array

Ek line mein rakhe hue boxes — har box ka number (index) hota hai

[10, 20, 30, 40]

Index 0 se start hota hai! arr[0] = 10

🗺️ HashMap / Dictionary

Key-Value pairs — jaise phone book (naam → number)

{"apple": 5, "banana": 3}

Key se directly value mil jaati hai — O(1) time!

🎯 Set

Sirf unique items — duplicates allowed nahi

{1, 2, 3} (no repeats!)

Check karna fast hai — "Yeh item hai ya nahi?"

📝 String

Characters ki array — words aur sentences

"hello" = ['h','e','l','l','o']

Immutable hoti hai (change nahi hoti)

⏱️

Time Complexity — Big O Notation (BAHUT Important!)

Yeh batata hai ki code kitna fast ya slow hai. Jitna chhota O, utna better!

O(1) Constant — Instant! ⚡ HashMap se value nikalna
O(log n) Logarithmic — Bahut Fast Binary Search
O(n) Linear — Theek hai Array mein ek baar loop
O(n log n) Log Linear — Sorting Merge Sort, Quick Sort
O(n²) Quadratic — Slow! 🐢 Nested loops (loop ke andar loop)
O(2ⁿ) Exponential — Bahut Slow! 💀 Recursion without memoization
💡 Yaad rakho: Interview mein hamesha poochte hain "Time Complexity kya hai?" — Toh har solution ka Big O zaroor samjho!
💡

Learning Tips

  • 📖 Pehle samjho, phir likho — Copy-paste se kuch nahi hoga
  • ✍️ Khud se code karo — Paper pe bhi try karo
  • 🔁 Revise karo — 2-3 din baad wapas solve karo
  • 🎯 Easy se shuru karo — Direct hard problems mat karo
  • ⏰ Daily 1-2 problems — Consistency > Quantity
🖥️

Yeh Page Kaise Use Karein?

  • ⌨️ ? dabao — Saare shortcuts dikhenge
  • 🔍 Ctrl+K — Search karo koi bhi problem
  • ✅ Double-click — Problem complete mark karo
  • ⭐ B dabao — Bookmark karo
  • 🌙 T dabao — Dark/Light theme toggle
  • 📋 Code pe hover karo — Copy button dikhega
📅

467Minimum Bit Flips to Convert NumberEasy
468Add Two IntegersEasy
469Find Closest Number to ZeroEasy
470Count Unguarded Cells in the GridMedium
471Make Array Non-decreasing or Non-increasingHard
472Largest Combination With Bitwise AND Greater Than ZeroMedium
473Sender With Largest Word CountMedium
474Minimum Obstacle Removal to Reach CornerHard
475Spiral Matrix IVMedium
476Move Pieces to Obtain a StringMedium
477Optimal Partition of StringMedium
478Divide Intervals Into Minimum Number of GroupsMedium
479Longest Increasing Subsequence IIHard
480Longest Subarray With Maximum Bitwise ANDMedium
481Height of Binary Tree After Subtree Removal QueriesHard
482Maximum Sum of Distinct Subarrays With Length KMedium
483Minimum Total Distance TraveledHard
484Take K of Each Character From Left and RightMedium
485Maximal Score After Applying K OperationsMedium
486Time Taken to Cross the DoorHard
487Count the Number of Fair PairsMedium
488Minimum Time to Visit a Cell In a GridHard
489Prime Subtraction OperationMedium
490Array Prototype LastEasy
491CounterEasy
492Convert Object to JSON StringMedium
493Apply Transform Over Each Element in ArrayEasy
494Cousins in Binary Tree IIMedium
495Lexicographically Smallest Beautiful StringHard
496Create Hello World FunctionEasy
497Maximum Number of Moves in a GridMedium
498Minimum String Length After Removing SubstringsEasy
499Return Length of Arguments PassedEasy
500To Be Or Not To BeEasy
501Extra Characters in a StringMedium
502Find the Safest Path in a GridMedium
503Create a DataFrame from ListEasy
504Minimum Number of Changes to Make Binary String BeautifulMedium
505Separate Black and White BallsMedium
506Find Missing and Repeated ValuesEasy
507Calculate Compressed MeanEasy
508Find Expensive CitiesEasy
509Class PerformanceMedium
510Loan TypesEasy
511Top Three WineriesHard
512Viewers Turned StreamersHard
513Find Beautiful Indices in the Given Array IIHard
514Find the Maximum Number of Elements in SubsetMedium
515Type of TriangleEasy
516Ant on the BoundaryEasy
517Find the Length of the Longest Common PrefixMedium
518Shortest Subarray With OR at Least K IIMedium
519Score of a StringEasy
520Minimum Array EndMedium
521String Compression IIIMedium
522Alternating Groups IIMedium

524Maximum Number of Moves to Kill All PawnsHard

💡 Pro Tip: Google loves system design thinking, clean code, and optimal solutions. Practice explaining your thought process out loud!

Ready ho? Chalo pehle problem se shuru karte hain! 🚀

Start Learning →
🎯

Pattern Master Guide — 94 DSA Patterns!

Interview mein pattern recognition hi success ki key hai! Har pattern ke detection tricks aur tips yahan hain! 🔥

🧠

Patterns Kyun Important Hain? — Interview Success Ka Secret!

❌ Bina Patterns Ke (WRONG Approach)
  • Har problem naya lagta hai 😰
  • 500+ problems yaad karna impossible
  • Interview mein panic hota hai
  • Time waste hota hai reinventing solutions mein
✅ Patterns Ke Saath (RIGHT Approach)
  • Naya problem → Pehchano pattern → Apply template! ✅
  • Sirf ~20 core patterns yaad karo, 200+ problems solve ho jayenge
  • Interview mein confidence rehta hai
  • Optimized solution quickly mil jata hai

💡 Golden Rule: "Pattern dekho, template apply karo, problem solve karo!" — Ye hai interview cracking ka formula!

👉👈

I. Two Pointer Patterns (Pattern 1-7)

Two Pointers tab use hota hai jab tumhe array/string ke elements ko efficiently compare ya manipulate karna ho. Do pointers rakhte ho jo different positions pe hote hain aur move karte hain!

🔍 Two Pointer Pattern Kab Use Karein? — Detection Tricks!
  • ✅ "Sorted array" mention ho problem mein
  • ✅ "Find pair/triplet" jo koi condition satisfy kare
  • ✅ "In-place modify" karna ho array ko
  • ✅ "Palindrome" check ya manipulation ho
  • ✅ "Container/area" maximize/minimize karna ho
  • ✅ "Remove duplicates" sorted array se
🔹 Pattern 1: Converging Pointers

Kya hai: Left pointer start se, Right pointer end se — dono middle ki taraf move karte hain jab tak cross na ho jayein.

Kab use karein: Sorted array mein pair find karna, palindrome check, container area

Problems: 11. Container With Most Water, 15. 3Sum, 167. Two Sum II

left = 0, right = n-1; while left < right: compare & move
🔹 Pattern 2: Fast & Slow Pointers

Kya hai: Ek pointer slow (1 step), ek fast (2 steps) — Floyd's Cycle Detection!

Kab use karein: Linked list cycle detect, duplicate number, middle find

Problems: 141. Linked List Cycle, 287. Find the Duplicate Number

slow = slow.next; fast = fast.next.next; if slow == fast: cycle!
🔹 Pattern 3: Fixed Separation

Kya hai: Do pointers fixed distance pe — pehle fast ko k steps aage bhejo, fir dono saath move karo.

Kab use karein: Nth node from end, specific distance wale elements

Problems: 19. Remove Nth Node From End of List

fast ko n steps aage bhejo; phir dono saath move karo
🔹 Pattern 4: In-place Array Modification

Kya hai: Read pointer traverse karta hai, Write pointer valid elements likhta hai — O(1) space!

Kab use karein: Remove duplicates, move zeroes, sort colors (Dutch National Flag)

Problems: 26. Remove Duplicates, 75. Sort Colors, 283. Move Zeroes

write = 0; for read in range(n): if valid: arr[write++] = arr[read]
🔹 Pattern 6: Expanding From Center

Kya hai: Har position ko center maan ke dono taraf expand karo jab tak valid rahe.

Kab use karein: Longest palindromic substring, palindrome count

Problems: 5. Longest Palindromic Substring

for center: expand(left, right) while s[left] == s[right]
🔹 Pattern 7: String Reversal

Kya hai: Two pointers se swap karte hue reverse — words reverse, whole string reverse

Kab use karein: Reverse words, reverse string in-place

Problems: 151. Reverse Words in a String

while left < right: swap(arr[left++], arr[right--])
🖥️

II. Sliding Window Patterns (Pattern 9-11)

Sliding Window tab use hota hai jab tumhe contiguous subarray/substring find karna ho. Window expand/shrink karte ho condition ke according!

🔍 Sliding Window Pattern Kab Use Karein? — Detection Tricks!
  • ✅ "Contiguous subarray/substring" mention ho
  • ✅ "Longest/Shortest" with some condition
  • ✅ "Maximum/Minimum sum" of k elements
  • ✅ "At most k distinct" characters/elements
  • ✅ "Anagram/Permutation" in string
  • ✅ "Fixed size window" operations
🔹 Pattern 9: Variable Size Sliding Window

Kya hai: Window expand karo (right++), shrink karo (left++) jab tak condition valid rahe.

Kab use karein: Longest substring without repeating, minimum window substring

Problems: 3. Longest Substring Without Repeating, 76. Minimum Window Substring, 424. Longest Repeating Character Replacement

while right < n: expand; while invalid: shrink; update_answer
🔹 Pattern 10: Fixed Size Window

Kya hai: Window size k fix hai — slide karo, add new element, remove old element.

Kab use karein: Maximum sum of k consecutive, moving average

Problems: 239. Sliding Window Maximum, 346. Moving Average

for i in range(k, n): add arr[i]; remove arr[i-k]; process
🔹 Pattern 11: Character Frequency Matching

Kya hai: HashMap use karke frequency track karo window ke andar — anagram/permutation find karo.

Kab use karein: Find all anagrams, permutation in string

Problems: 438. Find All Anagrams in a String, 567. Permutation in String

need = Counter(p); have = {}; if have == need: found!
🌳

III. Tree Traversal Patterns (Pattern 12-17)

Tree problems mein mainly DFS (Recursion) aur BFS (Level Order) use hota hai. Har traversal ka apna use case hai!

🔍 Tree Pattern Kab Use Karein? — Detection Tricks!
  • ✅ "Level by level" → BFS / Level Order (Pattern 12)
  • ✅ "Construct tree" from traversals → Preorder (Pattern 13)
  • ✅ "BST validation/search" → Inorder (Pattern 14)
  • ✅ "Height/Depth/Diameter" → Postorder (Pattern 15)
  • ✅ "Common ancestor" → LCA Pattern (Pattern 16)
  • ✅ "Serialize/Deserialize" → Pattern 17
🔹 Pattern 12: Level Order (BFS)

Kya hai: Queue use karo, level by level process karo.

Problems: 102. Binary Tree Level Order Traversal, 199. Right Side View

🔹 Pattern 13: Preorder (Root-Left-Right)

Kya hai: Pehle root process karo, fir children.

Problems: 105. Construct Tree, 226. Invert Binary Tree

🔹 Pattern 14: Inorder (Left-Root-Right)

Kya hai: BST mein sorted order milta hai!

Problems: 98. Validate BST, 230. Kth Smallest in BST

🔹 Pattern 15: Postorder (Left-Right-Root)

Kya hai: Children pehle, parent baad mein — bottom-up!

Problems: 104. Max Depth, 124. Max Path Sum, 543. Diameter

🔹 Pattern 16: Lowest Common Ancestor

Kya hai: Do nodes ka common ancestor dhundo.

Problems: 235. LCA of BST, 236. LCA of Binary Tree

🔹 Pattern 17: Serialization

Kya hai: Tree ko string mein convert karo aur wapas bhi!

Problems: 297. Serialize and Deserialize Binary Tree

🕸️

IV. Graph Patterns (Pattern 18-29)

Graph problems mein DFS/BFS traversal, cycle detection, topological sort, aur Union-Find common hain!

🔍 Graph Pattern Detection Tricks!
  • ✅ "Connected components / Islands" → DFS/BFS flood fill (Pattern 18)
  • ✅ "Cycle detection" → DFS with visited states (Pattern 20)
  • ✅ "Course schedule / Dependencies" → Topological Sort (Pattern 21)
  • ✅ "Clone graph" → Deep Copy (Pattern 22)
  • ✅ "Union components" → Union-Find (Pattern 25)
  • ✅ "Shortest path / Word ladder" → BFS (Pattern 29)
🔹 Pattern 18: DFS Island Counting

Problems: 200. Number of Islands, 695. Max Area of Island, 733. Flood Fill

🔹 Pattern 20: Cycle Detection

Problems: 207. Course Schedule

🔹 Pattern 21: Topological Sort

Problems: 210. Course Schedule II, 269. Alien Dictionary

🔹 Pattern 25: Union-Find

Problems: 323. Connected Components, 547. Number of Provinces

🧮

V. Dynamic Programming Patterns (Pattern 30-41)

DP tab use hota hai jab problem mein overlapping subproblems aur optimal substructure ho. Memoization se time save karo!

🔍 DP Pattern Detection Tricks!
  • ✅ "Count ways / Number of ways" → Fibonacci/Counting DP
  • ✅ "Maximum/Minimum" subarray/subsequence → Kadane's / LIS
  • ✅ "Coin change / Unbounded selection" → Unbounded Knapsack
  • ✅ "Partition / Subset sum" → 0/1 Knapsack
  • ✅ "Word break / Can construct" → Word Break Style
  • ✅ "Two strings comparison" → LCS Pattern
  • ✅ "Grid paths" → Unique Paths DP
🔹 Pattern 30: Fibonacci Style

Formula: dp[i] = dp[i-1] + dp[i-2]

Problems: 70. Climbing Stairs, 198. House Robber

🔹 Pattern 31: Kadane's Algorithm

Formula: dp[i] = max(arr[i], dp[i-1] + arr[i])

Problems: 53. Maximum Subarray, 152. Max Product

🔹 Pattern 32: Coin Change (Unbounded)

Formula: dp[i] = min(dp[i], dp[i-coin] + 1)

Problems: 322. Coin Change, 518. Coin Change 2

🔹 Pattern 33: 0/1 Knapsack

Formula: dp[i][w] = max(skip, take)

Problems: 416. Partition Equal Subset Sum

🔹 Pattern 35: LCS (Longest Common Subsequence)

2D DP: Compare two strings character by character

Problems: 1143. LCS, 72. Edit Distance

🔹 Pattern 40: LIS (Longest Increasing Subsequence)

Binary Search Optimization: O(n log n)

Problems: 300. LIS, 354. Russian Doll Envelopes

📚

VI-XV. More Patterns Quick Reference

🔹 VI. Heap Patterns (42-45)
  • 42. Top K: Kth largest, K frequent → Heap/QuickSelect
  • 43. Two Heaps: Median finding → Min + Max heap
  • 44. K-way Merge: Merge K lists → Min heap
  • 45. Scheduling: Meeting rooms → Sort + Heap
🔹 VII. Backtracking (46-52)
  • 46. Subsets: All possible subsets → 2^n combinations
  • 47. Permutations: All orderings → n! arrangements
  • 48. Combination Sum: Target sum → Recursive choices
  • 50. Word Search: Grid path finding → DFS backtrack
  • 51. N-Queens: Constraint satisfaction → Column/Diagonal check
🔹 VIII. Greedy (53-58)
  • 53. Interval Merging: Sort by start → Merge overlapping
  • 54. Jump Game: Reachability → Track max reach
  • 55. Buy/Sell Stock: Track min price, max profit
  • 56. Gas Station: Circuit → Prefix sum analysis
🔹 IX. Binary Search (59-63)
  • 59. Sorted Array: Classic binary search
  • 60. Rotated Array: Find pivot, search half
  • 61. On Answer: Binary search on result space
  • 62. First/Last: Lower/Upper bound
🔹 X. Stack (64-69)
  • 64. Valid Parentheses: Match opening/closing
  • 65. Monotonic Stack: Next greater/smaller element
  • 66. Expression Eval: Calculator, Polish notation
  • 69. Largest Rectangle: Histogram → Monotonic stack
🔹 XI. Bit Manipulation (70-73)
  • 70. XOR: Single number, missing → a^a=0
  • 71. AND: Counting bits → n&(n-1)
  • 72. Bitwise DP: Counting bits optimization
  • 73. Power of Two: n&(n-1)==0 check
🔹 XII. Linked List (74-78)
  • 74. In-place Reversal: prev, curr, next pointers
  • 75. Merge Lists: Two pointer merge
  • 76. Add Numbers: Digit by digit + carry
  • 78. Reordering: Find middle, reverse, merge
🔹 XV. Design (93-94)
  • 93. Design: LRU Cache, Min Stack, HashMap
  • 94. Tries: Prefix tree for autocomplete/search
🎯

Pattern Recognition Cheat Sheet — Interview Quick Reference!

Problem Mein Ye Dikhe Pattern Use Karo Key Technique
Sorted array + find pairTwo Pointersleft=0, right=n-1
Linked list cycle/middleFast & Slowslow++, fast+=2
Contiguous subarray/substringSliding Windowexpand right, shrink left
Tree height/depth/diameterPostorder DFSprocess children first
Islands/connected componentsDFS/BFS Flood Fillmark visited, explore neighbors
Course prerequisitesTopological SortKahn's BFS / DFS
Count ways / Fibonacci typeDP - Fibonaccidp[i] = dp[i-1] + dp[i-2]
Maximum subarrayKadane's Algorithmmax(arr[i], curr+arr[i])
Coin change / unlimited itemsUnbounded Knapsackdp[i-coin] + 1
Subset with target sum0/1 Knapsacktake or skip each item
All subsets/permutationsBacktrackingchoose, explore, unchoose
Merge intervalsGreedy - Sort Firstsort by start, merge
Find in rotated arrayModified Binary Searchcheck which half sorted
Next greater elementMonotonic Stackdecreasing stack
Single number (others twice)XORa^a=0, a^0=a
K largest/frequentHeap / QuickSelectmin heap size k
🏆

Pro Tips — Interview Mein Pattern Kaise Identify Karein?

🎯 5-Step Problem Solving Framework — Interview Mein Ye Follow Karo!
1
Problem Carefully Padho

Keywords note karo: "sorted", "contiguous", "all subsets", "shortest path", "maximum/minimum". Ye keywords pattern reveal karte hain!

2
Input/Output Dekho

Array hai? → Two Pointers/Sliding Window. Tree hai? → DFS/BFS. Graph hai? → BFS for shortest, DFS for exploration.

3
Constraints Check Karo

n ≤ 10^6 → O(n) ya O(n log n) chahiye (Two Pointers, Sliding Window). n ≤ 20 → O(2^n) chal jayega (Backtracking). n ≤ 10^4 → O(n²) bhi okay hai.

4
Brute Force Se Shuru Karo

Pehle simple solution batao, fir optimize karo. Interviewer ye dekhna chahta hai ki tum problem samajhte ho!

5
Pattern Apply Karo

Identified pattern ka template use karo. Edge cases handle karo. Code likho aur dry run karo!

🔥 Highest ROI Patterns — Ye Sabse Zyada Pooche Jaate Hain!

According to AlgoMonster data analysis of 10,000+ interview questions:

🥇
DFS (25%)

Trees, Graphs, Backtracking sab mein use hota hai!

🥈
BFS (15%)

Shortest path, Level order traversal, Word ladder!

🥉
Two Pointers (12%)

Arrays, Strings ke saare pair/triplet problems!

⭐
Sliding Window (10%)

Substring, Subarray optimization problems!

👉👈 Two Pointers — Deep Dive Tips!
🎯 Type 1: Left-Right Converging

Pattern: Dono ends se start, middle mein milte hain

Use when: Sorted array + pair find, Palindrome check, Container water

Logic: Sum chhota? left++. Sum bada? right--

🐢🐇 Type 2: Fast-Slow (Floyd's)

Pattern: Slow 1 step, Fast 2 steps

Use when: Cycle detect, Middle find, Duplicate in [1,n]

Key insight: Agar cycle hai toh fast-slow zaroor milenge!

🏃 Type 3: Same Direction

Pattern: Dono same side se, different speeds

Use when: Remove duplicates, Partition array, Merge arrays

Logic: Read pointer scan kare, Write pointer likhe

📏 Type 4: Fixed Distance

Pattern: Do pointers k distance apart

Use when: Nth from end, Rotate list by k

Logic: Pehle ek ko k aage bhejo, fir dono saath chalo

🪟 Sliding Window — Deep Dive Tips!

Golden Rule: Sliding Window = "Expand karo jab tak valid, Shrink karo jab invalid ho jaye, har step pe answer update karo!"

📏 Fixed Size Window

Kab: "Size k ka subarray", "k consecutive elements"

Template:
1. First k elements ka sum nikalo
2. Slide: arr[i] add karo, arr[i-k] remove karo
3. Max/min track karo

📐 Variable Size Window

Kab: "Longest/Shortest substring", "At most k distinct"

Template:
1. Right expand karo (right++)
2. Condition invalid? Left shrink karo (left++)
3. Valid window pe answer update karo

🔤 Character Frequency

Kab: "Find anagram", "Permutation in string"

Template:
1. Pattern ka frequency map banao
2. Window slide karo, match count track karo
3. Jab match == required, found!

💡 Pro Tip: Sliding Window problems mein HashMap/Set almost always use hota hai character/element tracking ke liye!

🧮 Dynamic Programming — Pattern Recognition Tips!

DP Kab Use Karna Hai? Jab problem mein "overlapping subproblems" ho aur "optimal substructure" ho (smaller problems ka optimal solution larger problem ka part ho).

✅ DP Signal Words
  • "Count number of ways"
  • "Maximum/Minimum cost"
  • "Can you reach/make?"
  • "Longest/Shortest sequence"
  • "Partition into groups"
❌ DP NOT Use When
  • Simple iteration chal jaye
  • Greedy optimal answer de de
  • No overlapping subproblems
  • Graph traversal problems
🎯 DP → DFS+Memo Trick

Agar DP nahi samajh aa raha, toh pehle recursive solution likho, fir memoization add karo — same result, easier to think!

🏢 Company-wise Pattern Trends — Kahan Kya Poochte Hain?
🛒 Amazon

Two Pointers, DFS, BFS dominate. Classic problems zyada aate hain. Bug-free code important!

🔍 Google

Unique problems + multiple patterns combine hote hain. DP + Binary Search, DFS + Prefix Sum common hai.

📘 Meta

Classic problems but slightly challenging. Bug-free coding pe zyada focus. Two Pointers, DFS, BFS!

🪟 Microsoft

Balanced mix of all patterns. Design questions bhi aate hain. Array/String problems common!

⚠️ Common Mistakes — Ye Mat Karna Interview Mein!

❌ Seedha code likhna — Pehle approach discuss karo!

❌ Edge cases ignore karna — Empty array, single element, duplicates handle karo!

❌ Time complexity na batana — Har solution ke baad TC/SC batao!

❌ Brute force skip karna — Simple se optimized tak journey dikhao!

🎯

Ultimate Google 541 — Organized by Algorithm!

Ye section Ultimate Google 541 LeetCode Problems ko Algorithm Category ke according organize karta hai! Ab tumhe pata chalega ki kaunsa problem kaunse pattern se solve hoga! 🚀

👉👈

35 Problems

🖥️

🔍

32 Problems

📊

68 Problems

🌐

#️⃣

📚

👉👈 TWO POINTER — Google Problems (35) ▼

📖 Algorithm Explanation

Two Pointer technique uses two pointers to traverse an array/string, typically from opposite ends or same direction. It reduces O(n²) brute force to O(n) by eliminating unnecessary comparisons.

⏱️ Time Complexity

O(n) - Single pass

💾 Space Complexity

O(1) - In-place

🎯 When to Use Two Pointers?

✅ Sorted Array: Find pair with target sum, triplets, closest sum
✅ Palindrome Check: Compare characters from both ends
✅ In-place Modification: Remove duplicates, move elements, partition
✅ Container/Area Problems: Maximize area between two lines
✅ Merge Operations: Merge two sorted arrays in-place

⚡ Code Templates

# Pattern 1: Opposite Direction (Most Common)

def two_sum_sorted(arr, target):
    left, right = 0, len(arr) - 1
    
    while left < right:
        curr_sum = arr[left] + arr[right]
        
        if curr_sum == target:
            return [left, right]
        elif curr_sum < target:
            left += 1      # Sum chota hai, left badha
        else:
            right -= 1     # Sum bada hai, right ghatao
    
    return []  # No pair found

# Pattern 2: Same Direction (Slow & Fast)

def remove_duplicates(arr):
    if not arr: return 0
    
    slow = 0  # Points to last unique element
    
    for fast in range(1, len(arr)):
        if arr[fast] != arr[slow]:
            slow += 1
            arr[slow] = arr[fast]
    
    return slow + 1  # Length of unique elements

# Pattern 3: Three Pointers (3Sum)

def three_sum(nums):
    nums.sort()
    result = []
    
    for i in range(len(nums) - 2):
        if i > 0 and nums[i] == nums[i-1]: continue  # Skip duplicates
        
        left, right = i + 1, len(nums) - 1
        while left < right:
            total = nums[i] + nums[left] + nums[right]
            if total == 0:
                result.append([nums[i], nums[left], nums[right]])
                while left < right and nums[left] == nums[left+1]: left += 1
                while left < right and nums[right] == nums[right-1]: right -= 1
                left += 1; right -= 1
            elif total < 0:
                left += 1
            else:
                right -= 1
    return result

💡 Pro Tips & Tricks

🔴 Sorted Array Required: For sum problems, always sort first (unless already sorted)

🟢 Skip Duplicates: Use while left < right and nums[left] == nums[left+1]: left += 1

🔵 Container Problems: Move the pointer with smaller height (greedy approach)

🟣 Palindrome: Use while left < right: if s[left] != s[right]: return False

Pattern Recognition: Sorted array, pair/triplet sum, palindrome, in-place modification, container problems

167. Two Sum II - Input Array Is Sorted Easy 15. 3Sum Medium 16. 3Sum Closest Medium 11. Container With Most Water Medium 42. Trapping Rain Water Hard 125. Valid Palindrome Easy 680. Valid Palindrome II Easy 26. Remove Duplicates from Sorted Array Easy 80. Remove Duplicates from Sorted Array II Medium 283. Move Zeroes Easy 75. Sort Colors Medium 977. Squares of a Sorted Array Easy 844. Backspace String Compare Easy 5. Longest Palindromic Substring Medium 88. Merge Sorted Array Easy 986. Interval List Intersections Medium 344. Reverse String Easy 151. Reverse Words in a String Medium 189. Rotate Array Medium 31. Next Permutation Medium 763. Partition Labels Medium 76. Minimum Window Substring Hard 845. Longest Mountain in Array Medium 777. Swap Adjacent in LR String Medium 2337. Move Pieces to Obtain a String Medium 1768. Merge Strings Alternately Easy 905. Sort Array By Parity Easy 2149. Rearrange Array Elements by Sign Medium 1813. Sentence Similarity III Medium 1089. Duplicate Zeros Easy
🖥️ SLIDING WINDOW — Google Problems (28) ▶

📖 Algorithm Explanation

Sliding Window maintains a "window" of elements that expands/shrinks based on conditions. Two types: Fixed Size (window size constant) and Variable Size (window expands until condition breaks, then shrinks).

⏱️ Time Complexity

O(n) - Each element visited max twice

💾 Space Complexity

O(k) - HashMap for window elements

🎯 When to Use Sliding Window?

✅ "Contiguous subarray/substring" - Window must be continuous
✅ "Longest/Shortest with condition" - Variable window problems
✅ "At most K distinct elements" - Classic variable window
✅ "Sum of subarray of size K" - Fixed window problems
✅ "Anagrams/Permutation in string" - Fixed window with frequency map

⚡ Code Templates

# Pattern 1: Fixed Size Window (Max Sum of K elements)

def max_sum_k(arr, k):
    n = len(arr)
    if n < k: return -1
    
    # Step 1: First window ka sum
    window_sum = sum(arr[:k])
    max_sum = window_sum
    
    # Step 2: Slide the window
    for i in range(k, n):
        window_sum += arr[i]      # Naya element add karo
        window_sum -= arr[i - k]  # Purana element remove karo
        max_sum = max(max_sum, window_sum)
    
    return max_sum

# Pattern 2: Variable Size Window (Longest Substring Without Repeating)

def length_of_longest_substring(s):
    char_index = {}              # Character ka last index track karo
    left = 0
    max_length = 0
    
    for right in range(len(s)):
        char = s[right]
        
        # Agar char pehle dekha hai aur window ke andar hai
        if char in char_index and char_index[char] >= left:
            left = char_index[char] + 1  # Window shrink karo
        
        char_index[char] = right         # Index update karo
        max_length = max(max_length, right - left + 1)
    
    return max_length

# Pattern 3: At Most K Distinct (Fruit Into Baskets)

def longest_with_k_distinct(s, k):
    freq = {}
    left = 0
    max_length = 0
    
    for right in range(len(s)):
        # Expand: Add right character
        freq[s[right]] = freq.get(s[right], 0) + 1
        
        # Shrink: While more than k distinct
        while len(freq) > k:
            freq[s[left]] -= 1
            if freq[s[left]] == 0:
                del freq[s[left]]
            left += 1
        
        max_length = max(max_length, right - left + 1)
    
    return max_length

💡 Pro Tips & Tricks

🔴 Fixed vs Variable: Fixed = window size given | Variable = find optimal size

🟢 Shrink Condition: Use while not if - may need multiple shrinks

🔵 Minimum Window: Shrink as much as possible while condition holds, track min

🟣 Frequency Map: For string problems, use HashMap or array[26] for character count

Pattern Recognition: Contiguous subarray/substring, longest/shortest with condition, k distinct elements, anagram/permutation

3. Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters Medium 76. Minimum Window Substring Hard 239. Sliding Window Maximum Hard 438. Find All Anagrams in a String Medium 567. Permutation in String Medium 424. Longest Repeating Character Replacement Medium 904. Fruit Into Baskets Medium 1004. Max Consecutive Ones III Medium 992. Subarrays with K Different Integers Hard 862. Shortest Subarray with Sum at Least K Hard 930. Binary Subarrays With Sum Medium 1248. Count Number of Nice Subarrays Medium 1358. Number of Substrings Containing All Three Characters Medium 1423. Maximum Points You Can Obtain from Cards Medium 1438. Longest Continuous Subarray With Absolute Diff ≤ Limit Medium 1658. Minimum Operations to Reduce X to Zero Medium 1838. Frequency of the Most Frequent Element Medium 2461. Maximum Sum of Distinct Subarrays With Length K Medium 2516. Take K of Each Character From Left and Right Medium 1371. Find the Longest Substring Containing Vowels in Even Counts Medium 30. Substring with Concatenation of All Words Hard 3325. Count Substrings With K-Frequency Characters I Medium 3208. Alternating Groups II Medium 3254. Find the Power of K-Size Subarrays I Medium
🔍 BINARY SEARCH — Google Problems (32) ▶

📖 Algorithm Explanation

Binary Search eliminates half the search space in each iteration. Works on sorted data or when there's a monotonic property (if condition true at index i, it's true for all j > i or all j < i).

⏱️ Time Complexity

O(log n) - Halving each step

💾 Space Complexity

O(1) - Iterative | O(log n) - Recursive

🎯 When to Use Binary Search?

✅ Sorted Array: Find element, first/last occurrence, insert position
✅ Rotated Sorted Array: Find minimum, search element
✅ "Minimum/Maximum that satisfies condition" - Binary search on answer
✅ Peak/Valley Finding: Find peak element, mountain array
✅ Kth Element: Kth smallest in matrix, median of two arrays

⚡ Code Templates

# Pattern 1: Standard Binary Search

def binary_search(arr, target):
    left, right = 0, len(arr) - 1
    
    while left <= right:
        mid = left + (right - left) // 2  # Overflow prevent karo
        
        if arr[mid] == target:
            return mid
        elif arr[mid] < target:
            left = mid + 1
        else:
            right = mid - 1
    
    return -1  # Not found

# Pattern 2: First/Last Occurrence (Lower/Upper Bound)

def first_occurrence(arr, target):
    left, right = 0, len(arr) - 1
    result = -1
    
    while left <= right:
        mid = left + (right - left) // 2
        
        if arr[mid] == target:
            result = mid       # Found, but check left for earlier
            right = mid - 1
        elif arr[mid] < target:
            left = mid + 1
        else:
            right = mid - 1
    
    return result

# Pattern 3: Binary Search on Answer (Koko Eating Bananas)

def min_eating_speed(piles, h):
    def can_finish(speed):
        hours = sum((p + speed - 1) // speed for p in piles)
        return hours <= h
    
    left, right = 1, max(piles)
    
    while left < right:
        mid = left + (right - left) // 2
        
        if can_finish(mid):
            right = mid      # Try smaller speed
        else:
            left = mid + 1   # Need more speed
    
    return left

💡 Pro Tips & Tricks

🔴 Overflow Prevention: Use mid = left + (right - left) // 2 instead of (left + right) // 2

🟢 Loop Condition: while left <= right (standard) vs while left < right (boundary search)

🔵 Rotated Array: One half is always sorted. Check arr[left] <= arr[mid] to identify sorted half

🟣 Answer Space: Think "what's the range of possible answers?" then binary search on that range

Pattern Recognition: Sorted array, search in rotated, find peak/minimum, search answer space, kth element

704. Binary Search Easy 35. Search Insert Position Easy 33. Search in Rotated Sorted Array Medium 81. Search in Rotated Sorted Array II Medium 153. Find Minimum in Rotated Sorted Array Medium 154. Find Minimum in Rotated Sorted Array II Hard 162. Find Peak Element Medium 852. Peak Index in a Mountain Array Medium 34. Find First and Last Position of Element in Sorted Array Medium 4. Median of Two Sorted Arrays Hard 875. Koko Eating Bananas Medium 1011. Capacity To Ship Packages Within D Days Medium 410. Split Array Largest Sum Hard 74. Search a 2D Matrix Medium 240. Search a 2D Matrix II Medium 981. Time Based Key-Value Store Medium 1146. Snapshot Array Medium 1539. Kth Missing Positive Number Easy 378. Kth Smallest Element in a Sorted Matrix Medium 658. Find K Closest Elements Medium 2064. Minimized Maximum of Products Distributed to Any Store Medium 2070. Most Beautiful Item for Each Query Medium 2563. Count the Number of Fair Pairs Medium 2601. Prime Subtraction Operation Medium 1631. Path With Minimum Effort Medium 2577. Minimum Time to Visit a Cell In a Grid Hard 3008. Find Beautiful Indices in the Given Array II Hard 3356. Zero Array Transformation II Medium
📊 DYNAMIC PROGRAMMING — Google Problems (68) ▶

📖 Algorithm Explanation

Dynamic Programming breaks complex problems into simpler subproblems, storing results to avoid recomputation. Two approaches: Top-Down (Memoization) - recursion with cache, and Bottom-Up (Tabulation) - iterative filling of DP table.

⏱️ Time Complexity

O(states × transitions)

💾 Space Complexity

O(states) - Can optimize to O(1) or O(n)

🎯 When to Use Dynamic Programming?

✅ "Count number of ways" - Climbing stairs, unique paths, coin change II
✅ "Minimum/Maximum cost/value" - Min path sum, house robber, knapsack
✅ "Is it possible?" - Can partition, word break, target sum
✅ "Longest/Shortest subsequence" - LIS, LCS, edit distance
✅ Decision at each step: Take/Skip, Include/Exclude pattern

⚡ Code Templates

# Pattern 1: 1D DP (Fibonacci Pattern - House Robber)

def house_robber(nums):
    if not nums: return 0
    if len(nums) == 1: return nums[0]
    
    # dp[i] = max money robbing houses 0 to i
    prev2, prev1 = nums[0], max(nums[0], nums[1])
    
    for i in range(2, len(nums)):
        current = max(prev1, prev2 + nums[i])  # Skip or Rob
        prev2, prev1 = prev1, current
    
    return prev1

# Pattern 2: 2D DP (Grid - Unique Paths)

def unique_paths(m, n):
    dp = [[1] * n for _ in range(m)]
    
    for i in range(1, m):
        for j in range(1, n):
            dp[i][j] = dp[i-1][j] + dp[i][j-1]  # From top + from left
    
    return dp[m-1][n-1]

# Pattern 3: String DP (LCS - Longest Common Subsequence)

def longest_common_subsequence(text1, text2):
    m, n = len(text1), len(text2)
    dp = [[0] * (n + 1) for _ in range(m + 1)]
    
    for i in range(1, m + 1):
        for j in range(1, n + 1):
            if text1[i-1] == text2[j-1]:
                dp[i][j] = dp[i-1][j-1] + 1  # Match: diagonal + 1
            else:
                dp[i][j] = max(dp[i-1][j], dp[i][j-1])  # No match: max of skip either
    
    return dp[m][n]

# Pattern 4: Knapsack (0/1 Knapsack - Partition Equal Subset)

def can_partition(nums):
    total = sum(nums)
    if total % 2 != 0: return False
    
    target = total // 2
    dp = [False] * (target + 1)
    dp[0] = True
    
    for num in nums:
        for j in range(target, num - 1, -1):  # Reverse to avoid reuse
            dp[j] = dp[j] or dp[j - num]
    
    return dp[target]

💡 Pro Tips & Tricks

🔴 State Definition: Ask "What info do I need to make decision at position i?" - That's your state

🟢 Space Optimization: If dp[i] only depends on dp[i-1], use two variables instead of array

🔵 Recurrence Relation: Write how dp[i] relates to previous states before coding

🟣 Base Cases: dp[0] or dp[0][0] - What's the answer for empty/first element?

Pattern Recognition: Optimal substructure, overlapping subproblems, min/max paths, distinct ways, strings DP, decision making

70. Climbing Stairs Easy 198. House Robber Medium 213. House Robber II Medium 62. Unique Paths Medium 63. Unique Paths II Medium 64. Minimum Path Sum Medium 322. Coin Change Medium 518. Coin Change II Medium 300. Longest Increasing Subsequence Medium 1143. Longest Common Subsequence Medium 72. Edit Distance Medium 91. Decode Ways Medium 139. Word Break Medium 140. Word Break II Hard 55. Jump Game Medium 45. Jump Game II Medium 1696. Jump Game VI Medium 121. Best Time to Buy and Sell Stock Easy 122. Best Time to Buy and Sell Stock II Medium 309. Best Time to Buy and Sell Stock with Cooldown Medium 221. Maximal Square Medium 1277. Count Square Submatrices with All Ones Medium 416. Partition Equal Subset Sum Medium 494. Target Sum Medium 10. Regular Expression Matching Hard 44. Wildcard Matching Hard 132. Palindrome Partitioning II Hard 97. Interleaving String Medium 115. Distinct Subsequences Hard 983. Minimum Cost For Tickets Medium 1155. Number of Dice Rolls With Target Sum Medium 1105. Filling Bookcase Shelves Medium 1043. Partition Array for Maximum Sum Medium 1218. Longest Arithmetic Subsequence of Given Difference Medium 2707. Extra Characters in a String Medium 2684. Maximum Number of Moves in a Grid Medium 2463. Minimum Total Distance Traveled Hard 2407. Longest Increasing Subsequence II Hard 3351. Sum of Good Subsequences Hard
🌐 GRAPH / BFS / DFS — Google Problems (55) ▶

📖 Algorithm Explanation

BFS (Breadth-First Search) explores level by level using a queue - ideal for shortest path in unweighted graphs. DFS (Depth-First Search) explores as deep as possible using recursion/stack - ideal for path finding, cycle detection, connected components.

⏱️ Time Complexity

O(V + E) - Visit all vertices & edges

💾 Space Complexity

O(V) - Queue/Stack + Visited set

🎯 When to Use BFS vs DFS?

🔵 Use BFS When:

  • Shortest path (unweighted)
  • Level-order traversal
  • Minimum steps/moves
  • Nearest neighbor problems

🟢 Use DFS When:

  • Path exists check
  • Cycle detection
  • Connected components
  • Topological sort

⚡ Code Templates

# Pattern 1: BFS - Grid Traversal (Rotting Oranges)

from collections import deque

def bfs_grid(grid):
    rows, cols = len(grid), len(grid[0])
    queue = deque()
    visited = set()
    
    # Add all starting points
    for r in range(rows):
        for c in range(cols):
            if grid[r][c] == START:
                queue.append((r, c, 0))  # (row, col, distance)
                visited.add((r, c))
    
    directions = [(0,1), (0,-1), (1,0), (-1,0)]
    
    while queue:
        r, c, dist = queue.popleft()
        
        for dr, dc in directions:
            nr, nc = r + dr, c + dc
            if 0 <= nr < rows and 0 <= nc < cols and (nr, nc) not in visited:
                if grid[nr][nc] == TARGET:
                    return dist + 1
                visited.add((nr, nc))
                queue.append((nr, nc, dist + 1))
    
    return -1

# Pattern 2: DFS - Number of Islands

def num_islands(grid):
    if not grid: return 0
    rows, cols = len(grid), len(grid[0])
    count = 0
    
    def dfs(r, c):
        if r < 0 or r >= rows or c < 0 or c >= cols or grid[r][c] != '1':
            return
        grid[r][c] = '0'  # Mark visited
        dfs(r+1, c); dfs(r-1, c); dfs(r, c+1); dfs(r, c-1)
    
    for r in range(rows):
        for c in range(cols):
            if grid[r][c] == '1':
                dfs(r, c)
                count += 1
    
    return count

# Pattern 3: Topological Sort (Course Schedule)

from collections import defaultdict, deque

def can_finish(numCourses, prerequisites):
    graph = defaultdict(list)
    indegree = [0] * numCourses
    
    for course, prereq in prerequisites:
        graph[prereq].append(course)
        indegree[course] += 1
    
    queue = deque([i for i in range(numCourses) if indegree[i] == 0])
    completed = 0
    
    while queue:
        course = queue.popleft()
        completed += 1
        
        for next_course in graph[course]:
            indegree[next_course] -= 1
            if indegree[next_course] == 0:
                queue.append(next_course)
    
    return completed == numCourses

💡 Pro Tips & Tricks

🔴 4-Direction Movement: Use directions = [(0,1), (0,-1), (1,0), (-1,0)] for grid problems

🟢 Multi-source BFS: Add ALL starting points to queue first, then BFS (Rotting Oranges)

🔵 Cycle Detection: Use 3 colors - WHITE (unvisited), GRAY (in progress), BLACK (done)

🟣 Graph Building: Use defaultdict(list) for adjacency list representation

Pattern Recognition: Grid traversal, island problems, shortest path, topological sort, connected components, cycle detection

200. Number of Islands Medium 695. Max Area of Island Medium 133. Clone Graph Medium 207. Course Schedule Medium 210. Course Schedule II Medium 417. Pacific Atlantic Water Flow Medium 994. Rotting Oranges Medium 286. Walls and Gates Medium 127. Word Ladder Hard 79. Word Search Medium 212. Word Search II Hard 130. Surrounded Regions Medium 261. Graph Valid Tree Medium 323. Number of Connected Components in Undirected Graph Medium 785. Is Graph Bipartite? Medium 863. All Nodes Distance K in Binary Tree Medium 815. Bus Routes Hard 818. Race Car Hard 773. Sliding Puzzle Hard 1192. Critical Connections in a Network Hard 1101. The Earliest Moment When Everyone Become Friends Medium 1136. Parallel Courses Medium 2050. Parallel Courses III Hard 1334. Find the City With Smallest Number of Neighbors Medium 1976. Number of Ways to Arrive at Destination Medium 2101. Detonate the Maximum Bombs Medium 2115. Find All Possible Recipes from Given Supplies Medium 2127. Maximum Employees to Be Invited to a Meeting Hard 2812. Find the Safest Path in a Grid Medium 3286. Find a Safe Walk Through a Grid Medium 2290. Minimum Obstacle Removal to Reach Corner Hard 3327. Check if DFS Strings Are Palindromes Hard
🌳 TREES — Google Problems (45) ▶

📖 Algorithm Explanation

Tree problems use recursion naturally. Key insight: think from one node's perspective - what info do I need from children? What do I return to parent? Common patterns: DFS (preorder/inorder/postorder), BFS (level-order), and bottom-up vs top-down approaches.

⏱️ Time Complexity

O(n) - Visit each node once

💾 Space Complexity

O(h) - h = height (log n balanced, n worst)

⚡ Key Templates

# DFS Template (Max Depth Example)

def max_depth(root):
    if not root: return 0  # Base case
    left = max_depth(root.left)
    right = max_depth(root.right)
    return 1 + max(left, right)  # Combine

# BFS Level Order Template

def level_order(root):
    if not root: return []
    result, queue = [], deque([root])
    while queue:
        level = []
        for _ in range(len(queue)):  # Process current level
            node = queue.popleft()
            level.append(node.val)
            if node.left: queue.append(node.left)
            if node.right: queue.append(node.right)
        result.append(level)
    return result

💡 Pro Tips

BST Property: Inorder traversal gives sorted order. Use for validation/kth smallest.

LCA Pattern: If p and q on different sides, current node is LCA.

Path Sum: Pass running sum down, check at leaves. Return path for backtracking.

Pattern Recognition: Tree traversal (inorder/preorder/postorder), BST validation, LCA, path sum, serialize/deserialize, balanced tree

94. Binary Tree Inorder Traversal Easy 102. Binary Tree Level Order Traversal Medium 103. Binary Tree Zigzag Level Order Traversal Medium 104. Maximum Depth of Binary Tree Easy 100. Same Tree Easy 226. Invert Binary Tree Easy 101. Symmetric Tree Easy 105. Construct Binary Tree from Preorder and Inorder Medium 98. Validate Binary Search Tree Medium 230. Kth Smallest Element in a BST Medium 235. Lowest Common Ancestor of a BST Medium 236. Lowest Common Ancestor of a Binary Tree Medium 199. Binary Tree Right Side View Medium 1448. Count Good Nodes in Binary Tree Medium 110. Balanced Binary Tree Easy 543. Diameter of Binary Tree Easy 572. Subtree of Another Tree Easy 112. Path Sum Easy 113. Path Sum II Medium 437. Path Sum III Medium 124. Binary Tree Maximum Path Sum Hard 297. Serialize and Deserialize Binary Tree Hard 114. Flatten Binary Tree to Linked List Medium 116. Populating Next Right Pointers in Each Node Medium 129. Sum Root to Leaf Numbers Medium 337. House Robber III Medium 1110. Delete Nodes And Return Forest Medium 951. Flip Equivalent Binary Trees Medium 2641. Cousins in Binary Tree II Medium 2458. Height of Binary Tree After Subtree Removal Queries Hard
🗂️ HASH TABLE — Google Problems (48) ▶

📖 Algorithm Explanation

Hash Tables provide O(1) average lookup, insert, delete. Key patterns: frequency counting, two-pass vs one-pass (store complement), prefix sum with hash (subarray sum problems).

⏱️ Time Complexity

O(1) avg lookup/insert

💾 Space Complexity

O(n) - Store n elements

⚡ Key Templates

# Two Sum - One Pass (Store complement)

def two_sum(nums, target):
    seen = {}  # num -> index
    for i, num in enumerate(nums):
        complement = target - num
        if complement in seen:
            return [seen[complement], i]
        seen[num] = i

# Prefix Sum + Hash (Subarray Sum = K)

def subarray_sum(nums, k):
    prefix_count = {0: 1}  # prefix_sum -> count
    curr_sum, count = 0, 0
    for num in nums:
        curr_sum += num
        # If (curr_sum - k) exists, we found subarrays
        count += prefix_count.get(curr_sum - k, 0)
        prefix_count[curr_sum] = prefix_count.get(curr_sum, 0) + 1
    return count

💡 Pro Tips

Anagrams: Use sorted string or frequency count as key: tuple(sorted(s))

LRU Cache: HashMap + Doubly Linked List for O(1) operations

Counter: Use collections.Counter() for frequency counting

Pattern Recognition: Frequency counting, two sum variants, anagrams, duplicate detection, subarray sum

1. Two Sum Easy 242. Valid Anagram Easy 49. Group Anagrams Medium 217. Contains Duplicate Easy 219. Contains Duplicate II Easy 347. Top K Frequent Elements Medium 560. Subarray Sum Equals K Medium 128. Longest Consecutive Sequence Medium 535. Encode and Decode TinyURL Medium 146. LRU Cache Medium 460. LFU Cache Hard 380. Insert Delete GetRandom O(1) Medium 138. Copy List with Random Pointer Medium 41. First Missing Positive Hard 454. 4Sum II Medium 438. Find All Anagrams in a String Medium 76. Minimum Window Substring Hard 1207. Unique Number of Occurrences Easy 2215. Find the Difference of Two Arrays Easy 1590. Make Sum Divisible by P Medium 2501. Longest Square Streak in an Array Medium 2461. Maximum Sum of Distinct Subarrays With Length K Medium 2657. Find the Prefix Common Array of Two Arrays Medium 2559. Count Vowel Strings in Ranges Medium
📚 STACK & QUEUE — Google Problems (35) ▶

📖 Algorithm Explanation

Monotonic Stack maintains elements in sorted order (increasing/decreasing). Used for Next Greater Element, histogram area, stock span. Key idea: pop elements that violate monotonic property, they found their "answer".

⏱️ Time Complexity

O(n) - Each element pushed/popped once

💾 Space Complexity

O(n) - Stack size

⚡ Key Templates

# Monotonic Stack - Next Greater Element

def next_greater(nums):
    n = len(nums)
    result = [-1] * n
    stack = []  # Store indices
    
    for i in range(n):
        # Pop all smaller elements - current is their "next greater"
        while stack and nums[stack[-1]] < nums[i]:
            result[stack.pop()] = nums[i]
        stack.append(i)
    
    return result

# Largest Rectangle in Histogram

def largest_rectangle(heights):
    stack = []  # (index, height)
    max_area = 0
    
    for i, h in enumerate(heights):
        start = i
        while stack and stack[-1][1] > h:
            idx, height = stack.pop()
            max_area = max(max_area, height * (i - idx))
            start = idx
        stack.append((start, h))
    
    for idx, height in stack:
        max_area = max(max_area, height * (len(heights) - idx))
    
    return max_area

💡 Pro Tips

Parentheses: Push opening, pop & match on closing. Stack empty at end = valid.

Calculator: Use stack for numbers, handle signs, process on +/- or end.

Decode String: Push current string & count on '[', pop & build on ']'.

Pattern Recognition: Monotonic stack, next greater element, valid parentheses, calculator, histogram area

20. Valid Parentheses Easy 22. Generate Parentheses Medium 155. Min Stack Medium 150. Evaluate Reverse Polish Notation Medium 739. Daily Temperatures Medium 496. Next Greater Element I Easy 503. Next Greater Element II Medium 84. Largest Rectangle in Histogram Hard 85. Maximal Rectangle Hard 42. Trapping Rain Water Hard 224. Basic Calculator Hard 227. Basic Calculator II Medium 394. Decode String Medium 735. Asteroid Collision Medium 1047. Remove All Adjacent Duplicates In String Easy 402. Remove K Digits Medium 853. Car Fleet Medium 901. Online Stock Span Medium 1475. Final Prices With a Special Discount Easy 2434. Using a Robot to Print Lexicographically Smallest String Medium
⛰️ HEAP / PRIORITY QUEUE — Google Problems (25) ▶

📖 Algorithm Explanation

Heap = complete binary tree with heap property. Min-heap: parent ≤ children (smallest at top). Max-heap: parent ≥ children (largest at top). Use for K largest/smallest, merge K sorted, running median.

⏱️ Time Complexity

O(log n) push/pop, O(n log k) for K elements

💾 Space Complexity

O(k) for K elements heap

⚡ Key Templates

# Kth Largest Element (Min-Heap of size K)

import heapq

def kth_largest(nums, k):
    min_heap = []
    
    for num in nums:
        heapq.heappush(min_heap, num)
        if len(min_heap) > k:
            heapq.heappop(min_heap)  # Remove smallest
    
    return min_heap[0]  # Kth largest at top

# Median from Data Stream (Two Heaps)

class MedianFinder:
    def __init__(self):
        self.small = []  # Max-heap (negate values)
        self.large = []  # Min-heap
    
    def addNum(self, num):
        heapq.heappush(self.small, -num)
        heapq.heappush(self.large, -heapq.heappop(self.small))
        
        if len(self.large) > len(self.small):
            heapq.heappush(self.small, -heapq.heappop(self.large))
    
    def findMedian(self):
        if len(self.small) > len(self.large):
            return -self.small[0]
        return (-self.small[0] + self.large[0]) / 2

# Merge K Sorted Lists

def merge_k_lists(lists):
    min_heap = []
    for i, lst in enumerate(lists):
        if lst:
            heapq.heappush(min_heap, (lst.val, i, lst))
    
    dummy = curr = ListNode(0)
    while min_heap:
        val, i, node = heapq.heappop(min_heap)
        curr.next = node
        curr = curr.next
        if node.next:
            heapq.heappush(min_heap, (node.next.val, i, node.next))
    
    return dummy.next

💡 Pro Tips

K Largest → Min-Heap: Keep size K, smallest gets popped, K largest remain!

K Smallest → Max-Heap: Or just use min-heap and return first K elements.

Max-Heap in Python: Negate values! Push -x, pop gives -largest.

Meeting Rooms: Min-heap of end times. If start ≥ heap[0], pop (room freed).

Pattern Recognition: K largest/smallest, merge K lists, median finder, schedule tasks, meeting rooms

215. Kth Largest Element in an Array Medium 703. Kth Largest Element in a Stream Easy 1046. Last Stone Weight Easy 23. Merge k Sorted Lists Hard 295. Find Median from Data Stream Hard 480. Sliding Window Median Hard 621. Task Scheduler Medium 253. Meeting Rooms II Medium 973. K Closest Points to Origin Medium 767. Reorganize String Medium 632. Smallest Range Covering Elements from K Lists Hard 355. Design Twitter Medium 2530. Maximal Score After Applying K Operations Medium 2406. Divide Intervals Into Minimum Number of Groups Medium 2182. Construct String With Repeat Limit Medium 2208. Minimum Operations to Halve Array Sum Medium
🎯 OTHER PATTERNS — Google Problems (120+) ▶

📖 Multi-Pattern Overview

This section covers essential patterns: Linked List (reverse, cycle detection), Backtracking (permutations, combinations), Math/Bit manipulation, Intervals (merge, meeting rooms), Trie (prefix tree), Union-Find (disjoint sets), and Greedy algorithms.

⚡ Essential Templates

# Linked List - Reverse

def reverse(head):
    prev, curr = None, head
    while curr:
        next_node = curr.next
        curr.next = prev
        prev, curr = curr, next_node
    return prev

# Backtracking - Subsets/Combinations

def backtrack(start, path, result, nums):
    result.append(path[:])  # Add current subset
    for i in range(start, len(nums)):
        path.append(nums[i])
        backtrack(i + 1, path, result, nums)
        path.pop()  # Backtrack

# Union-Find (Disjoint Set)

class UnionFind:
    def __init__(self, n):
        self.parent = list(range(n))
        self.rank = [0] * n
    
    def find(self, x):
        if self.parent[x] != x:
            self.parent[x] = self.find(self.parent[x])  # Path compression
        return self.parent[x]
    
    def union(self, x, y):
        px, py = self.find(x), self.find(y)
        if px == py: return False
        if self.rank[px] < self.rank[py]: px, py = py, px
        self.parent[py] = px
        if self.rank[px] == self.rank[py]: self.rank[px] += 1
        return True

# Intervals - Merge Overlapping

def merge(intervals):
    intervals.sort(key=lambda x: x[0])
    merged = [intervals[0]]
    for start, end in intervals[1:]:
        if start <= merged[-1][1]:
            merged[-1][1] = max(merged[-1][1], end)
        else:
            merged.append([start, end])
    return merged

💡 Pro Tips

Linked List: Use dummy node for edge cases. Floyd's for cycle (slow/fast pointers).

Backtracking: Choose → Explore → Unchoose. Skip duplicates with sort + check.

Union-Find: Use for connected components. Path compression + rank = O(α(n)) ≈ O(1).

Trie: Prefix search O(m). Build: insert char-by-char. Mark end of word.

Intervals: Always sort by start. Merge: check overlap with last end.

Includes: Linked List, Backtracking, Math/Bit, Intervals, Trie, Union Find, Greedy, String, Design, Array

🔗 Linked List
206. Reverse Linked List Easy 21. Merge Two Sorted Lists Easy 141. Linked List Cycle Easy 142. Linked List Cycle II Medium 2. Add Two Numbers Medium 19. Remove Nth Node From End of List Medium 143. Reorder List Medium 25. Reverse Nodes in k-Group Hard

78. Subsets Medium 90. Subsets II Medium 46. Permutations Medium 47. Permutations II Medium 39. Combination Sum Medium 40. Combination Sum II Medium 131. Palindrome Partitioning Medium 17. Letter Combinations of a Phone Number Medium 51. N-Queens Hard 37. Sudoku Solver Hard
🔢 Math & Bit Manipulation

📅 Intervals
56. Merge Intervals Medium 57. Insert Interval Medium 435. Non-overlapping Intervals Medium 252. Meeting Rooms Easy 452. Minimum Number of Arrows to Burst Balloons Medium

Complete Algorithm Templates — Code Templates with Detailed Explanation!

Ye section har major pattern ka complete step-by-step algorithm, code template, aur dry run dega. Interview mein ye templates directly apply kar sakte ho!

📘 TWO POINTER — Complete Guide ▶
🎓 Theory — Samjho Pehle!

Two Pointer ek technique hai jahan hum do index variables (pointers) use karte hain array/string traverse karne ke liye. Ye O(n²) brute force ko O(n) mein convert kar deta hai!

Core Idea: Dono pointers intelligently move karte hain based on current state — kabhi ek move hota hai, kabhi dono. Ye sorted arrays mein especially powerful hai kyunki hum jante hain ki left move karne se sum badhega, right move karne se ghatega!

🔄 4 Types of Two Pointer — Har Type Kab Use Karein?
Type 1: Opposite Direction (Converging) 👉...👈

Kya hai: left = 0, right = n-1 se start. Dono middle ki taraf aate hain.

Kab use karein:

  • Sorted array mein pair sum find karna (Two Sum II)
  • Palindrome check karna
  • Container with Most Water
  • 3Sum, 4Sum (nested two pointers)
  • Trapping Rain Water

Logic: if sum < target: left++ (sum badhao) | if sum > target: right-- (sum ghatao)

📝 Practice (5 Questions):

Two Sum II 3Sum Container With Most Water Trapping Rain Water Valid Palindrome
Type 2: Same Direction (Fast-Slow / Tortoise-Hare) 🐢...🐇

Kya hai: Dono same side se start, but different speeds se move karte hain.

Kab use karein:

  • Linked List mein cycle detect karna (Floyd's Algorithm)
  • Linked List ka middle find karna
  • Find duplicate number in [1, n]
  • Happy Number check

Logic: slow = slow.next | fast = fast.next.next — Agar cycle hai toh zaroor milenge!

📝 Practice (5 Questions):

Linked List Cycle Linked List Cycle II Middle of Linked List Find Duplicate Number Happy Number
Type 3: Read-Write Pointers (In-place Modification) 📖✍️

Kya hai: Read pointer scan karta hai, Write pointer valid elements likhta hai.

Kab use karein:

  • Remove Duplicates from Sorted Array
  • Move Zeroes to End
  • Remove Element
  • Sort Colors (Dutch National Flag)

Logic: if valid: arr[write++] = arr[read] — O(1) extra space mein modify!

📝 Practice (5 Questions):

Remove Duplicates Move Zeroes Remove Element Sort Colors Remove Duplicates II
Type 4: Fixed Distance Pointers 📏📏

Kya hai: Do pointers k distance apart rakhte hain.

Kab use karein:

  • Remove Nth Node From End of List
  • Rotate List by K
  • Get Kth node from end

Logic: Pehle fast ko k steps aage bhejo, fir dono saath chalo jab tak fast end pe na pahunche!

📝 Practice (5 Questions):

Remove Nth Node Rotate List Reorder List Palindrome Linked List Intersection of Two Lists
⚡ Algorithm Template — Copy-Paste Ready!

# Type 1: Converging Pointers (Two Sum in Sorted Array)

def two_sum_sorted(arr, target):
    left, right = 0, len(arr) - 1   # Start from both ends
    
    while left < right:              # Jab tak cross na ho
        current_sum = arr[left] + arr[right]
        
        if current_sum == target:
            return [left, right]     # Found! ✅
        elif current_sum < target:
            left += 1                # Sum chhota hai, left badha
        else:
            right -= 1               # Sum bada hai, right ghata
    
    return [-1, -1]                  # Not found

# Type 2: Fast-Slow (Linked List Cycle Detection)

def has_cycle(head):
    slow = fast = head
    
    while fast and fast.next:        # Fast valid hai check karo
        slow = slow.next             # 1 step
        fast = fast.next.next        # 2 steps
        
        if slow == fast:             # Agar mile toh cycle hai!
            return True
    
    return False                     # Cycle nahi hai

# Type 3: Read-Write (Remove Duplicates from Sorted Array)

def remove_duplicates(arr):
    if not arr: return 0
    
    write = 1                        # Write pointer (pehla element toh unique hai)
    
    for read in range(1, len(arr)):  # Read pointer scan karta hai
        if arr[read] != arr[read-1]: # Naya element mila?
            arr[write] = arr[read]   # Write position pe likho
            write += 1               # Write aage badho
    
    return write                     # New length
🔬 Dry Run — Step by Step Dekho!

Problem: Two Sum II — arr = [2, 7, 11, 15], target = 9

Step left right arr[left] arr[right] Sum Action
1032151717 > 9, right--
2022111313 > 9, right--
301279Found! ✅

Result: Return [0, 1] — indices 0 aur 1 pe elements 2 + 7 = 9!

🎯 Practice Problems — Solve Karo!
1. Two Sum II - Input Array Is Sorted Easy
2. 3Sum Medium
3. Container With Most Water Medium
4. Remove Duplicates from Sorted Array Easy
5. Trapping Rain Water Hard
📗 SLIDING WINDOW — Complete Guide ▶
🎓 Theory — Samjho Pehle!

Sliding Window ek technique hai jahan hum ek "window" (contiguous subarray) maintain karte hain jo data structure pe slide karti hai. Ye O(n²) brute force ko O(n) mein convert kar deta hai by avoiding repetitive computations!

Core Idea: Pichle window ka result reuse karo! Jab window slide ho, sirf naya element add karo aur purana element remove karo — poora window dubara calculate mat karo!

🔄 2 Types of Sliding Window
Type 1: Fixed Size Window 📏

Kya hai: Window size k fix hai, bas slide hoti hai left to right.

Kab use karein:

  • Maximum sum of k consecutive elements
  • Find all anagrams in string (pattern length fixed)
  • Maximum of all subarrays of size k
  • Average of k elements

Steps: 1) First k elements ka result nikalo. 2) Slide: arr[i] add, arr[i-k] remove. 3) Update answer.

📝 Practice (5 Questions):

Max Average Subarray Find All Anagrams Sliding Window Maximum Permutation in String Contains Duplicate II
Type 2: Variable Size Window 📐↔️

Kya hai: Window expand/shrink hoti hai based on condition.

Kab use karein:

  • Longest substring without repeating characters
  • Minimum window substring
  • Longest substring with at most k distinct chars
  • Smallest subarray with sum >= k

Steps: 1) Expand right (right++). 2) Condition invalid? Shrink left (left++). 3) Valid window pe answer update karo.

📝 Practice (5 Questions):

Longest Substring Minimum Window Substring Longest Repeating Char Min Size Subarray Sum Fruit Into Baskets
⚡ Algorithm Template — Copy-Paste Ready!

# Fixed Size: Maximum Sum of K Elements

def max_sum_k(arr, k):
    n = len(arr)
    if n < k: return -1
    
    # Step 1: First window ka sum
    window_sum = sum(arr[:k])
    max_sum = window_sum
    
    # Step 2: Slide the window
    for i in range(k, n):
        window_sum += arr[i]      # Naya element add karo
        window_sum -= arr[i - k]  # Purana element remove karo
        max_sum = max(max_sum, window_sum)
    
    return max_sum

# Variable Size: Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters

def length_of_longest_substring(s):
    char_index = {}              # Character ka last index track karo
    left = 0
    max_length = 0
    
    for right in range(len(s)):
        char = s[right]
        
        # Agar char pehle dekha hai aur window ke andar hai
        if char in char_index and char_index[char] >= left:
            left = char_index[char] + 1  # Window shrink karo
        
        char_index[char] = right         # Index update karo
        max_length = max(max_length, right - left + 1)
    
    return max_length
🔬 Dry Run — Variable Size Window

Problem: Longest Substring Without Repeating — s = "abcabcbb"

right char left Window Length max_length
0a0"a"11
1b0"ab"22
2c0"abc"33
3a1"bca"33
4b2"cab"33

Result: max_length = 3 — "abc" longest unique substring hai!

🎯 Practice Problems — Solve Karo!
1. Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters Medium
2. Minimum Window Substring Hard
3. Sliding Window Maximum Hard
4. Permutation in String Medium
5. Longest Repeating Character Replacement Medium
📙 DYNAMIC PROGRAMMING — Complete Guide ▶
🎓 Theory — Samjho Pehle!

Dynamic Programming (DP) ek optimization technique hai jahan hum overlapping subproblems ke results store karte hain taaki dubara calculate na karna pade. Ye exponential time complexity ko polynomial mein convert kar deta hai!

2 Key Properties:
1. Overlapping Subproblems — Same subproblem baar baar aata hai (Fibonacci mein f(3) multiple times calculate hota)
2. Optimal Substructure — Optimal solution smaller optimal solutions se banta hai

🔄 5 Major DP Patterns (LeetCode Famous!)
Pattern 1: Min/Max Path to Target 🎯

Statement: Given target, find minimum/maximum cost/path/sum to reach it.

Formula: dp[i] = min(dp[i-1], dp[i-2], ..., dp[i-k]) + cost[i]

📝 Practice (5 Questions):

Coin Change Min Cost Climbing Min Path Sum Triangle Min Falling Path
Pattern 2: Distinct Ways 🔢

Statement: Count number of distinct ways to reach target.

Formula: dp[i] = dp[i-1] + dp[i-2] + ... + dp[i-k]

📝 Practice (5 Questions):

Climbing Stairs Unique Paths Unique Paths II Combination Sum IV Decode Ways
Pattern 3: DP on Strings 🔤

Statement: Given two strings s1, s2, find some result (LCS, Edit Distance).

Formula: 2D DP — if s1[i]==s2[j]: dp[i][j] = dp[i-1][j-1] + 1

📝 Practice (5 Questions):

LCS Edit Distance Longest Palindrome Subseq Longest Palindrome Substr Distinct Subsequences
Pattern 4: Decision Making (Take/Skip) ✅❌

Statement: At each state, decide to take or skip current value.

Formula: dp[i] = max(dp[i-1], dp[i-2] + arr[i]) (House Robber style)

📝 Practice (5 Questions):

House Robber House Robber II Buy Sell Stock Partition Equal Subset Target Sum
Pattern 5: Merging Intervals 🔗

Statement: Find optimal way to merge/split intervals.

Formula: dp[i][j] = dp[i][k] + result[k] + dp[k+1][j]

📝 Practice (5 Questions):

Burst Balloons Min Cost Tree Palindrome Partition II Stone Game Min Score Triangulation
⚡ Algorithm Templates — Copy-Paste Ready!

# Pattern 1: Coin Change (Min Path to Target)

def coin_change(coins, amount):
    dp = [float('inf')] * (amount + 1)
    dp[0] = 0  # 0 amount ke liye 0 coins chahiye
    
    for i in range(1, amount + 1):      # Har amount ke liye
        for coin in coins:               # Har coin try karo
            if coin <= i:                # Valid hai?
                dp[i] = min(dp[i], dp[i - coin] + 1)
    
    return dp[amount] if dp[amount] != float('inf') else -1

# Pattern 2: Climbing Stairs (Distinct Ways)

def climb_stairs(n):
    if n <= 2: return n
    
    dp = [0] * (n + 1)
    dp[1] = 1  # 1 way to reach stair 1
    dp[2] = 2  # 2 ways to reach stair 2
    
    for i in range(3, n + 1):
        dp[i] = dp[i-1] + dp[i-2]  # Last step se 1 ya 2 step se aa sakte
    
    return dp[n]

# Pattern 4: House Robber (Decision Making)

def house_robber(nums):
    if not nums: return 0
    if len(nums) == 1: return nums[0]
    
    dp = [0] * len(nums)
    dp[0] = nums[0]                      # First house rob karo
    dp[1] = max(nums[0], nums[1])        # First ya second, jo bada ho
    
    for i in range(2, len(nums)):
        # Skip current house OR rob current + whatever we had 2 houses ago
        dp[i] = max(dp[i-1], dp[i-2] + nums[i])
    
    return dp[-1]
🧠 DP Problem Solving Steps — Ye Follow Karo!
  1. State Define Karo: dp[i] kya represent karta hai? (e.g., dp[i] = min coins for amount i)
  2. Recurrence Relation Likho: dp[i] kaise dp[i-1], dp[i-2] se derive hota hai?
  3. Base Cases Handle Karo: dp[0], dp[1] kya hoga? (smallest subproblems)
  4. Iteration Order Decide Karo: Left to right? Bottom to top? Depends on dependency.
  5. Space Optimize Karo (Optional): Agar sirf dp[i-1], dp[i-2] chahiye toh 2 variables use karo!

💡 Pro Tip: Agar DP confusing lage, pehle recursive solution likho with memoization, phir bottom-up convert karo!

🎯 Practice Problems — Solve Karo!
1. Climbing Stairs Easy
2. Coin Change Medium
3. Longest Common Subsequence Medium
4. House Robber Medium
5. Edit Distance Medium
📕 BINARY SEARCH — Complete Guide ▶
🎓 Binary Search Kab Use Karein?
  • ✅ Sorted array mein element search karna
  • ✅ First/Last occurrence find karna (Lower/Upper Bound)
  • ✅ Rotated sorted array mein search/min find
  • ✅ Search space pe binary search (Koko eating bananas, capacity to ship)
  • ✅ "Minimum maximum" ya "Maximum minimum" wording dikhe
⚡ Templates

# Classic Binary Search

def binary_search(arr, target):
    left, right = 0, len(arr) - 1
    
    while left <= right:
        mid = left + (right - left) // 2  # Overflow safe
        
        if arr[mid] == target:
            return mid                     # Found!
        elif arr[mid] < target:
            left = mid + 1                 # Right half mein dekho
        else:
            right = mid - 1                # Left half mein dekho
    
    return -1                              # Not found

# Binary Search on Answer (Koko Eating Bananas style)

def min_eating_speed(piles, h):
    left, right = 1, max(piles)  # Answer range
    
    while left < right:
        mid = left + (right - left) // 2
        hours = sum((p + mid - 1) // mid for p in piles)  # Ceiling division
        
        if hours <= h:
            right = mid      # Can do faster, try smaller
        else:
            left = mid + 1   # Too slow, need to eat faster
    
    return left
🎯 Practice Problems — Solve Karo!
1. Binary Search Easy
2. Search in Rotated Sorted Array Medium
3. Find Minimum in Rotated Sorted Array Medium
4. Koko Eating Bananas Medium
5. Median of Two Sorted Arrays Hard
📓 GRAPH ALGORITHMS — Complete Guide ▶
🎓 Graph Representation Samjho!

Adjacency List (Most Used) ✅

# Python
graph = defaultdict(list)
graph[0].append(1)  # 0 -> 1
graph[0].append(2)  # 0 -> 2

Edge List (Union Find)

edges = [[0,1], [0,2], [1,2]]
# Kripke/MST ke liye
🔄 BFS vs DFS — Kab Kya Use Karein?
BFS (Breadth-First Search) — Level by Level 🌊

Kab use karein:

  • Shortest path in unweighted graph (MUST use BFS!)
  • Level order traversal (Tree)
  • Nearest neighbor problems
  • Rotten Oranges, Walls and Gates

Data Structure: Queue (FIFO)

📝 Practice (5 Questions):

Level Order Traversal Rotting Oranges Word Ladder 01 Matrix Shortest Path Binary
DFS (Depth-First Search) — Deep Dive First 🏊

Kab use karein:

  • All paths find karna
  • Cycle detection
  • Topological sort
  • Connected components
  • Number of Islands, Clone Graph

Data Structure: Stack (ya Recursion)

📝 Practice (5 Questions):

Number of Islands Clone Graph Course Schedule Pacific Atlantic Surrounded Regions
⚡ Templates

# BFS Template (Shortest Path)

from collections import deque

def bfs(graph, start):
    visited = set([start])
    queue = deque([start])
    level = 0
    
    while queue:
        size = len(queue)                # Current level size
        for _ in range(size):            # Process entire level
            node = queue.popleft()
            for neighbor in graph[node]:
                if neighbor not in visited:
                    visited.add(neighbor)
                    queue.append(neighbor)
        level += 1                       # Next level
    
    return level

# DFS Template (Recursive)

def dfs(graph, node, visited):
    if node in visited: return
    visited.add(node)
    
    for neighbor in graph[node]:
        dfs(graph, neighbor, visited)

# Usage: visited = set(); dfs(graph, 0, visited)

# Number of Islands (DFS on Grid)

def num_islands(grid):
    if not grid: return 0
    rows, cols = len(grid), len(grid[0])
    count = 0
    
    def dfs(r, c):
        if r < 0 or r >= rows or c < 0 or c >= cols: return
        if grid[r][c] != '1': return
        
        grid[r][c] = '0'  # Mark visited
        dfs(r+1, c); dfs(r-1, c)  # Up/Down
        dfs(r, c+1); dfs(r, c-1)  # Left/Right
    
    for r in range(rows):
        for c in range(cols):
            if grid[r][c] == '1':
                dfs(r, c)
                count += 1
    return count
🎯 Practice Problems — Solve Karo!
1. Number of Islands Medium
2. Clone Graph Medium
3. Course Schedule (Topological Sort) Medium
4. Rotting Oranges (BFS) Medium
5. Word Ladder Hard
🌳 TREE TRAVERSAL — Complete Guide ▶
🎓 Traversal Types — Kab Kya Use Karein?
Inorder (Left → Root → Right): BST mein sorted order milta hai! Kth smallest/largest find karo.
Kth Smallest Validate BST BST Iterator Recover BST Sorted Array to BST
Preorder (Root → Left → Right): Tree copy/serialize karna ho. Root pehle process.
Construct from Preorder Serialize Tree Flatten Tree Max Path Sum Path Sum II
Postorder (Left → Right → Root): Tree delete karna ho. Children pehle process, root last.
LCA Diameter Max Depth Balanced Tree Subtree Check
Level Order (BFS): Level by level traverse. Shortest path tree mein.
Level Order Zigzag Level Right Side View Average of Levels Next Right Pointers
⚡ Templates

# Inorder Traversal (Recursive)

def inorder(root, result=[]):
    if not root: return result
    inorder(root.left, result)     # Left subtree
    result.append(root.val)        # Root
    inorder(root.right, result)    # Right subtree
    return result

# Level Order (BFS) — Most Asked!

def level_order(root):
    if not root: return []
    result = []
    queue = deque([root])
    
    while queue:
        level = []
        for _ in range(len(queue)):  # Process entire level
            node = queue.popleft()
            level.append(node.val)
            if node.left: queue.append(node.left)
            if node.right: queue.append(node.right)
        result.append(level)
    
    return result
🎯 Practice Problems — Solve Karo!
1. Binary Tree Level Order Traversal Medium
2. Validate Binary Search Tree Medium
3. Lowest Common Ancestor of a Binary Tree Medium
4. Kth Smallest Element in a BST Medium
5. Serialize and Deserialize Binary Tree Hard
⛰️ HEAP / PRIORITY QUEUE — Complete Guide ▶
🎓 Heap Types — Kab Kya Use Karein?
Type 1: Top K Elements 🏆

Kab use karein: "Top K", "K largest/smallest", "K most frequent"

Trick: Top K largest → Min Heap of size K | Top K smallest → Max Heap of size K

Kth Largest Top K Frequent K Closest Points Kth in Stream Sort by Frequency
Type 2: Two Heaps (Median Stream) ⚖️

Kab use karein: Stream median, sliding window median

Trick: Max Heap (left half) + Min Heap (right half), balance sizes!

Median from Stream Sliding Window Median IPO Find Right Interval Maximize Sum
Type 3: Merge K Sorted 🔀

Kab use karein: Merge K sorted arrays/lists, smallest range

Trick: Min Heap with one element from each list

Merge K Lists Smallest Range K Pairs Smallest Kth in Sorted Matrix Ugly Number II
Type 4: Scheduling / Greedy 📅

Kab use karein: Meeting rooms, task scheduler, CPU scheduling

Trick: Sort by start time, use heap for end times/cooldowns

Task Scheduler Meeting Rooms II Reorganize String Car Pooling Process Tasks
⚡ Templates

# Top K Frequent Elements

import heapq
from collections import Counter

def top_k_frequent(nums, k):
    count = Counter(nums)
    # heapq is min-heap by default, use negative for max behavior
    return heapq.nlargest(k, count.keys(), key=count.get)
    
    # OR manually with min-heap of size k:
    # heap = []
    # for num, freq in count.items():
    #     heapq.heappush(heap, (freq, num))
    #     if len(heap) > k:
    #         heapq.heappop(heap)  # Remove smallest freq
    # return [num for freq, num in heap]

# Merge K Sorted Lists

def merge_k_lists(lists):
    heap = []
    for i, lst in enumerate(lists):
        if lst:
            heapq.heappush(heap, (lst.val, i, lst))
    
    dummy = ListNode()
    curr = dummy
    
    while heap:
        val, i, node = heapq.heappop(heap)
        curr.next = node
        curr = curr.next
        if node.next:
            heapq.heappush(heap, (node.next.val, i, node.next))
    
    return dummy.next
🎯 Practice Problems — Solve Karo!
1. Kth Largest Element in an Array Medium
2. Top K Frequent Elements Medium
3. Merge K Sorted Lists Hard
4. Find Median from Data Stream Hard
5. Task Scheduler Medium
🔙 BACKTRACKING — Complete Guide ▶
🎓 Backtracking Kya Hai?

Backtracking = Enhanced DFS + Undo. Hum ek path try karte hain, agar kaam nahi karta toh backtrack (wapis aao) aur dusra option try karo. Ye "All possible combinations/permutations/subsets" problems ke liye perfect hai!

⚠️ Warning: Time complexity usually O(2^n) ya O(n!) hai — exponential! Pruning important hai.

📋 Backtracking Types — 3 Categories
Type 1: Subsets / Combinations 🧩

Pattern: Include/Exclude elements, order doesn't matter

Key: for i in range(start, n) — avoid duplicates

Subsets Subsets II Combinations Combination Sum Combination Sum II
Type 2: Permutations 🔄

Pattern: Order matters, use all elements

Key: for i in range(0, n) + visited set

Permutations Permutations II Letter Case Permutation Next Permutation Palindrome Perm II
Type 3: Grid / Constraint-based 🎯

Pattern: Valid placement, constraint satisfaction

Key: isValid() check before placing + undo

N-Queens Sudoku Solver Word Search Word Search II Restore IP Addresses
Type 4: Partitioning / String 📝

Pattern: Split into valid parts, generate strings

Key: Partition at each index, validate before recursing

Palindrome Partition Generate Parentheses Phone Letter Combos Expression Operators Additive Number
⚡ Universal Backtracking Template

# Subsets (Power Set)

def subsets(nums):
    result = []
    
    def backtrack(start, path):
        result.append(path[:])        # Current subset add karo
        
        for i in range(start, len(nums)):
            path.append(nums[i])       # Choose
            backtrack(i + 1, path)     # Explore (start from i+1, not 0!)
            path.pop()                 # Un-choose (BACKTRACK!)
    
    backtrack(0, [])
    return result

# Output: [[], [1], [1,2], [1,2,3], [1,3], [2], [2,3], [3]]

💡 Key Insight: Subsets vs Permutations difference:
• Subsets: for i in range(start, n) — Order matters nahi, [1,2] = [2,1]
• Permutations: for i in range(0, n) + visited set — [1,2] ≠ [2,1]

🎯 Practice Problems — Solve Karo!
1. Subsets Medium
2. Permutations Medium
3. Combination Sum Medium
4. Word Search Medium
5. N-Queens Hard

⚡ QUICK REFERENCE — Interview Mein Yaad Rakho!

Pattern Keyword/Signal Data Structure TC
Two PointerSorted array, pair sum, palindromeArray/StringO(n)
Sliding WindowSubarray, substring, contiguous, k sizeArray + HashMapO(n)
Dynamic ProgrammingMin/max path, count ways, optimalArray (1D/2D)O(n) - O(n²)
Binary SearchSorted, min of max, first/last occurArrayO(log n)
BFSShortest path (unweighted), level by levelQueueO(V+E)
DFSAll paths, cycle, connected componentsStack/RecursionO(V+E)
HeapTop K, Kth largest/smallest, merge KPriority QueueO(n log k)
BacktrackingAll combinations, permutations, subsetsRecursion + ListO(2ⁿ) / O(n!)
TriePrefix, autocomplete, word dictionaryTrie NodeO(word len)
Union FindConnected components, redundant connectionParent ArrayO(α(n)) ≈ O(1)
Monotonic StackNext greater/smaller, histogramStackO(n)
✅ Interview Opening Template

1. "Let me clarify — [restate problem]"
2. "Can I assume [edge cases]?"
3. "I'll start with brute force, then optimize"
4. "This looks like a [PATTERN] problem because..."

⏰ Time Management (45 min)

• 5 min: Understand + ask questions
• 5 min: Pattern identify + approach discuss
• 25 min: Code + explain while writing
• 10 min: Test + optimize + questions

Arrays & Hashing

Hash Maps, Sets, aur Array manipulation techniques

    Medium
📚 Problem #1
🎯 Pattern: HashMap/HashSet

Contains Duplicate

Array mein duplicate elements dhundne ke 4 tarike — simple se optimized tak! 🔍

🟢 Easy Level

Problem Kya Hai?

Ek integer array nums diya gaya hai. Tumhe batana hai ki array mein koi duplicate value hai ya nahi. Agar koi bhi value ek se zyada baar aati hai, toh true return karo, warna false.

🎯 Example: [1, 2, 3, 1] → true (kyunki 1 do baar aa raha hai)
🎯 Example: [1, 2, 3, 4] → false (sab unique hain)

🎭 Real-life Analogy — Samjho Asaan Bhasha Mein!

Scenario: Socho tumhare paas ek box of marbles hai aur har marble pe ek number likha hai. Tumhe batana hai ki koi bhi number do marbles pe repeat ho raha hai ya nahi? 🔵🔴🟢

Method 1 (Brute Force): Ek-ek marble uthao, baaki sab marbles se compare karo — "Yeh wali aur wo wali same toh nahi?" Time lagega bohot! 😅

Method 2 (Sorting): Saari marbles ko number wise line mein lagao — same number wali automatically paas paas aa jayengi! 📊

Method 3 (HashSet): Ek register maintain karo. Jab bhi marble dekho, register mein check karo — "Yeh number pehle likha hai kya?" Agar haan, duplicate mil gaya! Agar nahi, register mein likh do. ✍️

💡 Real Interview Insight: Interviewer actually ye dekhna chahta hai ki tum trade-off samajhte ho ya nahi — Time vs Space. HashSet fast hai but extra memory lagti hai. Sorting mein memory nahi lagti but original array change ho jata hai. Dono options discuss karo interview mein!

🎤 Interview Tips — Interviewer Ko Impress Karo!

  • ❓ Pehle clarifying questions poochho: "Kya array mein negative numbers ho sakte hain?" "Kya array sorted hai?" "Array kitna bada ho sakta hai?"
  • 📝 Brute force se shuru karo: "Sabse simple approach nested loops hai..." — Ye dikhata hai ki tum problem samajh gaye ho
  • 🚀 Phir optimize karo: "Isko improve karne ke liye, hum HashSet use kar sakte hain..." — Ye dikhata hai ki tum better solutions soch sakte ho
  • ⚖️ Trade-offs discuss karo: "HashSet O(n) time deta hai but O(n) extra space bhi leta hai. Agar space constraint ho toh sorting better hai"
  • 🔄 Edge cases mention karo: Empty array, single element array, all same elements, all unique elements

❓ Common Follow-up Questions — Ye Bhi Pooch Sakte Hain!

Q1: "Agar duplicates ki count return karni ho toh?"
→ HashMap use karo jo frequency store kare, phir count nikalo jo >1 hain

Q2: "Agar exactly k duplicates allowed hon toh?" (Contains Duplicate II)
→ HashMap mein index store karo, check karo ki same value ke beech ka gap ≤ k hai ya nahi

Q3: "Agar constant space mein karna ho aur array modify nahi kar sakte?"
→ Floyd's Cycle Detection use karo (advanced technique)

Q4: "Agar array bohot bada ho aur memory mein fit na ho?"
→ External sorting ya Bloom Filter consider karo (ye advanced hai, but mention karna good impression deta hai)

1

Brute Force Approach
