Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Sabse simple aur seedha tarika — har ek element ko baaki saare elements ke saath compare kar lo! 🔍

Matlab agar array mein 5 elements hain, toh pehle element ko baaki 4 se compare karo, phir doosre ko baaki 3 se, aur aisa hi chalte jao. Agar kabhi bhi do same values mil gayi, toh duplicate mil gaya!

💭 Socho jaise class mein sabke birthdays check kar rahe ho — har student ko har doosre student se poochna padega!

Algorithm (Steps)

  1. Do nested loops lagao — outer loop i ke liye, inner loop j ke liye
  2. Inner loop i + 1 se start karo (khud se compare mat karo!)
  3. Agar nums[i] == nums[j] toh turant true return karo
  4. Saari pairs check hone ke baad koi match nahi mila? false return karo
Python 
class Solution:
    def hasDuplicate(self, nums: List[int]) -> bool:
        for i in range(len(nums)):
            for j in range(i + 1, len(nums)):
                if nums[i] == nums[j]:
                    return True
        return False

Time & Space Complexity

⏱️ Time Complexity
O(n²)
💾 Space Complexity
O(1)
😅 Slow hai bhai! n elements ke liye n×n comparisons — 1000 elements = 10 lakh operations!
2

Sorting Approach

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Agar array ko sort kar dein, toh jo bhi duplicate elements honge, wo ek doosre ke paas aa jayenge! 📊

Phir bas ek simple loop lagao aur har element ko uske pichle wale se compare karo. Agar dono same hain = duplicate found! ✅

💭 Jaise students ko height ke hisaab se line mein khada karo — same height wale automatically paas paas aa jayenge!

Algorithm (Steps)

  1. Array ko sort karo (chhote se bade)
  2. Index 1 se loop start karo (0 se nahi, kyunki pehle element ka previous nahi hota)
  3. Har element ko uske previous element se compare karo
  4. Agar dono equal hain → true return karo
  5. Loop khatam ho gaya bina match ke? → false
Python 
class Solution:
    def hasDuplicate(self, nums: List[int]) -> bool:
        nums.sort()  # Array ko sort kar do
        for i in range(1, len(nums)):
            if nums[i] == nums[i - 1]:
                return True
        return False

Time & Space Complexity

⏱️ Time Complexity
O(n log n)
💾 Space Complexity
O(1)
🤔 Better than brute force! Sorting mein n log n lagta hai, jo n² se kaafi better hai.
3

Hash Set Approach

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Hash Set ek aisi data structure hai jo sirf unique values store karti hai, aur kisi bhi value ko O(1) time mein dhundh sakti hai! 🔥

Idea simple hai: Ek empty set lo. Array mein ghoomte jao — agar current number pehle se set mein hai, toh duplicate mil gaya! Warna use set mein daal do.

💭 Socho jaise ek register maintain kar rahe ho — har naya naam aane pe pehle check karo kahin pehle se toh nahi likha!

Algorithm (Steps)

  1. Ek empty set banao (seen = set())
  2. Array ke har number pe loop lagao
  3. Check karo: kya ye number pehle se set mein hai?
  4. Agar hai → true return (duplicate mila!)
  5. Nahi hai → set mein add kar do
  6. Loop khatam, koi duplicate nahi → false
Python 
class Solution:
    def hasDuplicate(self, nums: List[int]) -> bool:
        seen = set()  # Empty set banao
        for num in nums:
            if num in seen:  # Pehle dekha hai?
                return True
            seen.add(num)  # Set mein daal do
        return False

Time & Space Complexity

⏱️ Time Complexity
O(n)
💾 Space Complexity
O(n)
🚀 Best time complexity! Har element ko sirf ek baar dekhte hain.

🧠 Kyun Ye Approach Kaam Karta Hai? — Deep Understanding!

HashSet ki superpower hai ki wo O(1) time mein bata deta hai ki koi element usmein hai ya nahi! Ye internally hashing use karta hai.

Hashing ka logic: Har number ko ek "address" milta hai (hash function se). Jab check karte ho "5 hai kya?", toh seedha us address pe jaake dekh lete ho — poori list scan nahi karni padti! 🏠

Real-world example: Socho library mein books dhundhni hai. Brute force = har shelf check karo. HashSet = catalog dekho, seedha shelf number milo, wahan jao! 📚

⚡ Pro Tip: Python mein set() aur dict dono internally hash table use karte hain. Isliye in operator O(1) hai set/dict mein, but O(n) hai list mein!

📋 Step-by-Step Dry Run — Ek-Ek Step Samjho!

Input: nums = [1, 2, 3, 1]

Stepnumseen (Set)num in seen?Action
Start - {} (empty) - Initialize empty set
1 1 {} ❌ No Add 1 → {1}
2 2 {1} ❌ No Add 2 → {1, 2}
3 3 {1, 2} ❌ No Add 3 → {1, 2, 3}
4 1 {1, 2, 3} ✅ YES! 🎉 Return True
👆 Dekho step 4 mein 1 dobara aaya — set mein pehle se tha — duplicate found! Loop pura complete hone ki zaroorat nahi, jaise hi duplicate mila, return kar diya!
4

Hash Set Length (One-Liner) 🎯

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Ye previous approach ka shortcut version hai! Set automatically duplicates remove kar deta hai.

Toh agar original array ki length set ki length se zyada hai, iska matlab kuch elements remove ho gaye — yani duplicates the! 🧠

💭 Jaise 10 students ki class mein agar unique roll numbers 8 hi nikle, toh 2 duplicates zaroor hain!
Python 
class Solution:
    def hasDuplicate(self, nums: List[int]) -> bool:
        return len(set(nums)) < len(nums)

Time & Space Complexity

⏱️ Time Complexity
O(n)
💾 Space Complexity
O(n)
✨ Cleanest code! Ek line mein kaam ho gaya. Interview mein impress karne ke liye perfect!
⚠️

Common Galtiyan (Pitfalls)

Galat Comparison in Brute Force

Nested loops mein sabse common mistake — inner loop ko i se start karna instead of i + 1. Isse element khud se compare ho jata hai!

Python ❌ Wrong 
for j in range(len(nums)):
    if nums[i] == nums[j]:
        return True
Python ✅ Correct 
for j in range(i + 1, len(nums)):
    if nums[i] == nums[j]:
        return True

Original Array Modify Karna

Sorting approach mein nums.sort() use karne se original array badal jata hai!

Python ⚠️ Risky 
nums.sort()
Python ✅ Safe 
sorted_nums = sorted(nums)

📋 Quick Comparison Table

Approach Time Space Notes
Brute Force O(n²) O(1) Slow but simple
Sorting O(n log n) O(1)* Better, modifies array
Hash Set O(n) O(n) Fast! Extra space
Set Length BEST O(n) O(n) Clean one-liner! ✨
📚 Problem #2
🎯 Pattern 11: Character Frequency

Valid Anagram

Do strings anagram hain ya nahi — 3 alag tarike se check karo! 🔤✨

🟢 Easy Level

Problem Kya Hai?

Do strings s aur t diye gaye hain. Tumhe batana hai ki kya t string s ka anagram hai ya nahi.

Anagram Kya Hota Hai?

Anagram matlab ek word ke letters ko rearrange karke doosra word banana. Dono words mein same characters hone chahiye, same frequency ke saath!

🎯 Example: "listen" aur "silent" → true (same letters, different order)
🎯 Example: "rat" aur "car" → false (different letters)
🎯 Example: "anagram" aur "nagaram" → true ✅
1

Sorting Approach

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Agar do strings anagram hain, toh unme exactly same characters honge with same frequencies! 🧩

Toh simple idea: Dono strings ko sort kar do! Agar anagram hain, toh sorting ke baad dono strings identical ho jayengi.

💭 "listen" → "eilnst" aur "silent" → "eilnst" — dono same! ✨

Algorithm (Steps)

  1. Pehle lengths check karo — agar different hain, toh directly false
  2. Dono strings ko sort karo
  3. Sorted strings ko compare karo
  4. Agar equal hain → true, warna → false
Python 
class Solution:
    def isAnagram(self, s: str, t: str) -> bool:
        if len(s) != len(t):
            return False
        
        return sorted(s) == sorted(t)

Time & Space Complexity

⏱️ Time Complexity
O(n log n)
n log n + m log m
💾 Space Complexity
O(n + m)
or O(1) - algo pe depend
2

Hash Map Approach

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Sorting ki jagah, hum directly character frequencies count kar sakte hain! 📊

Do hash maps (dictionaries) banao — ek string s ke liye, ek string t ke liye. Har character kitni baar aaya, wo count karo.

💭 Jaise exam mein attendance le rahe ho — dono classes ke students ki count karke match karo!

Algorithm (Steps)

  1. Length check — different hain toh false
  2. Do empty dictionaries banao: countS aur countT
  3. Dono strings pe simultaneously loop lagao
  4. Har character ka count apne dictionary mein increment karo
  5. End mein dono dictionaries compare karo
Python 
class Solution:
    def isAnagram(self, s: str, t: str) -> bool:
        if len(s) != len(t):
            return False
        
        countS, countT = {}, {}
        
        for i in range(len(s)):
            countS[s[i]] = 1 + countS.get(s[i], 0)
            countT[t[i]] = 1 + countT.get(t[i], 0)
        
        return countS == countT

Time & Space Complexity

⏱️ Time Complexity
O(n + m)
Linear scan!
💾 Space Complexity
O(1)
Max 26 characters
🚀 Better than sorting! Space O(1) kyunki max 26 unique lowercase letters hi ho sakte hain.
3

Hash Table using Array 🎯

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Problem mein sirf lowercase English letters (a-z). Toh ek fixed-size array of 26 use karein! 💡

Smart trick: String s ke liye count increment, string t ke liye decrement. End mein sab 0 hona chahiye! 🎉

💭 Bank balance jaise — deposit (s) aur withdrawal (t). Match kare toh balance zero!
Python 
class Solution:
    def isAnagram(self, s: str, t: str) -> bool:
        if len(s) != len(t):
            return False
        
        count = [0] * 26  # 26 letters ke liye
        
        for i in range(len(s)):
            count[ord(s[i]) - ord('a')] += 1  # increment
            count[ord(t[i]) - ord('a')] -= 1  # decrement
        
        for val in count:
            if val != 0:
                return False
        return True

ord() Function Kya Karta Hai?

ord('a') - ord('a') = 0 → index 0
ord('b') - ord('a') = 1 → index 1
ord('z') - ord('a') = 25 → index 25
Har character ka unique index! 🔢

Time & Space Complexity

⏱️ Time Complexity
O(n + m)
💾 Space Complexity
O(1)
Fixed 26 size
⚡ Most Efficient! No hashing overhead, simple array. Interview mein impressive!
⚠️

Common Galtiyan (Pitfalls)

Length Check Bhool Jana

Agar do strings ki lengths different hain, toh wo kabhi anagram nahi ho sakte! Always first step: if len(s) != len(t): return False

Case Sensitivity Issue

Is problem mein sirf lowercase letters hain. But agar mixed case allow ho:

Python ❌ Wrong 
# "Listen" != "silent"
return sorted(s) == sorted(t)
Python ✅ Correct 
s = s.lower()
t = t.lower()
return sorted(s) == sorted(t)

📋 Quick Comparison Table

Approach Time Space Notes
Sorting O(n log n) O(n) Simple but slower
Hash Map O(n) O(1) Fast with dicts
Array BEST O(n) O(1) Most efficient! ⚡
📚 Problem #3
🎯 Pattern: HashMap Complement

Two Sum

Array mein do numbers dhoondo jinke sum se target bane! 🎯➕

🟢 Easy Level

Problem Kya Hai?

Ek integer array nums aur ek integer target diya gaya hai. Tumhe do numbers ke indices return karne hain jinke sum se target ban jaye. Matlab nums[i] + nums[j] == target aur i != j.

Important Points

✅ Exactly ek valid answer hamesha exist karega
✅ Same element ko do baar use nahi kar sakte
✅ Answer mein smaller index pehle aana chahiye

🎯 Example 1: nums = [3,4,5,6], target = 7 → [0,1] (3+4=7)
🎯 Example 2: nums = [4,5,6], target = 10 → [0,2] (4+6=10)
🎯 Example 3: nums = [5,5], target = 10 → [0,1] (5+5=10)

🎭 Real-life Analogy — Party Mein Partner Dhundho!

Scenario: Socho ek party mein sabke paas kuch paise hain. Tumhe do logo ko dhundhna hai jinke paas milake exactly ₹100 ho. 💰💰

Brute Force (Slow): Har aadmi ko har doosre aadmi ke paas jao, paise count karo — "Bhai, tere paas kitne? Mere paas 40, tere paas 60? Chalo, 100 ho gaye!" 🚶‍♂️🚶

Smart Approach (HashMap): Ek register maintain karo jismein likho ki "Mere paas 40 hain, mujhe 60 wala chahiye!" Ab jab 60 wala aaye, register check kare — "60 chahiye kisko? Oh, 40 wale ko! Match ho gaya!" 🎯

💡 Key Insight: Agar tumhe target banana hai aur tumhare paas x hai, toh tumhe target - x dhundhna hai! Ye "complement" kehlaata hai. HashMap se complement O(1) mein mil jaata hai! ⚡

🎤 Interview Tips — Ye Problem FAANG Favourite Hai!

  • 🔥 Ye LeetCode #1 hai! Almost har interview mein poochha jaata hai — ye problem achhe se yaad karo!
  • ❓ Clarifying questions poochho: "Kya array sorted hai?" (agar haan toh Two Pointer bhi use ho sakta hai), "Kya negative numbers ho sakte hain?", "Kya multiple valid answers ho sakte hain?"
  • 🧠 Complement concept explain karo: "Main ye dekh raha hun ki target - current = complement. Agar complement already dekha hai toh answer mil gaya!"
  • ⚡ One-pass vs Two-pass: Two-pass pehle batao, phir optimize karke One-pass batao — ye dikhata hai ki tum iteratively improve kar sakte ho!
  • 🔄 Edge case mention karo: [5, 5] with target=10 — same value do jagah! Ye one-pass mein handle hota hai par two-pass mein tricky hai

❓ Common Follow-up Questions — Tayyar Raho!

Q1: "Agar array sorted ho toh kaise optimize karoge?"
→ Two Pointer technique! Left = 0, Right = n-1. Sum zyada ho toh right--, kam ho toh left++. O(1) space!

Q2: "Agar 3 numbers ka sum chahiye?" (3Sum Problem)
→ Ek number fix karo, baaki two ke liye Two Sum lagao. Sorting + Two Pointers se O(n²) mein ho jaata hai!

Q3: "Agar saare valid pairs return karne ho, sirf ek nahi?"
→ HashMap mein list of indices store karo. Result list maintain karo. Duplicates handle karo carefully!

Q4: "Agar target ke closest sum dhundhna ho (exact na mile toh)?"
→ Sorting + Two Pointers. Har step pe closest track karo. 3Sum Closest problem hai ye!

1

Brute Force Approach

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Sabse simple approach — har possible pair try karo! 🔄

Do nested loops lagao. Pehle element pick karo, phir baaki sab elements ke saath add karke dekho. Agar sum target ke barabar aa gaya, toh wo dono indices return kar do!

💭 Socho jaise party mein 2 logon ko dhundna hai jinke paas milake exactly ₹100 ho. Har ek ko har doosre se poochna padega!

Algorithm (Steps)

  1. Outer loop i se array traverse karo (0 se n-1)
  2. Inner loop j ko i+1 se start karo (same element avoid)
  3. Check karo: nums[i] + nums[j] == target?
  4. Agar haan → [i, j] return karo
  5. Nahi mila toh loop continue...
Python 
class Solution:
    def twoSum(self, nums: List[int], target: int) -> List[int]:
        for i in range(len(nums)):
            for j in range(i + 1, len(nums)):
                if nums[i] + nums[j] == target:
                    return [i, j]
        return []  # kabhi nahi aayega (guaranteed answer)

Time & Space Complexity

⏱️ Time Complexity
O(n²)
💾 Space Complexity
O(1)
😅 Slow hai! Har pair check kar rahe hain — n elements ke liye almost n² comparisons.
2

Hash Map - Two Pass

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Key insight: Agar hume nums[i] pata hai aur target pata hai, toh hum dusra number calculate kar sakte hain! 🧮

complement = target - nums[i]
Ab bas ye complement array mein hai ya nahi, ye O(1) mein check karna hai. Hash Map perfect hai iske liye!

💭 Jaise agar target ₹100 hai aur tumhare paas ₹40 hai, toh dusre ke paas exactly ₹60 hone chahiye. Ab ₹60 wala dhundo — fast dhundna hai toh phone book (hash map) use karo!

Algorithm (Steps)

  1. First Pass: Poori array traverse karo, har number:index pair ko hash map mein daalo
  2. Second Pass: Phir se traverse karo
  3. Har element ke liye complement = target - nums[i] calculate karo
  4. Check karo: complement hash map mein hai? Aur khud nahi hai (i != j)?
  5. Agar milgaya → dono indices return karo!
Python 
class Solution:
    def twoSum(self, nums: List[int], target: int) -> List[int]:
        # First Pass: Build the hash map
        numToIndex = {}
        for i, num in enumerate(nums):
            numToIndex[num] = i
        
        # Second Pass: Find the complement
        for i, num in enumerate(nums):
            complement = target - num
            if complement in numToIndex and numToIndex[complement] != i:
                return [i, numToIndex[complement]]
        
        return []

Time & Space Complexity

⏱️ Time Complexity
O(n)
2 passes = O(n) + O(n)
💾 Space Complexity
O(n)
Hash map storage
🚀 Much better! n² se n pe aa gaye. Hash map ke kaaran lookup O(1) mein ho jata hai.
3

Hash Map - One Pass 🎯

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Kya hum ek hi pass mein kaam kar sakte hain? Haan! 🔥

Jaise jaise array traverse karte hain, simultaneously check karte jao ki current element ka complement pehle se map mein hai ya nahi.

Agar hai → answer mil gaya! Nahi hai → current element ko map mein daal do future ke liye.

💭 Jaise train mein seat dhund rahe ho. Har seat pe jaake pehle check karo — "kya mera partner already yahan baitha hai?" Nahi hai toh apna naam likh do ki "main yahan hun, mera partner baad mein aaye toh mil jayega!"

Algorithm (Steps)

  1. Ek empty hash map banao
  2. Array traverse karo (index i, value num)
  3. complement = target - num calculate karo
  4. Check: kya complement pehle se map mein hai?
  5. Agar hai → [map[complement], i] return karo
  6. Nahi hai → map[num] = i add karo
  7. Continue until found!
Python 
class Solution:
    def twoSum(self, nums: List[int], target: int) -> List[int]:
        prevMap = {}  # num -> index
        
        for i, num in enumerate(nums):
            complement = target - num
            
            # Kya complement pehle dekha hai?
            if complement in prevMap:
                return [prevMap[complement], i]
            
            # Current num ko map mein daalo
            prevMap[num] = i
        
        return []

Kyun Kaam Karta Hai?

Jab hum index i pe hain, tab tak 0 se i-1 tak ke saare elements already map mein hain. Toh agar complement pehle aaya tha, toh mil jayega!

Aur agar complement baad mein aayega, toh tab tak current element map mein hoga, toh tab match ho jayega. Win-win! 🎉

🧠 Kyun Ye Approach Sabse Best Hai? — Deep Dive!

Magic: Hum "need" store kar rahe hain, "want" dhundh rahe hain!

Har element ke liye:
1️⃣ "Main X hun. Mujhe target banana hai. Mujhe (target - X) chahiye!" — Ye check karo ki pehle aaya tha kya?
2️⃣ Nahi mila? "Theek hai, main apna address chhod ke jaata hun. Jisko main chahiye, wo baad mein aayega toh mujhe dhundh lega!" 📍

💡 Interview Insight: Ye pattern "complement finding" kehlaata hai. Bohot saari problems mein use hota hai — Two Sum, Three Sum, Four Sum, aur bhi kaafi! Ek baar samajh lo, bahut kaam aayega! 🔥

📋 Step-by-Step Dry Run — Visualize Karo!

Input: nums = [2, 7, 11, 15], target = 9

Stepinumcomplement (9-num)prevMapcomplement in map?Action
Start - - - {} - Initialize empty map
1 0 2 7 {} ❌ No (map empty) Add 2→0: {2:0}
2 1 7 2 {2:0} ✅ YES! 2 hai! 🎉 Return [0, 1]
👆 Dekho! Jab 7 aaya (index 1), usne pucha "mujhe 2 chahiye (9-7=2)". Map mein dekha — 2 index 0 pe hai! Match found: [0, 1] — Sirf 2 iterations mein answer! 🚀

Time & Space Complexity

⏱️ Time Complexity
O(n)
Single pass! 🚀
💾 Space Complexity
O(n)
Hash map storage
⚡ Best approach! Sirf ek baar array traverse karna hai. Interview mein ye approach sabse zyada impress karegi!
⚠️

Common Galtiyan (Pitfalls)

Same Element Ko Do Baar Use Karna

Problem mein clearly bola hai i != j. Matlab same element ko do baar use nahi kar sakte!

Python ❌ Wrong 
# [3,3] target=6 pe galat
if complement in numToIndex:
    return [i, numToIndex[complement]]
Python ✅ Correct 
# Index check karo!
if complement in numToIndex \
   and numToIndex[complement] != i:
    return [i, numToIndex[complement]]
💡 One-pass approach mein ye automatically handle ho jata hai kyunki hum current element ko baad mein map mein daalte hain!

Duplicate Values Handle Karna

Array mein same values ho sakti hain jaise [5, 5]. Two-pass mein map overwrite ho jata hai, par one-pass mein sahi se handle hota hai.

💡 [5, 5] target=10 → One-pass mein jab second 5 pe aate hain, tab first 5 already map mein hai. Complement 10-5=5 milega, indices [0,1] return!

Index Order Galat Dena

Problem kehta hai smaller index first. One-pass mein [prevMap[complement], i] automatically correct order deta hai kyunki prevMap wala index hamesha current i se chhota hoga!

📋 Quick Comparison Table

Approach Time Space Notes
Brute Force O(n²) O(1) Simple but slow
Two Pass Hash O(n) O(n) 2 loops, fast lookup
One Pass BEST O(n) O(n) Single loop! ⚡
📚 Problem #4
🎯 Pattern 11: Frequency as Key

Group Anagrams

Similar characters wale strings ko groups mein baanto! 🔤📦

🟡 Medium Level

Problem Kya Hai?

Ek array of strings strs diya gaya hai. Tumhe saare anagrams ko group karke sublists mein return karna hai. Output kisi bhi order mein ho sakta hai.

Anagram Kya Hota Hai?

Do strings anagram hain agar unme exact same characters hain, bas order different ho sakta hai.
📌 "act" aur "cat" → Anagrams! (a, c, t same hain)
📌 "stop" aur "pots" → Anagrams! (s, t, o, p same hain)

🎯 Example 1: ["act","pots","tops","cat","stop","hat"]
→ [["hat"],["act", "cat"],["stop", "pots", "tops"]]

🎯 Example 2: ["x"] → [["x"]]
🎯 Example 3: [""] → [[""]]

Constraints: 1 ≤ strs.length ≤ 1000, lowercase English letters only
1

Sorting as Key

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Key insight: Agar do strings anagrams hain, toh sort karne ke baad wo identical ho jayenge! 🎯

"cat" → sort → "act"
"act" → sort → "act"
"tac" → sort → "act"
Sab same! Toh sorted string ko key bana ke hash map mein group kar sakte hain.

💭 Socho jaise jumbled letters ka puzzle ho — sab letters ko alphabetically arrange karo, same letters wale ek hi answer denge!

Algorithm (Steps)

  1. Ek hash map banao (sorted_string → list of original strings)
  2. Har string ke liye:
  3. String ko sort karo → ye hamari key hai
  4. Is key ke against original string ko list mein add karo
  5. Finally, hash map ki saari values return karo!
Python 
class Solution:
    def groupAnagrams(self, strs: List[str]) -> List[List[str]]:
        anagramGroups = {}  # sorted_str -> list of original strings
        
        for s in strs:
            # Sort the string to get the key
            sortedStr = ''.join(sorted(s))
            
            # Add to the group
            if sortedStr not in anagramGroups:
                anagramGroups[sortedStr] = []
            anagramGroups[sortedStr].append(s)
        
        return list(anagramGroups.values())

Dry Run Example

Input: ["act", "cat", "pots", "stop"]

"act" → sorted: "act" → map: {"act": ["act"]}
"cat" → sorted: "act" → map: {"act": ["act", "cat"]}
"pots" → sorted: "opst" → map: {"act": [...], "opst": ["pots"]}
"stop" → sorted: "opst" → map: {"act": [...], "opst": ["pots", "stop"]}

Output: [["act", "cat"], ["pots", "stop"]] ✅

Time & Space Complexity

⏱️ Time Complexity
O(n × k log k)
n strings, each of length k sorted
💾 Space Complexity
O(n × k)
Hash map storage
📊 Sorting ka overhead hai (k log k per string), par simple aur clean solution hai!
2

Character Count as Key 🎯

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Sorting se better idea: Character frequency hi key ban sakti hai! 🔥

"cat" → {a:1, c:1, t:1}
"act" → {a:1, c:1, t:1}
"tac" → {a:1, c:1, t:1}
Same frequency = Same group! Ab sorting ki zaroorat nahi.

Par dictionary hashable nahi hoti Python mein. Toh hum ek tuple banayenge jo 26 letters ki count represent kare!

💭 Socho jaise har word ka "fingerprint" bana rahe ho — kitne 'a', kitne 'b'... Same fingerprint wale ek group mein!

Algorithm (Steps)

  1. Ek defaultdict(list) banao
  2. Har string ke liye:
  3. Size 26 ka count array banao (a-z ke liye)
  4. Har character ki frequency count karo
  5. Array ko tuple mein convert karo (hashable key ke liye)
  6. Is tuple key ke against string add karo
  7. Hash map ki values return karo!
Python 
from collections import defaultdict

class Solution:
    def groupAnagrams(self, strs: List[str]) -> List[List[str]]:
        anagramGroups = defaultdict(list)  # count_tuple -> list of strings
        
        for s in strs:
            # Create character count array (26 letters)
            count = [0] * 26
            
            for char in s:
                count[ord(char) - ord('a')] += 1
            
            # Tuple as key (lists aren't hashable)
            anagramGroups[tuple(count)].append(s)
        
        return list(anagramGroups.values())

Kyun Tuple Use Karte Hain?

Python mein dictionary keys hashable honi chahiye.
❌ List → Mutable, not hashable
✅ Tuple → Immutable, hashable!

tuple([1,0,0,1,0,...,1]) → (1,0,0,1,0,...,1)
Ab ye key ban sakti hai! 🔑

ord() Function Kya Karta Hai?

ord('a') = 97, ord('b') = 98, ...
ord(char) - ord('a') → 0-25 ka index milta hai!

'a' → 0, 'b' → 1, 'c' → 2, ... 'z' → 25

Time & Space Complexity

⏱️ Time Complexity
O(n × k)
No sorting! Just counting 🚀
💾 Space Complexity
O(n × k)
Hash map storage
⚡ Best approach! Sorting hatane se O(k log k) → O(k) ho gaya per string. Interview mein ye approach sabse impressive hai!
⚠️

Common Galtiyan (Pitfalls)

List Ko Directly Key Banana

Python mein list hashable nahi hoti!

Python ❌ Wrong 
# TypeError!
map[count].append(s)  # count is list
Python ✅ Correct 
# Convert to tuple first!
map[tuple(count)].append(s)

Empty String Handle Karna

Empty string "" bhi valid input hai! Iske liye:
• Sorted: "" → "" (works!)
• Count: all zeros tuple (0,0,0,...) (works!)
Dono approaches automatically handle kar lete hain. 👍

defaultdict vs Regular dict

Regular dict mein pehle check karna padta hai key exists ya nahi. defaultdict(list) automatically empty list create karta hai!

Python 😐 Verbose 
if key not in d:
    d[key] = []
d[key].append(s)
Python ✅ Clean 
# defaultdict auto-creates!
d[key].append(s)

📋 Quick Comparison Table

Approach Time Space Notes
Sorting as Key O(n × k log k) O(n × k) Simple, intuitive
Char Count BEST O(n × k) O(n × k) Fastest! No sorting ⚡
📌 n = number of strings, k = average length of strings
📚 Problem #5
🎯 Pattern 42: Top K Elements

Top K Frequent Elements

Array mein sabse zyada baar aane wale K elements dhundo! 📊🔝

🟡 Medium Level

Problem Kya Hai?

Ek integer array nums aur ek integer k diya gaya hai. Tumhe array ke k most frequent elements return karne hain. Matlab jo elements sabse zyada baar aaye hain, unme se top k.

Important Points

✅ Answer hamesha unique hoga (test cases aise hain)
✅ Output kisi bhi order mein de sakte ho
✅ k hamesha ≤ distinct elements ki count hogi

🎯 Example 1: nums = [1,2,2,3,3,3], k = 2
→ [2,3] ya [3,2] (3 appears 3x, 2 appears 2x — top 2 frequent)

🎯 Example 2: nums = [7,7], k = 1 → [7]

Constraints: 1 ≤ nums.length ≤ 10⁴, -1000 ≤ nums[i] ≤ 1000
1

Sorting Approach

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Sabse simple approach: Pehle frequency count karo, phir frequency ke basis pe sort karo, aur top k elements le lo!

💭 Jaise class mein attendance ke hisaab se top k students dhundne hain — pehle sabki attendance count karo, phir highest se lowest sort karo, top k names le lo!

Algorithm (Steps)

  1. Counter/HashMap se har element ki frequency count karo
  2. Frequencies ko descending order mein sort karo
  3. Top k elements return karo
Python 
from collections import Counter

class Solution:
    def topKFrequent(self, nums: List[int], k: int) -> List[int]:
        # Count frequencies
        count = Counter(nums)
        
        # Sort by frequency (descending) and take top k
        sorted_items = sorted(count.keys(), key=lambda x: count[x], reverse=True)
        
        return sorted_items[:k]

Time & Space Complexity

⏱️ Time Complexity
O(n log n)
Sorting dominates
💾 Space Complexity
O(n)
HashMap storage
2

Min Heap Approach

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Sorting se better: Heap use karo! 📚

Hum ek Min Heap of size k maintain karenge. Jab bhi heap size k se zyada ho, sabse chhoti frequency wala element pop kar do. End mein heap mein sirf top k frequent elements bachenge!

💭 Socho jaise ek choti si basket hai jisme sirf k cheezein aa sakti hain. Jab nayi cheez daalni ho aur basket full ho, toh sabse kam valuable cheez nikaal do!

Algorithm (Steps)

  1. Counter se frequencies count karo
  2. Ek Min Heap banao (Python mein heapq by default min heap hai)
  3. Har (frequency, element) pair ko heap mein daalo
  4. Agar heap size > k → heappop karo (smallest frequency nikalta hai)
  5. End mein heap se saare elements return karo
Python 
import heapq
from collections import Counter

class Solution:
    def topKFrequent(self, nums: List[int], k: int) -> List[int]:
        count = Counter(nums)
        
        # Min heap of size k
        minHeap = []
        
        for num, freq in count.items():
            heapq.heappush(minHeap, (freq, num))
            
            # Keep only k elements
            if len(minHeap) > k:
                heapq.heappop(minHeap)  # Remove smallest freq
        
        # Extract elements from heap
        return [num for freq, num in minHeap]

Kyun Min Heap? Max Heap Nahi?

🤔 Counter-intuitive lagta hai, par suno:

• Hum top k frequent chahte hain
• Min Heap mein sabse chhota element root pe hota hai
• Jab heap size > k, hum smallest frequency pop karte hain
• Isse sirf k biggest frequencies bachti hain!

Max Heap use karte toh saara data sort karna padta (n log n). Min Heap se sirf k elements maintain karte hain (n log k)!

Time & Space Complexity

⏱️ Time Complexity
O(n log k)
Better than sorting! 🚀
💾 Space Complexity
O(n + k)
HashMap + Heap
📊 Jab k << n (k bahut chhota), tab O(n log k) is much better than O(n log n)!
3

Bucket Sort Approach 🎯

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Sabse clever approach! 🧠 Heap bhi nahi chahiye.

Key insight: Maximum possible frequency kya ho sakti hai? n (array length)!
Toh hum n+1 buckets bana sakte hain, jahan bucket[i] mein wo elements hain jinki frequency exactly i hai.

Phir buckets ko reverse order mein traverse karo (highest frequency first) aur k elements collect karo!

💭 Socho jaise school mein marks ke hisaab se shelves hain — 100 marks wali shelf, 99 marks wali, 98... Highest shelf se dekhna shuru karo, top k students mil jayenge!

Algorithm (Steps)

  1. Counter se frequencies count karo
  2. Size n+1 ka bucket array banao (index = frequency)
  3. Har element ko uski frequency wale bucket mein daalo
  4. Buckets ko reverse mein traverse karo (n se 1 tak)
  5. Jab tak k elements nahi mil jaate, elements collect karo
Python 
from collections import Counter

class Solution:
    def topKFrequent(self, nums: List[int], k: int) -> List[int]:
        count = Counter(nums)
        n = len(nums)
        
        # Create buckets: bucket[i] = elements with frequency i
        buckets = [[] for _ in range(n + 1)]
        
        for num, freq in count.items():
            buckets[freq].append(num)
        
        # Collect k elements from highest frequency buckets
        result = []
        for freq in range(n, 0, -1):  # n to 1 (reverse)
            for num in buckets[freq]:
                result.append(num)
                if len(result) == k:
                    return result
        
        return result

Dry Run Example

nums = [1,1,1,2,2,3], k = 2

Step 1: count = {1:3, 2:2, 3:1}
Step 2: buckets (index = frequency):
• bucket[1] = [3] (freq 1)
• bucket[2] = [2] (freq 2)
• bucket[3] = [1] (freq 3)

Step 3: Traverse reverse (3→1):
• freq=3: add 1 → result=[1]
• freq=2: add 2 → result=[1,2] → len=k, STOP!

Output: [1, 2] ✅

Time & Space Complexity

⏱️ Time Complexity
O(n)
No sorting/heap! ⚡
💾 Space Complexity
O(n)
Buckets + HashMap
⚡ Best approach! Linear time mein kaam ho gaya. Interview mein is approach se interviewer impress ho jayega! 😎
⚠️

Common Galtiyan (Pitfalls)

Heap mein (frequency, element) ka Order

Python heap first element ke basis pe compare karta hai. Frequency pehle daalo taaki sorting frequency pe ho!

Python ❌ Wrong 
# Sorts by element, not freq!
heapq.heappush(heap, (num, freq))
Python ✅ Correct 
# Sorts by frequency!
heapq.heappush(heap, (freq, num))

Bucket Array Size

Bucket array ki size n+1 honi chahiye, n nahi! Kyunki frequency 0 se n tak ho sakti hai (index 0 se n).

💡 Agar array = [5,5,5,5,5] (length 5), toh 5 ki frequency = 5. Bucket[5] access karne ke liye size minimum 6 chahiye!

Counter.most_common() Shortcut

Python mein ek shortcut hai! Par interview mein pata hona chahiye underlying logic.

Python 😎 One-liner 
def topKFrequent(self, nums, k):
    return [x for x, _ in Counter(nums).most_common(k)]

📋 Quick Comparison Table

Approach Time Space Notes
Sorting O(n log n) O(n) Simple, straightforward
Min Heap O(n log k) O(n + k) Better when k << n
Bucket Sort BEST O(n) O(n) Linear time! ⚡
📌 Pro tip: Bucket sort tab use karo jab frequency range bounded ho (yahan max freq = n).
📚 Problem #6

Encode and Decode Strings

List of strings ko ek single string mein encode karo aur wapas decode karo! 🔐🔓

🟡 Medium Level

Problem Kya Hai?

Design karo ek algorithm jo list of strings ko ek single string mein encode kare, aur phir us encoded string ko wapas original list of strings mein decode kare.

Kyun Tricky Hai?

⚠️ Strings mein koi bhi character ho sakta hai — comma, space, special symbols, even empty string!
✅ Tumhara encoding scheme robust hona chahiye taaki kisi bhi character se break na ho.
✅ Decode karne pe exactly original strings wapas milni chahiye.

🎯 Example 1: ["neet","code","love","you"]
encode → "4#neet4#code4#love3#you"
decode → ["neet","code","love","you"] ✅

🎯 Example 2: ["we","say",":","yes"]
encode → "2#we3#say1#:3#yes" → special characters bhi handle! ✅
1

Length Array + Separator

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Key insight: Agar hum har string ki length pehle se store kar lein, toh decoding mein exactly pata hoga ki kitne characters padhne hain! 🎯

Strategy:
1. Pehle saari lengths comma-separated likho
2. Phir # lagao as boundary
3. Phir saari strings back-to-back append karo

💭 Jaise parcel bhejte time pehle ek list likhte ho — "item1: 2kg, item2: 3kg, item3: 1kg" phir actual items pack karte ho. Receiver ko weight se pata chal jayega kaunsa item kahan khatam hota hai!

Algorithm (Steps)

🔐 Encoding Steps

  1. Agar list empty hai → empty string return karo
  2. Har string ki length ek list mein store karo
  3. Saari lengths ko comma-separated string mein likho
  4. # lagao as separator
  5. Phir saari original strings append karo

🔓 Decoding Steps

  1. Agar string empty hai → empty list return karo
  2. # tak padho aur lengths extract karo
  3. # ke baad, har length ke hisaab se substring nikalo
  4. Result list mein add karte jao
Python 
class Solution:
    def encode(self, strs: List[str]) -> str:
        if not strs:
            return ""
        
        sizes = []  # Store all lengths
        res = ""
        
        # Collect all lengths
        for s in strs:
            sizes.append(len(s))
        
        # Write lengths with comma separator
        for sz in sizes:
            res += str(sz) + ','
        
        res += '#'  # Boundary marker
        
        # Append all strings
        for s in strs:
            res += s
        
        return res

    def decode(self, s: str) -> List[str]:
        if not s:
            return []
        
        sizes, res, i = [], [], 0
        
        # Extract all sizes until '#'
        while s[i] != '#':
            cur = ""
            while s[i] != ',':
                cur += s[i]
                i += 1
            sizes.append(int(cur))
            i += 1  # Skip comma
        
        i += 1  # Skip '#'
        
        # Extract strings based on sizes
        for sz in sizes:
            res.append(s[i:i + sz])
            i += sz
        
        return res

Dry Run Example

Input: ["hi", "bye"]

Encode:
• sizes = [2, 3]
• res = "2,3,#hibye"

Decode: "2,3,#hibye"
• Read until #: sizes = [2, 3]
• After #: "hibye"
• Read 2 chars: "hi" → res = ["hi"]
• Read 3 chars: "bye" → res = ["hi", "bye"] ✅

Time & Space Complexity

⏱️ Time Complexity
O(m)
m = total chars in all strings
💾 Space Complexity
O(m + n)
m chars + n lengths stored
2

Length Prefix (Optimal) 🎯

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Aur bhi simple approach: Inline length prefixing! 🔥

Har string ke liye directly length#string format use karo.
Pehle saari lengths collect karne ki zaroorat nahi — stream mein encode/decode kar sakte ho!

💭 Jaise WhatsApp voice message mein pehle duration dikhta hai phir message — "0:05" message. Har message ka apna duration prefix hota hai, sab ek saath collect nahi karte!

Algorithm (Steps)

🔐 Encoding (Super Simple!)

  1. Har string ke liye:
  2. length nikalo
  3. "length#string" format mein append karo
  4. Bas! 🎉

🔓 Decoding

  1. Pointer i = 0 se shuru karo
  2. Jab tak string khatam na ho:
  3. Pointer j ko aage badhao jab tak # na mile
  4. s[i:j] se length extract karo
  5. # ke baad length characters padho → original string!
  6. i ko aage move karo next segment ke liye
Python 
class Solution:
    def encode(self, strs: List[str]) -> str:
        res = ""
        for s in strs:
            res += str(len(s)) + "#" + s
        return res

    def decode(self, s: str) -> List[str]:
        res = []
        i = 0
        
        while i < len(s):
            # Find the '#' separator
            j = i
            while s[j] != '#':
                j += 1
            
            # Extract length
            length = int(s[i:j])
            
            # Move past '#'
            i = j + 1
            
            # Extract the string of 'length' characters
            j = i + length
            res.append(s[i:j])
            
            # Move to next segment
            i = j
        
        return res

Dry Run Example

Input: ["hello", "world"]

Encode:
• "hello" → "5#hello"
• "world" → "5#world"
• Result: "5#hello5#world"

Decode: "5#hello5#world"
• i=0, find #: j=1, length=5
• i=2, read 5 chars: "hello" ✓
• i=7, find #: j=8, length=5
• i=9, read 5 chars: "world" ✓
• Output: ["hello", "world"] ✅

Kyun # Safe Hai?

🤔 "Par agar string mein # ho toh?"

Koi problem nahi! Kyunki hum length se padhte hain, delimiter se nahi!

Example: ["a#b"]
• Encode: "3#a#b" (length 3, then a#b)
• Decode: Read "3", skip #, read 3 chars = "a#b" ✅

Length-based approach kisi bhi character ke saath kaam karta hai! 💪

Time & Space Complexity

⏱️ Time Complexity
O(m)
Single pass through all chars
💾 Space Complexity
O(m + n)
Output storage
⚡ Optimal approach! Simpler code, same complexity, aur streaming-friendly bhi hai!
⚠️

Common Galtiyan (Pitfalls)

Simple Delimiter Use Karna (Comma, Space)

Agar tumne sirf comma ya space se strings join kiye, toh string mein comma aaye toh? Sab toot jayega!

Python ❌ Wrong 
# "hello,world" ke saath break!
encoded = ",".join(strs)
decoded = encoded.split(",")  # WRONG!
Python ✅ Correct 
# Length-based approach
res += str(len(s)) + "#" + s

Empty String Handle Karna

Edge cases:
• Empty list [] → encode should return ""
• List with empty string [""] → encode returns "0#"
Ye dono different hain! Properly distinguish karo.

💡 [""] encode → "0#" (length 0, then empty string)
[] encode → "" (nothing to encode)

Multi-Digit Length Parse Karna

Agar string ki length 10 ya usse zyada hai, toh length multi-digit hogi! Single digit assume mat karo.

Python ❌ Wrong 
# Assumes single digit length!
length = int(s[i])  # BREAKS for len >= 10
Python ✅ Correct 
# Read until # for full length
while s[j] != '#':
    j += 1
length = int(s[i:j])  # Handles any length!

📋 Quick Comparison Table

Approach Time Space Notes
Length Array + # O(m) O(m + n) Two-pass, stores lengths first
Inline Prefix BEST O(m) O(m + n) Simpler, streaming-friendly ⚡
📌 Key insight: Length-prefixing se koi bhi character (including delimiter) safely encode hota hai!
📚 Problem #7

Product of Array Except Self

Har index pe baaki sab elements ka product nikalo — bina division ke! ✖️➡️✅

🟡 Medium Level

Problem Kya Hai?

Ek integer array nums diya gaya hai. Tumhe ek array output return karna hai jahan output[i] = product of all elements except nums[i].

Important Constraints

⚠️ Division operation use nahi kar sakte!
✅ O(n) time mein solve karna hai
✅ Product 32-bit integer mein fit hoga (guaranteed)

🎯 Example 1: nums = [1,2,4,6]
→ output[0] = 2×4×6 = 48
→ output[1] = 1×4×6 = 24
→ output[2] = 1×2×6 = 12
→ output[3] = 1×2×4 = 8
→ [48, 24, 12, 8]

🎯 Example 2: nums = [-1,0,1,2,3] → [0,-6,0,0,0]
(0 hai array mein, toh baaki sab 0 except 0's position)
1

Brute Force

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Sabse simple: Har index ke liye, baaki sab elements ka product manually calculate karo!

💭 Jaise class mein har student ke liye baaki sabki marks ka average nikalna ho — ek ek karke sab ke liye alag se calculate karo.
Python 
class Solution:
    def productExceptSelf(self, nums: List[int]) -> List[int]:
        n = len(nums)
        result = []
        
        for i in range(n):
            product = 1
            for j in range(n):
                if i != j:
                    product *= nums[j]
            result.append(product)
        
        return result

Time & Space Complexity

⏱️ Time Complexity
O(n²)
Nested loops
💾 Space Complexity
O(1)
Output excluded
🙅 Interview mein ye approach mat batao — TLE (Time Limit Exceeded) aayega!
2

Division Approach (Not Allowed!)

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Agar division allowed hoti: Total product / nums[i] = answer for index i.

Par ye approach problems create karti hai:
• Agar 0 hai array mein → Division by zero!
• Problem explicitly says no division

💭 Samjhne ke liye: [1,2,3,4] ka total product = 24.
index 0: 24/1 = 24, index 1: 24/2 = 12... par ye allowed nahi hai!
Python ❌ Not Allowed 
# DON'T USE THIS - Just for understanding
def productExceptSelf(self, nums):
    total = 1
    for num in nums:
        total *= num
    return [total // num for num in nums]  # WRONG!
3

Prefix & Suffix Products

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Key insight: output[i] = (left side ka product) × (right side ka product)! 🎯

Hum do arrays banayenge:
• prefix[i] = product of all elements before index i
• suffix[i] = product of all elements after index i

Final answer: prefix[i] × suffix[i]

💭 Socho array ko beech mein kaat diya — left part ka product × right part ka product = answer! [1, 2, | 4 |, 6] → (1×2) × (6) = 12 for index 2.

Algorithm (Steps)

  1. prefix array banao: left to right traverse karte hue running product store karo
  2. suffix array banao: right to left traverse karte hue running product store karo
  3. Result: result[i] = prefix[i] × suffix[i]
Python 
class Solution:
    def productExceptSelf(self, nums: List[int]) -> List[int]:
        n = len(nums)
        
        # prefix[i] = product of all elements before i
        prefix = [1] * n
        for i in range(1, n):
            prefix[i] = prefix[i - 1] * nums[i - 1]
        
        # suffix[i] = product of all elements after i
        suffix = [1] * n
        for i in range(n - 2, -1, -1):
            suffix[i] = suffix[i + 1] * nums[i + 1]
        
        # result[i] = prefix[i] * suffix[i]
        result = [1] * n
        for i in range(n):
            result[i] = prefix[i] * suffix[i]
        
        return result

Dry Run Example

nums = [1, 2, 3, 4]

Prefix (left products):
• prefix[0] = 1 (nothing before)
• prefix[1] = 1 (just nums[0])
• prefix[2] = 1×2 = 2
• prefix[3] = 1×2×3 = 6
→ prefix = [1, 1, 2, 6]

Suffix (right products):
• suffix[3] = 1 (nothing after)
• suffix[2] = 4
• suffix[1] = 4×3 = 12
• suffix[0] = 4×3×2 = 24
→ suffix = [24, 12, 4, 1]

Result: prefix × suffix
→ [1×24, 1×12, 2×4, 6×1] = [24, 12, 8, 6] ✅

Time & Space Complexity

⏱️ Time Complexity
O(n)
3 passes through array
💾 Space Complexity
O(n)
prefix + suffix arrays
4

Optimized - O(1) Extra Space 🎯

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Kya hum prefix aur suffix arrays hatake directly result mein calculate kar sakte hain? 🤔

Haan! Result array ko hi prefix array ki tarah use karo, phir right se traverse karte hue suffix multiply karte jao!

💭 Pehle left side ka product result mein store karo. Phir right se aate hue ek variable mein right product track karo aur multiply karte jao!

Algorithm (Steps)

  1. First pass (left to right): result[i] mein prefix product store karo
  2. Ek variable suffix = 1 lo
  3. Second pass (right to left): result[i] ×= suffix, phir suffix ×= nums[i]
  4. Done! Result array ready hai
Python 
class Solution:
    def productExceptSelf(self, nums: List[int]) -> List[int]:
        n = len(nums)
        result = [1] * n
        
        # First pass: Store prefix products in result
        prefix = 1
        for i in range(n):
            result[i] = prefix
            prefix *= nums[i]
        
        # Second pass: Multiply with suffix products
        suffix = 1
        for i in range(n - 1, -1, -1):
            result[i] *= suffix
            suffix *= nums[i]
        
        return result

Dry Run Example (Step by Step)

nums = [1, 2, 3, 4]

First Pass (Left → Right): Build prefix in result

i=0: result[0]=1, prefix=1×1=1
i=1: result[1]=1, prefix=1×2=2
i=2: result[2]=2, prefix=2×3=6
i=3: result[3]=6, prefix=6×4=24
result = [1, 1, 2, 6] (prefix products)

Second Pass (Right → Left): Multiply suffix
i=3: result[3]=6×1=6, suffix=1×4=4
i=2: result[2]=2×4=8, suffix=4×3=12
i=1: result[1]=1×12=12, suffix=12×2=24
i=0: result[0]=1×24=24, suffix=24×1=24
result = [24, 12, 8, 6] ✅

Time & Space Complexity

⏱️ Time Complexity
O(n)
2 passes only
💾 Space Complexity
O(1)
Output array not counted!
⚡ Best approach! O(n) time, O(1) extra space. Interview mein ye approach se interviewer khush ho jayega! 😎
⚠️

Common Galtiyan (Pitfalls)

Division Use Karna

Problem explicitly says no division! Plus zero handle karna mushkil ho jata hai.

Prefix/Suffix Array Initialize Karna

Prefix aur suffix arrays ko 1 se initialize karo, 0 se nahi! Kyunki multiplication identity 1 hai.

Python ❌ Wrong 
result = [0] * n  # Sab 0 ho jayenge!
Python ✅ Correct 
result = [1] * n  # Multiplication identity!

Zero Handle Karna

Agar array mein zero hai:
• Ek zero → sirf us index pe non-zero answer hoga, baaki sab 0
• Multiple zeros → saare answers 0

Prefix-suffix approach automatically handle karta hai ye cases! 👍

Off-by-One Errors in Loops

Second pass mein n-1 se 0 tak jaana hai (inclusive). range(n-1, -1, -1) use karo!

📋 Quick Comparison Table

Approach Time Space Notes
Brute Force O(n²) O(1) TLE! Don't use
Division O(n) O(1) ❌ Not allowed!
Prefix + Suffix O(n) O(n) Easy to understand
Optimized BEST O(n) O(1) Perfect solution! ⚡
📌 Key insight: output[i] = (product of left) × (product of right). Ye pattern bahut important hai!
📚 Problem #8

Longest Consecutive Sequence

Array mein sabse lambi consecutive sequence dhundo — O(n) mein! 🔢📈

🟡 Medium Level

Problem Kya Hai?

Ek unsorted integer array nums diya gaya hai. Tumhe longest consecutive elements sequence ki length return karni hai. Consecutive matlab 1, 2, 3, 4... ya 100, 101, 102...

Important Constraint

⚡ Algorithm O(n) time mein run hona chahiye!
Matlab sorting allowed nahi (wo O(n log n) hai)

🎯 Example 1: nums = [2, 20, 4, 10, 3, 4, 5]
→ Consecutive sequences: [2,3,4,5], [10], [20]
→ Longest = [2,3,4,5] = length 4

🎯 Example 2: nums = [0,3,2,5,4,6,1,1]
→ [0,1,2,3,4,5,6] = length 7
1

Brute Force

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Har number se start karo aur dekho kitna aage tak consecutive mil sakte hain. num+1 hai? num+2 hai? ... jab tak milte rahe, streak badhate jao!

💭 Problem: Har number ke liye ye karte hain, toh bahut baar same sequence count hoti hai. [1,2,3,4] mein 1 se bhi count, 2 se bhi count... waste!
Python 
class Solution:
    def longestConsecutive(self, nums: List[int]) -> int:
        res = 0
        store = set(nums)  # O(1) lookup ke liye
        
        for num in nums:
            streak, curr = 0, num
            while curr in store:
                streak += 1
                curr += 1
            res = max(res, streak)
        
        return res

Time & Space Complexity

⏱️ Time Complexity
O(n²)
Same sequences recount
💾 Space Complexity
O(n)
Set storage
2

Sorting Approach

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Agar array sort kar dein, toh consecutive elements adjacent aa jayenge! Phir simply traverse karo aur streaks count karo.

💭 [100, 4, 200, 1, 3, 2] → sorted [1, 2, 3, 4, 100, 200]
Ab consecutive dhundna easy hai! Par sorting O(n log n) hai...
Python 
class Solution:
    def longestConsecutive(self, nums: List[int]) -> int:
        if not nums:
            return 0
        
        nums.sort()
        res = 1
        streak = 1
        
        for i in range(1, len(nums)):
            if nums[i] == nums[i - 1]:  # Skip duplicates
                continue
            elif nums[i] == nums[i - 1] + 1:  # Consecutive!
                streak += 1
            else:  # Sequence broken
                streak = 1
            res = max(res, streak)
        
        return res

Time & Space Complexity

⏱️ Time Complexity
O(n log n)
Sorting dominates
💾 Space Complexity
O(1)
In-place sort
😐 Problem requirement O(n) hai, ye O(n log n) hai. Technically valid nahi!
3

Hash Set - Smart Start 🎯

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Key insight: Sirf sequence ke START se count karo! 💡

Ek number sequence ka start tab hai jab num-1 set mein nahi hai!
Agar num-1 hai, toh wo number sequence ke beech mein hai, skip karo.

💭 [1, 2, 3, 4, 100]
• 1 → 0 nahi hai set mein → START! Count: 1,2,3,4 = 4
• 2 → 1 hai set mein → skip (beech ka number hai)
• 3 → 2 hai set mein → skip
• 4 → 3 hai set mein → skip
• 100 → 99 nahi hai → START! Count: 100 = 1

Har number sirf ek baar process hota hai! O(n) ✅

Algorithm (Steps)

  1. Array ko set mein convert karo (O(1) lookup)
  2. Har number ke liye check karo: num-1 set mein hai?
  3. Agar nahi hai → ye sequence ka start hai!
  4. Is number se aage count karo: num+1, num+2... jab tak milte rahe
  5. Longest streak track karo
Python 
class Solution:
    def longestConsecutive(self, nums: List[int]) -> int:
        numSet = set(nums)
        longest = 0
        
        for num in numSet:
            # Only start counting from sequence START
            if (num - 1) not in numSet:
                # This is the start of a sequence!
                length = 1
                
                # Count how far the sequence goes
                while (num + length) in numSet:
                    length += 1
                
                longest = max(longest, length)
        
        return longest

Dry Run Example

nums = [100, 4, 200, 1, 3, 2]
numSet = {100, 4, 200, 1, 3, 2}

Check each number:
• 100: 99 ∉ set → START! count 100 → length=1
• 4: 3 ∈ set → skip (not start)
• 200: 199 ∉ set → START! count 200 → length=1
• 1: 0 ∉ set → START! count 1,2,3,4 → length=4 ✅
• 3: 2 ∈ set → skip
• 2: 1 ∈ set → skip

Answer: 4

Kyun O(n) Hai?

🤔 "Par while loop hai andar, toh O(n²) nahi hona chahiye?"

Nahi! Kyunki har number at most ek baar while loop mein process hota hai:
• While loop sirf sequence start pe chalta hai
• Har number exactly ek sequence ka part hai
• Total operations = n (har element ek baar)

Amortized O(n) hai! 😎

Time & Space Complexity

⏱️ Time Complexity
O(n)
Each element processed once!
💾 Space Complexity
O(n)
Set storage
⚡ Best approach! O(n) time meets the requirement. Interview mein ye approach expected hai!
4

Hash Map - Boundary Tracking

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Advanced approach: Jab naya number aata hai, wo do existing sequences ko connect kar sakta hai!

Hash map mein boundary pe sequence length store karo.
• mp[num-1] = left side ki sequence length
• mp[num+1] = right side ki sequence length
Naya number dono ko join karta hai!

💭 Jaise puzzle pieces connect karte ho — left piece + new piece + right piece = bigger piece! Boundaries pe length update kar do taaki future connections ke liye pata rahe.
Python 
from collections import defaultdict

class Solution:
    def longestConsecutive(self, nums: List[int]) -> int:
        mp = defaultdict(int)  # num -> sequence length at boundary
        res = 0
        
        for num in nums:
            if not mp[num]:  # Skip duplicates
                # Get lengths of adjacent sequences
                left = mp[num - 1]   # Sequence ending at num-1
                right = mp[num + 1]  # Sequence starting at num+1
                
                # New sequence length = left + current + right
                length = left + right + 1
                
                # Update current position
                mp[num] = length
                
                # Update boundaries of the merged sequence
                mp[num - left] = length   # Left boundary
                mp[num + right] = length  # Right boundary
                
                res = max(res, length)
        
        return res

Dry Run Example

nums = [1, 3, 2]

Process 1: left=0, right=0 → len=1
mp = {1:1}

Process 3: left=0, right=0 → len=1
mp = {1:1, 3:1}

Process 2: left=mp[1]=1, right=mp[3]=1
len = 1+1+1 = 3
Update boundaries: mp[1]=3, mp[3]=3
mp = {1:3, 2:3, 3:3}

Answer: 3 ✅

Time & Space Complexity

⏱️ Time Complexity
O(n)
Single pass
💾 Space Complexity
O(n)
Hash map storage
💡 Ye approach Union-Find concept jaisi hai. Thoda complex, par interesting!
⚠️

Common Galtiyan (Pitfalls)

Har Number Se Sequence Start Karna

Ye biggest mistake hai! Same sequence baar baar count hoti hai → O(n²).

Python ❌ O(n²) 
for num in nums:
    # Starts from EVERY number!
    while curr in numSet:
        ...
Python ✅ O(n) 
for num in numSet:
    if (num - 1) not in numSet:
        # Only from STARTS!
        ...

Duplicates Handle Karna

Array mein duplicates ho sakte hain jaise [1,1,2,2,3].
Set use karo — automatically duplicates remove ho jayenge!

Empty Array Check

Agar nums = [] hai, toh answer 0 hai. Check karo edge case!

nums vs numSet Iterate Karna

Original array pe iterate karne se duplicates baar baar process hote hain. numSet pe iterate karo!

📋 Quick Comparison Table

Approach Time Space Notes
Brute Force O(n²) O(n) Repeated counting
Sorting O(n log n) O(1) Doesn't meet O(n) req
Hash Set BEST O(n) O(n) Start-only counting ⚡
Hash Map O(n) O(n) Boundary tracking
📌 Key insight: Sirf sequence ke START se count karo (num-1 should NOT exist)!
📚 Problem #9

Longest Common Prefix

Sabhi strings ka common prefix dhundho — Sorting ka Jugaad! 🔤✨

🟢 Easy Level

📋 Problem Statement

Tumhe ek array of strings diya gaya hai. Tumhe sabhi strings ka longest common prefix find karna hai. Agar koi common prefix nahi hai, toh empty string "" return karo.

🎯 Simple Bhasha Mein: Sab strings mein starting se jo letters same hain — wo dhundho! Jaise "flower", "flow", "flight" mein "fl" common hai starting se! 🌸

Example 1:

strs = ["flower", "flow", "flight"]

Output: "fl"

Sabhi strings "fl" se start hoti hain!

Example 2:

strs = ["dog", "racecar", "car"]

Output: ""

Koi common prefix nahi hai — sab alag letters se start hote hain!

📌 Constraints:

  • 1 <= strs.length <= 200
  • 0 <= strs[i].length <= 200
  • strs[i] contains only lowercase English letters

🎭 Real-life Analogy — Samjho Asaan Bhasha Mein!

Scenario — Phone Numbers! 📱
Socho tumhare paas kuch phone numbers hain: 9876543210, 9876512345, 9876598765. Inme starting digits same hain — 98765. Ye hai common prefix!

💡 File Names Wala Example:
project_report_v1.pdf, project_report_v2.pdf, project_report_final.pdf
Common prefix = "project_report_" 📁

🏷️ Naming Convention: Companies mein files ka naming convention hota hai — common prefix identify karna useful hota hai organization ke liye! 📂

🎨 Visual Understanding — Common Prefix Kaise Dikhta Hai?

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                    LONGEST COMMON PREFIX — VISUAL                            │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                                              │
│   strs = ["flower", "flow", "flight"]                                       │
│                                                                              │
│   STEP 1: Sort the array                                                    │
│   ─────────────────────────                                                  │
│   After sorting: ["flight", "flow", "flower"]                               │
│                                                                              │
│   STEP 2: Compare FIRST and LAST string only!                               │
│   ────────────────────────────────────────────                               │
│                                                                              │
│   First String:  f  l  i  g  h  t                                           │
│                  ↓  ↓  ✗                                                     │
│   Last String:   f  l  o  w  e  r                                           │
│                  ✓  ✓  ✗                                                     │
│                                                                              │
│   Common Prefix: "fl" ✅                                                     │
│                                                                              │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                                              │
│   🔥 WHY ONLY FIRST & LAST?                                                  │
│   ─────────────────────────                                                  │
│                                                                              │
│   After sorting:                                                             │
│   • First string = Lexicographically SMALLEST                               │
│   • Last string = Lexicographically LARGEST                                 │
│                                                                              │
│   Agar first aur last mein common prefix hai,                               │
│   toh BEECH wali sab strings mein bhi hoga! 💡                               │
│                                                                              │
│   Example:                                                                   │
│   Sorted: [abc, abd, abe, abf, abz]                                         │
│            ↑                    ↑                                            │
│          first               last                                            │
│                                                                              │
│   "abc" aur "abz" mein "ab" common hai                                      │
│   → Beech wali sab mein bhi "ab" common hoga! ✅                            │
│                                                                              │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

🧠 Algorithm — Sorting + Compare First & Last

📋 Algorithm Steps — Step by Step

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                    SORTING TRICK ALGORITHM                                   │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                                              │
│   STEP 1: Sort the array of strings                                         │
│   ──────────────────────────────────                                         │
│   Why? Sorting arranges strings lexicographically!                          │
│   After sorting, first string = smallest, last = largest                    │
│                                                                              │
│   STEP 2: Get first and last string                                         │
│   ──────────────────────────────────                                         │
│   first = strs[0]                                                           │
│   last = strs[-1]  (or strs[n-1])                                           │
│                                                                              │
│   STEP 3: Compare character by character                                    │
│   ───────────────────────────────────────                                    │
│   for i in range(min(len(first), len(last))):                               │
│       if first[i] != last[i]:                                               │
│           return prefix_so_far                                              │
│       prefix += first[i]                                                    │
│                                                                              │
│   STEP 4: Return the common prefix                                          │
│   ──────────────────────────────────                                         │
│   return prefix                                                              │
│                                                                              │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                                              │
│   ⏱️ Time Complexity:  O(n log n + m)                                       │
│      • n log n for sorting                                                  │
│      • m for comparing first and last (m = min length)                      │
│                                                                              │
│   📦 Space Complexity: O(1) extra (sorting can be in-place)                 │
│      • Just storing prefix string                                           │
│                                                                              │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

🔬 Dry Run — Complete Example!

📊 Dry Run: strs = ["flower", "flow", "flight"]

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                        COMPLETE DRY RUN                                       │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                                              │
│   INPUT: strs = ["flower", "flow", "flight"]                                │
│                                                                              │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│   STEP 1: Sort the array                                                    │
│   ─────────────────────────                                                  │
│                                                                              │
│   Before: ["flower", "flow", "flight"]                                      │
│   After:  ["flight", "flow", "flower"]                                      │
│                                                                              │
│   (Lexicographic order: flight < flow < flower)                             │
│                                                                              │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│   STEP 2: Get first and last                                                │
│   ──────────────────────────                                                 │
│                                                                              │
│   first = "flight"                                                          │
│   last  = "flower"                                                          │
│                                                                              │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│   STEP 3: Compare character by character                                    │
│   ───────────────────────────────────────                                    │
│                                                                              │
│   min_len = min(6, 6) = 6                                                   │
│                                                                              │
│   i=0: first[0]='f', last[0]='f' → MATCH ✅ → prefix = "f"                  │
│   i=1: first[1]='l', last[1]='l' → MATCH ✅ → prefix = "fl"                 │
│   i=2: first[2]='i', last[2]='o' → MISMATCH ❌ → RETURN "fl"                │
│                                                                              │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│   RESULT: "fl" ✅                                                            │
│                                                                              │
│   VERIFICATION:                                                              │
│   • "flight" starts with "fl" ✅                                            │
│   • "flow" starts with "fl" ✅                                              │
│   • "flower" starts with "fl" ✅                                            │
│                                                                              │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

📊 Dry Run 2: strs = ["dog", "racecar", "car"]

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                        NO COMMON PREFIX CASE                                  │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                                              │
│   INPUT: strs = ["dog", "racecar", "car"]                                   │
│                                                                              │
│   After sorting: ["car", "dog", "racecar"]                                  │
│                                                                              │
│   first = "car"                                                             │
│   last  = "racecar"                                                         │
│                                                                              │
│   i=0: first[0]='c', last[0]='r' → MISMATCH ❌ → RETURN ""                  │
│                                                                              │
│   RESULT: "" (empty string) ✅                                              │
│   First character hi different hai, toh koi common prefix nahi!             │
│                                                                              │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

💻 Code — Tumhara Solution (Sorting Approach!)

Python Sorting Trick — O(n log n) Time 
class Solution:
    def longestCommonPrefix(self, strs: List[str]) -> str:
        # Step 1: Sort the array
        # After sorting: first = smallest, last = largest (lexicographically)
        strs = sorted(strs)
        
        # Step 2: Get first and last strings
        first = strs[0]
        last = strs[-1]
        
        # Step 3: Compare first and last character by character
        s = ""  # This will store our common prefix
        
        for i in range(min(len(first), len(last))):
            if first[i] != last[i]:
                # Mismatch found! Return what we have so far
                return s
            s += first[i]  # Add matching character to prefix
        
        return s

# ✅ Time:  O(n log n + m) where n = number of strings, m = min string length
# ✅ Space: O(1) extra space (just storing prefix)
# 💡 Beats 100% Memory! 🚀
Python Vertical Scanning — O(n × m) Alternative 
class Solution:
    def longestCommonPrefix(self, strs: List[str]) -> str:
        if not strs:
            return ""
        
        # Take first string as reference
        prefix = strs[0]
        
        # Compare with each string
        for s in strs[1:]:
            # Shrink prefix until it matches
            while not s.startswith(prefix):
                prefix = prefix[:-1]  # Remove last character
                if not prefix:
                    return ""
        
        return prefix

# ✅ Time:  O(n × m) where n = number of strings, m = min string length
# ✅ Space: O(1) 
# 💡 Intuitive approach - shrink prefix until it fits all strings!
Java Sorting Approach 
class Solution {
    public String longestCommonPrefix(String[] strs) {
        // Sort the array
        Arrays.sort(strs);
        
        // Get first and last strings
        String first = strs[0];
        String last = strs[strs.length - 1];
        
        // Compare character by character
        StringBuilder prefix = new StringBuilder();
        int minLen = Math.min(first.length(), last.length());
        
        for (int i = 0; i < minLen; i++) {
            if (first.charAt(i) != last.charAt(i)) {
                return prefix.toString();
            }
            prefix.append(first.charAt(i));
        }
        
        return prefix.toString();
    }
}

🤔 Why Sorting Trick Works?

KEY INSIGHT — LEXICOGRAPHIC SORTING:
─────────────────────────────────────

Jab strings ko sort karte hain (lexicographically):
• First string = Sabse CHHOTA (alphabetically)
• Last string = Sabse BADA (alphabetically)

MAGIC: ✨
────────
Agar first aur last mein common prefix hai,
toh BEECH wali SABHI strings mein bhi wahi prefix hoga!

WHY?
────
Lexicographic sorting character-by-character compare karti hai.

Example:
    Sorted: ["abc", "abd", "abe", "abz"]
             ↑                      ↑
           first                  last
    
    "abc" aur "abz" mein "ab" common hai.
    
    Koi bhi string jo "abc" aur "abz" ke beech mein aayegi,
    uska starting bhi "ab" hi hoga! (by definition of sorting)
    
    "abd" → starts with "ab" ✅
    "abe" → starts with "ab" ✅

CONCLUSION:
───────────
Sirf FIRST aur LAST compare karna sufficient hai!
Baaki sab automatically covered ho jaate hain! 🎯

🧪 Edge Cases — Interview Mein Puchenge!

Case Example Result Why?
Single String ["hello"] "hello" Khud hi common prefix hai!
Empty String in Array ["", "abc"] "" Empty string se kuch common nahi
All Same ["aaa", "aaa"] "aaa" Puri string hi common hai!
No Common ["a", "b", "c"] "" First character hi alag
One is Prefix ["ab", "abc"] "ab" Smaller string is the prefix

🔄 Alternative Approaches

  1. Horizontal Scanning: Pehle 2 strings ka prefix lo, phir 3rd se compare karo, phir 4th... O(S) where S = sum of all characters
  2. Vertical Scanning: Column by column check karo — pehle sab ka 1st char, phir 2nd char... O(S)
  3. Divide & Conquer: Array ko 2 parts mein divide karo, har part ka prefix nikalo, phir merge karo O(S)
  4. Binary Search: Min length pe binary search karo prefix length ke liye O(S × log m)
  5. Trie: Sab strings ko Trie mein daalo, common path find karo O(S)
💡 Interview Tip: Sorting approach simple aur memorable hai! But interviewer se pucho — "Should I optimize for time or space?" Horizontal scanning O(S) time but O(1) space! ⚡

🎤 Interview Strategy — Kaise Approach Karo?

  1. Clarify: "So I need to find the longest prefix common to ALL strings?"
  2. Edge Cases: "What if array is empty? What if a string is empty?"
  3. Brute Force: "I could compare all strings character by character — O(n × m)"
  4. Optimization: "But if I SORT first, I only need to compare first and last!"
  5. Explain Why: "After sorting, if first and last share a prefix, all middle strings must too!"
🔥 Pro Tip: Ye problem bahut basic lagti hai, but sorting trick dikhake interviewer ko impress kar sakte ho! Simple problem, clever solution! 🏆

📊 Complexity Comparison

Approach Time Space Best For?
Sorting + Compare O(n log n + m) O(1) Simple & Clean Code
Horizontal Scan O(S) O(1) Optimal Time
Vertical Scan O(S) O(1) Early Termination
Divide & Conquer O(S) O(m log n) Parallelizable
🎯 Final Takeaway: Sorting trick yaad rakho! Sort karo → First aur Last compare karo → Done! Easy problem, smart solution! 💪
👉

Two Pointers

Left-Right pointers se efficient searching aur matching

5 Problems
📚 Problem #10

Merge Strings Alternately

Do strings ko alternating order mein merge karo — Easy peasy! 🔀✨

🟢 Easy Level

📋 Problem Statement

Tumhe do strings word1 aur word2 diye gaye hain. Inhe alternating order mein merge karo, word1 se start karke. Agar ek string doosri se badi hai, to remaining letters end mein append kar do.

🎯 Simple Bhasha Mein: Pehle word1 ka ek letter, phir word2 ka ek letter, phir word1 ka, phir word2 ka... Aise alternate karte jao! Jab ek khatam ho jaye, baaki ka directly attach kar do! 🎉

Example 1:

word1 = "abc", word2 = "pqr"

Output: "apbqcr"

a + p + b + q + c + r → apbqcr (Equal length, perfect interleave!)

Example 2:

word1 = "ab", word2 = "pqrs"

Output: "apbqrs"

word2 longer hai, to "rs" end mein append!

Example 3:

word1 = "abcd", word2 = "pq"

Output: "apbqcd"

word1 longer hai, to "cd" end mein append!

📌 Constraints:

  • 1 <= word1.length, word2.length <= 100
  • word1 aur word2 sirf lowercase English letters hain

🎭 Real-life Analogy — Samjho Asaan Bhasha Mein!

Scenario — Playing Cards Deal Karna! 🃏
Imagine karo tum 2 decks se cards deal kar rahe ho. Pehle deck 1 se ek card, phir deck 2 se ek card, phir deck 1, phir deck 2... jab tak dono mein cards hain!

Jab ek deck khatam ho jaye, baaki deck ke saare cards seedha de do! 🎴

💡 Another Analogy — Zipper! 🔐
Socho do zip tracks hain. Zipper inhe alternate karke join karta hai — exactly wahi karna hai!

🎨 Visual Understanding — Kaise Merge Hota Hai?

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                   MERGE STRINGS ALTERNATELY — VISUAL                         │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                                              │
│   EXAMPLE 1: Equal Length Strings                                            │
│   ─────────────────────────────────                                          │
│                                                                              │
│   word1:    a       b       c                                               │
│             ↓       ↓       ↓                                               │
│   merged:   a   p   b   q   c   r                                           │
│                 ↑       ↑       ↑                                           │
│   word2:        p       q       r                                           │
│                                                                              │
│   Result: "apbqcr" ✅                                                        │
│                                                                              │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                                              │
│   EXAMPLE 2: word2 is Longer                                                 │
│   ───────────────────────────                                                │
│                                                                              │
│   word1:    a       b                                                       │
│             ↓       ↓                                                       │
│   merged:   a   p   b   q   r   s                                           │
│                 ↑       ↑   ↑   ↑                                           │
│   word2:        p       q   r   s   ← Extra letters append!                 │
│                                                                              │
│   Result: "apbqrs" ✅                                                        │
│                                                                              │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                                              │
│   EXAMPLE 3: word1 is Longer                                                 │
│   ───────────────────────────                                                │
│                                                                              │
│   word1:    a       b       c   d   ← Extra letters append!                 │
│             ↓       ↓       ↓   ↓                                           │
│   merged:   a   p   b   q   c   d                                           │
│                 ↑       ↑                                                    │
│   word2:        p       q                                                   │
│                                                                              │
│   Result: "apbqcd" ✅                                                        │
│                                                                              │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

🧠 Algorithm — Two Pointer Approach

📋 Algorithm Steps

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                        ALGORITHM                                              │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                                              │
│   1️⃣  Find minimum length: l = min(len(word1), len(word2))                 │
│                                                                              │
│   2️⃣  Initialize: i = 0, ans = ""                                          │
│                                                                              │
│   3️⃣  WHILE i < l:                                                         │
│       • ans += word1[i]    (word1 ka letter pehle)                          │
│       • ans += word2[i]    (phir word2 ka letter)                           │
│       • i += 1                                                               │
│                                                                              │
│   4️⃣  AFTER LOOP:                                                          │
│       • Agar word1 bada hai → ans += word1[i:]  (remaining append)          │
│       • Agar word2 bada hai → ans += word2[i:]  (remaining append)          │
│                                                                              │
│   5️⃣  Return ans                                                            │
│                                                                              │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

⏱️ Time Complexity:  O(n + m) — Dono strings ek baar traverse
📦 Space Complexity: O(n + m) — Result string ke liye

🔬 Dry Run — Step by Step!

📊 Dry Run: word1 = "ab", word2 = "pqrs"

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                        COMPLETE DRY RUN                                       │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                                              │
│   INITIAL STATE:                                                             │
│   word1 = "ab"    (length = 2)                                              │
│   word2 = "pqrs"  (length = 4)                                              │
│   l = min(2, 4) = 2                                                         │
│   i = 0, ans = ""                                                           │
│                                                                              │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│   ITERATION 1 (i = 0):                                                       │
│   ─────────────────────                                                      │
│   ans += word1[0] = "a"   → ans = "a"                                       │
│   ans += word2[0] = "p"   → ans = "ap"                                      │
│   i = 1                                                                      │
│                                                                              │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│   ITERATION 2 (i = 1):                                                       │
│   ─────────────────────                                                      │
│   ans += word1[1] = "b"   → ans = "apb"                                     │
│   ans += word2[1] = "q"   → ans = "apbq"                                    │
│   i = 2                                                                      │
│                                                                              │
