        ']': '[',    # ']' ka match '[' hai
        '}': '{'     # '}' ka match '{' hai
    }
    
    # 🔄 Har character ko process karo
    for char in s:
        
        # 🔴 CASE 1: Closing bracket mila
        if char in closeToOpen:
            # Check karo: Stack empty toh nahi? Aur top match karta hai?
            if stack and stack[-1] == closeToOpen[char]:
                # ✅ Match! Pop karo
                stack.pop()
            else:
                # ❌ Mismatch ya stack empty — Invalid!
                return False
        
        # 🟢 CASE 2: Opening bracket mila
        else:
            # Simply push karo stack mein
            stack.append(char)
    
    # 🎯 FINAL CHECK: Stack empty hona chahiye!
    # Agar kuch bacha → unmatched opening brackets
    return len(stack) == 0


# 🧪 Testing All Cases
print(isValid("()"))         # True ✅ — Simple pair
print(isValid("()[]{}"))     # True ✅ — Multiple pairs
print(isValid("(]"))         # False ❌ — Mismatch
print(isValid("{[()]}"))     # True ✅ — Nested valid
print(isValid("([)]"))       # False ❌ — Wrong order
print(isValid("(("))         # False ❌ — Unmatched opens

Detailed Dry Run

Input: s = "([{}])"

icharTypeActionStack
0(OpenPush[(]
1[OpenPush[(, []
2{OpenPush[(, [, {]
3}CloseTop='{' ✅ Pop[(, []
4]CloseTop='[' ✅ Pop[(]
5)CloseTop='(' ✅ Pop[]

Stack empty → true ✅

⏱️ Time: O(n)
💾 Space: O(n)

⚠️ Common Galtiyan (Pitfalls)

❌

Empty Stack Check Bhoolna

Close bracket aaye aur stack empty ho — pehle check karo warna crash!

# ❌ WRONG: stack[-1] pehle access karna
if stack[-1] == closeToOpen[c]:

# ✅ CORRECT: Pehle check karo stack empty toh nahi
if stack and stack[-1] == closeToOpen[c]:
❌

End Mein Stack Check Bhoolna

"(()" process ho jaata hai bina error ke, but '(' bacha reh jaata hai! End mein stack empty check karo.

✅ Fix: return len(stack) == 0
❌

Mapping Direction Galat

Close → Open hona chahiye, Open → Close nahi!

✅ Correct: {')': '(', ']': '[', '}': '{'}
❌

Queue Use Karna Stack Ki Jagah

Queue FIFO hai, Stack LIFO! Parentheses ko LIFO chahiye (last opened = first closed).

✅ Fix: Stack use karo — list with append() & pop()

📋 Quick Comparison Table

Approach Time Space Notes
Brute Force (Replace) O(n²) O(n) Pairs replace karte jao
Stack BEST O(n) O(n) LIFO perfect fit! ⚡
📌 Key Insight: Stack = LIFO = "Jo last mein khula, wo pehle band!" Jab bhi nested structure ho (parentheses, HTML tags, function calls), Stack try karo! 🥞

19. Min Stack

Stack with getMin() in O(1) — Design ka classic interview question! 📚

MEDIUM

📋 Problem Statement

Design a stack that supports push, pop, top, and retrieving the minimum element in constant time O(1).

Operations:
  • push(val) — pushes the element val onto the stack
  • pop() — removes the element on the top of the stack
  • top() — gets the top element of the stack
  • getMin() — retrieves the minimum element in the stack
Example:
MinStack minStack = new MinStack();
minStack.push(-2);
minStack.push(0);
minStack.push(-3);
minStack.getMin();   // return -3
minStack.pop();
minStack.top();      // return 0
minStack.getMin();   // return -2
Constraints:
  • -2³¹ ≤ val ≤ 2³¹ - 1
  • Methods pop, top and getMin will always be called on non-empty stacks
  • At most 3 × 10⁴ calls will be made to push, pop, top, and getMin

🧠 Problem Ka Real Intuition — Kya Sochna Hai?

🎯 Core Question: Normal stack me getMin() ke liye poora stack scan karna padta hai — O(n). Lekin hume chahiye O(1) me minimum! Kaise karein?

🏠 Real Life Analogy — Book Stack Example

Imagine tumhare paas books ka stack hai. Har book ka price alag hai.

  • 📚 Normal stack: "Sabse sasti book kaun si?" → Saari books check karo
  • 📚 Smart stack: Har book ke saath ek chit chipka do jisme likha ho — "Ab tak ki sabse sasti book: ₹X"
  • 📚 Ab jab bhi poochho "sabse sasti?" → Sirf top book ki chit dekho! O(1)! 🎉

💡 Key Insight: Har level pe minimum track karo! Jab naya element aaye, uska minimum = min(current_value, previous_minimum)

🤔 Naive Approach Kyu Fail Hota Hai?

Naive Approach 
# ❌ Wrong Approach
def getMin(self):
    return min(self.stack)  # O(n) - poora stack scan!

# Interview me ye answer diya → Reject! 😅
🔴 Naive vs Smart Approach
❌ Naive Approach
1
getMin() called
2
Scan entire stack
O(n) time 🐢
3
Interview Reject! ❌
✅ Smart Approach
1
getMin() called
2
Return min_stack.top()
O(1) time ⚡
3
Interview Pass! ✅

✅ Approach A: Two Stack Method (Industry Standard)

O(1) all ops O(n)

💡 Core Idea — Har Level Ka Minimum Store Karo

🎯 Golden Rule: Do stacks maintain karo —

  1. stack → Actual values store karta hai
  2. min_stack → Har level tak ka minimum store karta hai

Dono stacks same size me chalte hain. Jab bhi kuch push/pop ho, dono me karo!

📊 Two Stack Architecture
📚 Main Stack
3 ← top
1 ★ min
4
2
5
📉 Min Stack
1 ← top
1 ★ min
2
2
5
💡 Rule: min_stack.top() = Current minimum in entire stack!

⚙️ Operations Ka Logic

📤 PUSH Operation Flow
push(val)
→
min_stack empty?
YES: push(val)
NO: push(min(val, top))
↓
stack.push(val) → Done! O(1)
📥 POP Operation Flow
pop()
→
stack.pop()
→
min_stack.pop()
→
Done! O(1)
🔄 Dono stacks se pop karo — sync me rahenge!
🔍 getMin Operation
getMin()
→
return min_stack.top()
→
⚡ O(1) - No scanning!

📺 Visual Dry Run — Step by Step

🎬 Operations Sequence
1
push(5)
stack: [5] | min_stack: [5] | min = 5
2
push(2)
stack: [5,2] | min_stack: [5,2] | min = 2 🆕
3
push(4)
stack: [5,2,4] | min_stack: [5,2,2] | min = 2 (unchanged)
4
push(1) 🎯 NEW MIN!
stack: [5,2,4,1] | min_stack: [5,2,2,1] | min = 1 🆕
🔍 Detailed Dry Run
Operation stack min_stack getMin() Explanation
push(5) [5] [5] 5 First element, min = 5
push(2) [5, 2] [5, 2] 2 min(2, 5) = 2
push(4) [5, 2, 4] [5, 2, 2] 2 min(4, 2) = 2 (min unchanged)
push(1) [5, 2, 4, 1] [5, 2, 2, 1] 1 min(1, 2) = 1 (NEW MIN!)
getMin() [5, 2, 4, 1] [5, 2, 2, 1] 1 Return min_stack.top()
pop() [5, 2, 4] [5, 2, 2] 2 Pop from both stacks
top() [5, 2, 4] [5, 2, 2] 2 Return stack.top() = 4
getMin() [5, 2, 4] [5, 2, 2] 2 min_stack.top() = 2
Python - Approach A (Two Stacks) 
class MinStack:
    """
    Min Stack using Two Stacks - Industry Standard Solution
    
    Approach:
    - Maintain two stacks: one for values, one for minimums
    - min_stack[i] = minimum value from index 0 to i
    - Both stacks always have same size
    
    Time: O(1) for all operations
    Space: O(n) for the extra min_stack
    """
    
    def __init__(self):
        self.stack = []      # Actual values
        self.min_stack = []  # Minimum at each level
    
    def push(self, val: int) -> None:
        """
        Push value onto stack and update minimum.
        
        Logic:
        - Always push to main stack
        - For min_stack: push min(val, current_min)
        """
        self.stack.append(val)
        
        if not self.min_stack:
            # First element - it's the minimum
            self.min_stack.append(val)
        else:
            # New min = min(new_value, previous_min)
            current_min = self.min_stack[-1]
            new_min = min(val, current_min)
            self.min_stack.append(new_min)
    
    def pop(self) -> None:
        """
        Pop from both stacks to keep them in sync.
        
        Why pop from both?
        - If we only pop from main stack, min_stack
          would have wrong size and wrong minimum
        """
        self.stack.pop()
        self.min_stack.pop()
    
    def top(self) -> int:
        """
        Return top element of main stack.
        Standard stack operation - O(1)
        """
        return self.stack[-1]
    
    def getMin(self) -> int:
        """
        Return current minimum - THE MAGIC!
        
        Why this works:
        - min_stack[-1] always has minimum of all elements
          currently in the stack
        - No scanning needed! O(1)
        """
        return self.min_stack[-1]


# ============ USAGE EXAMPLE ============
if __name__ == "__main__":
    minStack = MinStack()
    
    print("=== MinStack Demo ===")
    
    minStack.push(5)
    print(f"push(5) → stack={minStack.stack}, min_stack={minStack.min_stack}")
    
    minStack.push(2)
    print(f"push(2) → stack={minStack.stack}, min_stack={minStack.min_stack}")
    
    minStack.push(4)
    print(f"push(4) → stack={minStack.stack}, min_stack={minStack.min_stack}")
    
    minStack.push(1)
    print(f"push(1) → stack={minStack.stack}, min_stack={minStack.min_stack}")
    
    print(f"\ngetMin() = {minStack.getMin()}")  # 1
    
    minStack.pop()
    print(f"\npop() → stack={minStack.stack}, min_stack={minStack.min_stack}")
    print(f"getMin() = {minStack.getMin()}")  # 2
    
    print(f"\ntop() = {minStack.top()}")  # 4

✅ Interview Verdict: Ye approach most preferred hai! Clean, readable, bug-free, production-safe. Interviewer isse hi expect karta hai! 🎯

⚠️ Approach B: Single Stack Encoding Trick (Advanced)

O(1) all ops O(1) extra

⚠️ Warning — Ye Approach Risky Hai!

🔴 Interview me sirf tab bolo jab explicitly pucha jaaye:
"Can you do it with O(1) extra space?" ya "Can you use single stack?"

Otherwise, Approach A stick karo! Ye approach error-prone hai.

🧠 Core Idea — Encoding Magic

💡 Mind-bending trick: Hum stack me actual value store nahi karte!

Instead, hum store karte hain:

encoded_value = val - current_min

Aur saath me ek variable min_val maintain karte hain.

🔐 Encoding Logic
📝 Encoding Rules
1
diff = val - min_val
2
diff < 0?
YES → New minimum! Update min_val
NO → Normal push, min unchanged
🔓 Decoding Rules
1
Negative diff = This WAS the minimum
2
Get value: return min_val
3
Restore: old_min = min_val - diff

📜 Rules Explained

📤 PUSH with Encoding
push(val)
→
stack empty?
YES: push(0), min_val = val
NO: diff = val - min_val
↓
diff < 0?
YES: min_val = val 🆕
NO: min unchanged
📥 POP with Decoding
pop()
→
diff = stack.pop()
→
diff < 0?
YES: min_val = min_val - diff (restore!)
NO: min unchanged
👀 TOP with Decoding
top()
→
diff = stack.top()
→
diff < 0?
YES: return min_val (this IS min)
NO: return min_val + diff

❓ Why diff < 0 Important Hai?

🎯 Negative diff ka matlab:

  • diff = val - min_val
  • Agar diff < 0 → val < min_val
  • Matlab ye element new minimum tha!

👉 Isliye negative diff dekhte hi samajh jaate hain: "Ye wala element minimum tha, aur iske pehle ka minimum min_val - diff se recover hoga!"

🔍 Dry Run — Encoding Trick

Step-by-Step Trace
Operation val diff stack min_val Explanation
push(5) 5 0 [0] 5 First element, push 0
push(2) 2 -3 [0, -3] 2 2-5=-3 < 0 → NEW MIN!
push(4) 4 2 [0, -3, 2] 2 4-2=2 ≥ 0 → normal
top() - 2 [0, -3, 2] 2 diff≥0 → return 2+2=4 ✓
getMin() - - [0, -3, 2] 2 return min_val = 2
pop() - 2 [0, -3] 2 diff≥0 → min unchanged
pop() - -3 [0] 5 diff<0 → restore: 2-(-3)=5
getMin() - - [0] 5 return min_val = 5 ✓
Python - Approach B (Single Stack Encoding) 
class MinStack:
    """
    Min Stack using Encoding Trick - Single Stack, O(1) Extra Space
    
    Approach:
    - Store diff = val - current_min instead of actual value
    - Negative diff indicates: this element is/was the minimum
    - Decode using min_val when accessing
    
    Time: O(1) for all operations
    Space: O(1) extra (only min_val variable)
    
    WARNING: This approach is clever but error-prone!
    Use only when explicitly asked for O(1) space.
    """
    
    def __init__(self):
        self.stack = []    # Stores differences, not actual values!
        self.min_val = 0   # Current minimum
    
    def push(self, val: int) -> None:
        """
        Push encoded value onto stack.
        
        Encoding Logic:
        - First element: push 0, set min_val = val
        - Otherwise: push (val - min_val)
        - If val < min_val: update min_val (negative diff signals this)
        """
        if not self.stack:
            # First element - push 0, this becomes the baseline
            self.stack.append(0)
            self.min_val = val
        else:
            # Calculate difference from current minimum
            diff = val - self.min_val
            self.stack.append(diff)
            
            # If diff is negative, we have a new minimum!
            if diff < 0:
                self.min_val = val
    
    def pop(self) -> None:
        """
        Pop and potentially restore old minimum.
        
        Decoding Logic:
        - If popped diff < 0: this element WAS the minimum
        - Need to restore: old_min = current_min - diff
        """
        diff = self.stack.pop()
        
        # Negative diff means we're removing a minimum element
        # Need to restore the previous minimum
        if diff < 0:
            # old_min = min_val - diff
            # (since diff = old_val - old_min, and old_val == min_val when diff < 0)
            self.min_val = self.min_val - diff
    
    def top(self) -> int:
        """
        Decode and return actual top value.
        
        Decoding Logic:
        - If diff < 0: actual value = min_val (this IS the minimum)
        - If diff >= 0: actual value = min_val + diff
        """
        diff = self.stack[-1]
        
        if diff < 0:
            # This element is the current minimum
            return self.min_val
        else:
            # Decode: actual_value = min_val + diff
            return self.min_val + diff
    
    def getMin(self) -> int:
        """
        Return current minimum.
        Simply return min_val - O(1)!
        """
        return self.min_val


# ============ USAGE EXAMPLE ============
if __name__ == "__main__":
    minStack = MinStack()
    
    print("=== MinStack (Encoding) Demo ===\n")
    
    minStack.push(5)
    print(f"push(5) → stack={minStack.stack}, min_val={minStack.min_val}")
    print(f"  Explanation: First element, push 0, min=5")
    
    minStack.push(2)
    print(f"\npush(2) → stack={minStack.stack}, min_val={minStack.min_val}")
    print(f"  Explanation: diff=2-5=-3 < 0 → NEW MIN! push -3, update min=2")
    
    minStack.push(4)
    print(f"\npush(4) → stack={minStack.stack}, min_val={minStack.min_val}")
    print(f"  Explanation: diff=4-2=2 >= 0 → normal push")
    
    print(f"\ntop() = {minStack.top()}")
    print(f"  Explanation: diff=2 >= 0 → actual = 2+2 = 4")
    
    print(f"\ngetMin() = {minStack.getMin()}")
    
    minStack.pop()
    print(f"\npop() → stack={minStack.stack}, min_val={minStack.min_val}")
    print(f"  Explanation: diff=2 >= 0 → min unchanged")
    
    minStack.pop()
    print(f"\npop() → stack={minStack.stack}, min_val={minStack.min_val}")
    print(f"  Explanation: diff=-3 < 0 → restore min = 2-(-3) = 5")

📊 Approach A vs Approach B — Interview Comparison

Feature Two Stack (A) Encoding Trick (B)
Time Complexity O(1) all ops O(1) all ops
Space Complexity O(n) extra O(1) extra
Code Simplicity ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ ⭐⭐
Bug Risk Low High
Readability Excellent Tricky
Interview Safe ✅ Always ⚠️ Only if asked
Production Ready ✅ Yes ❌ Risky
Integer Overflow Risk None Possible with large values

🎤 Interview Tips — Min Stack

  • 📚 Default answer: Always start with Two Stack approach — clean, simple, no bugs!
  • 🎯 If asked for O(1) space: Then mention encoding trick, but explain the trade-offs
  • ⚠️ Encoding limitations: Integer overflow possible with very large/small values
  • 💡 Follow-up ready: "Can you implement Max Stack too?" (Same concept, track max instead)
  • 🔥 Variation: "getMin() that returns element AND its index" — need more bookkeeping

⚠️ Common Pitfalls — Avoid These Mistakes!

❌ Pitfall 1: Single min variable without tracking history
# WRONG!
class BadMinStack:
    def __init__(self):
        self.stack = []
        self.min_val = float('inf')
    
    def push(self, val):
        self.stack.append(val)
        self.min_val = min(self.min_val, val)
    
    def pop(self):
        val = self.stack.pop()
        # BUG: What if val == min_val?
        # min_val is now wrong! 😱

Problem: When you pop the minimum element, you lose track of the next minimum!

❌ Pitfall 2: Forgetting to sync both stacks
# WRONG!
def pop(self):
    self.stack.pop()
    # Forgot to pop from min_stack!
    # Now sizes are different, getMin() gives wrong answer
❌ Pitfall 3: Empty stack edge case
# WRONG!
def push(self, val):
    self.stack.append(val)
    # BUG: min_stack[-1] fails if min_stack is empty!
    self.min_stack.append(min(val, self.min_stack[-1]))

Fix: Always check if min_stack is empty first!

📊 Complexity Summary

Operation Two Stack Encoding
push() O(1) O(1)
pop() O(1) O(1)
top() O(1) O(1)
getMin() O(1) O(1)
Space O(n) O(1) extra

🔥 Interview One-liner

"The safest MinStack uses two stacks where each level stores the current minimum; a single-stack encoding trick exists for O(1) space but is harder to reason about and error-prone — use it only when explicitly asked!"

🔍

Binary Search

Sorted arrays mein O(log n) mein search — Divide & Conquer ka magic!

3 Problems
📚 Problem #20
🎯 Pattern 60: Rotated Array Binary Search

Find Minimum in Rotated Sorted Array

Rotated sorted array mein minimum dhundho — Binary Search ka twist! 🔄

🟡 Medium Level

Problem Kya Hai?

Ek sorted array nums diya hai jo k times rotate kiya gaya hai. Tumhe array ka minimum element find karna hai.

🎯 Rotation ka matlab: Array ke end se elements uthake front mein daal diye
📌 [1,2,3,4,5] → 2 times rotate → [4,5,1,2,3]
🎯 Goal: Minimum element dhundho (yahan 1)

Example 1:

nums = [3,4,5,1,2]

Output: 1

Explanation: Original sorted array [1,2,3,4,5] ko 3 times rotate kiya

Example 2:

nums = [4,5,6,7,0,1,2]

Output: 0

Example 3:

nums = [11,13,15,17]

Output: 11 — No rotation, already sorted!

🎭 Real-life Analogy — Circular Queue Mein Sabse Chhota Dhundho!

Scenario: Socho tumhare paas ek circular table hai jismein numbered cards rakhe hain (1 se 7 tak, sorted). Kisi ne table ghuma di! 🔄 Ab tumhe sabse chhota number dhundhna hai.

Observation: Rotation ke baad bhi ek interesting pattern hai — do sorted parts ban gaye!
• Part 1: [4, 5, 6, 7] — sorted, bade numbers
• Part 2: [1, 2, 3] — sorted, chhote numbers (minimum yahan hai!)

Key Insight: Minimum hamesha us jagah hoga jahan "big se small" ka jump ho! Ye wo point hai jahan rotation hui thi (pivot point)! 📍

💡 Binary Search Magic: Har step pe decide karo ki minimum LEFT mein hai ya RIGHT mein. Agar mid element last element se bada hai → minimum RIGHT side mein hai! Nahi toh LEFT mein (ya mid hi hai)!

🎤 Interview Tips — Binary Search Variations Master Karo!

  • 🔍 Binary Search kab use karein: "Array sorted hai (ya partially sorted), toh O(log n) possible hai. Linear search se better kar sakte hain!"
  • 📊 Pattern recognize karo: "Rotated array do sorted subarrays mein divide hota hai. Minimum wo point hai jahan drop hota hai!"
  • ⚠️ Edge cases batao:
    • No rotation: [1,2,3,4] → first element hi minimum
    • Single element: [5] → wo hi minimum
    • Two elements: [2,1] → compare karo
    • Full rotation (n times): Same as original sorted
  • 🧠 Key decision explain karo: "Har step pe compare karta hun mid vs right. Agar mid > right, minimum right mein hai. Agar mid ≤ right, minimum left mein ya mid hai!"
  • 🔄 Related problem mention karo: "Search in Rotated Array bhi similar hai — pehle minimum find karo, phir correct half mein search karo!"

🧠 Kyun Binary Search Kaam Karta Hai? — Deep Dive!

Core Insight: Rotated sorted array mein hamesha ek "inflection point" hota hai jahan big number ke baad chhota number aata hai. Minimum wahi hai!

Decision Logic:
• Array: [4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2] (0 = minimum)
• Compare mid with right:
  → If nums[mid] > nums[right]: Minimum is in RIGHT half (jump happened)
  → If nums[mid] ≤ nums[right]: Minimum is in LEFT half or is mid itself

Example walkthrough: [4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2]
• mid=7, right=2 → 7>2 → minimum RIGHT mein hai ✅
• mid=0, right=2 → 0≤2 → minimum LEFT mein ya mid hai → check left
• Eventually 0 milega!

❓ Common Follow-up Questions — Tayyar Raho!

Q1: "Agar duplicates allowed hon toh?" (Find Min II)
→ Tricky! Jab nums[mid]==nums[right], right-- karo. Worst case O(n) ban sakta hai!

Q2: "Specific target search karna ho rotated array mein?"
→ Pehle minimum find karo (pivot), phir decide karo left half mein search karna hai ya right half mein!

Q3: "Kitni baar rotate hua hai ye kaise pata karein?"
→ Minimum ka index = number of rotations! Index 4 pe minimum → 4 times rotated!

Q4: "Agar descending order mein sorted ho toh?"
→ Comparisons flip karo! Maximum dhundhna easy hoga, minimum end mein hoga!

🔄 Rotated Array Ka Structure

Original: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7]  (sorted ascending)

Rotated:  [4, 5, 6, 7, 1, 2, 3]  (rotated by 4)
          │←──────→│ │←────→│
          Sorted ↑   Sorted ↓
          (Higher)   (Lower)  
                     ↑
                   MINIMUM!

Key Observation:
┌────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│  Rotated array has TWO sorted halves!          │
│                                                │
│  Left half:  [4, 5, 6, 7] → sorted, HIGHER     │
│  Right half: [1, 2, 3]    → sorted, LOWER      │
│                                                │
│  Minimum = First element of right half! 🎯     │
└────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Binary Search Trick:
- Compare mid with rightmost element
- If nums[mid] > nums[right] → min is in RIGHT half
- If nums[mid] < nums[right] → min is in LEFT half (including mid)
1

Brute Force Approach

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Simple hai — saare elements check karo, sabse chhota return karo! 🔍

Rotation ho ya na ho, minimum toh array mein hai hi. Poora scan karo aur minimum track karo.

💭 Jaise class mein sabse chhota student dhundhna ho — sabko khada karke compare karo!

Python Code

# ============================================
# 🔍 BRUTE FORCE: Find Minimum in Rotated Array
# ============================================
# Approach: Simple hai — poora array scan karo!
# Rotation ho ya na ho, minimum toh hai hi andar 😄

def findMin(nums):
    """
    Sabse simple tarika — Python ka built-in min() use karo
    Time: O(n) kyunki poora array traverse hota hai
    """
    return min(nums)


# --------------------------------------------
# 📝 Manual Implementation (Interview ke liye)
# --------------------------------------------
def findMin_manual(nums):
    """
    Khud se minimum find karo — bina built-in function ke
    Yeh approach interviewer ko dikhao pehle!
    """
    # Step 1: Pehle element ko minimum maan lo
    minimum = nums[0]
    
    # Step 2: Baaki sabko check karo
    for num in nums:
        # Agar current element chhota hai, update karo
        if num < minimum:
            minimum = num
    
    # Step 3: Sabse chhota return karo
    return minimum


# 🧪 Testing
print(findMin([3, 4, 5, 1, 2]))       # Output: 1 ✅
print(findMin([4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2])) # Output: 0 ✅
print(findMin([11, 13, 15, 17]))      # Output: 11 ✅ (no rotation)
⏱️ Time: O(n)
💾 Space: O(1)

⚠️ Works, but we're not using the fact that array is SORTED! Can we do better? 🤔

2

Binary Search

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Rotated sorted array ki ek special property hai: 🎯

Ek portion sorted hai, doosra mein rotation point (minimum) hai!

  • Agar left half sorted hai → minimum RIGHT mein hoga
  • Agar right half sorted hai → minimum LEFT mein hoga (ya mid pe)
  • Har step mein half array eliminate karo!
💭 Sochko — agar left side sorted hai (ascending), toh rotation point right mein hai!

Algorithm Steps

1
Initialize: left = 0, right = n-1, res = nums[0]
2
Check sorted: Agar nums[left] < nums[right] → already sorted, return min(res, nums[left])
3
Find mid: mid = (left + right) // 2
4
Update res: res = min(res, nums[mid])
5
Decide: Agar nums[mid] >= nums[left] → left sorted, search RIGHT. Else search LEFT.

Python Code

# ============================================
# 🔍 BINARY SEARCH: Find Minimum in Rotated Array
# ============================================
# Key Insight: Rotated array = 2 sorted halves!
# Ek half HIGHER values wala, ek LOWER values wala
# Minimum = Lower half ka first element 🎯

def findMin(nums):
    """
    Binary Search approach jo sorted property use karta hai
    Har step mein half array eliminate karte hain!
    
    Time: O(log n) — kyunki half-half karte hain
    Space: O(1) — sirf pointers use kar rahe
    """
    
    # Step 1: Initialize karo pointers aur result
    res = nums[0]              # Pehle element se start karo
    left = 0                   # Left pointer
    right = len(nums) - 1      # Right pointer
    
    # Step 2: Binary search loop
    while left <= right:
        
        # 🎯 OPTIMIZATION: Agar current window already sorted hai
        # toh minimum left pe hi hai — no need to search further!
        if nums[left] < nums[right]:
            res = min(res, nums[left])
            break   # Early exit! 🚀
        
        # Middle element calculate karo
        mid = (left + right) // 2
        
        # Current mid ko consider karo as potential answer
        res = min(res, nums[mid])
        
        # 🤔 DECIDE: Konsi side jaana hai?
        # Agar nums[mid] >= nums[left] → Left half sorted hai
        # Matlab rotation RIGHT side mein hai!
        if nums[mid] >= nums[left]:
            # Left side sorted (higher values) → search RIGHT
            left = mid + 1
        else:
            # Right side sorted (lower values) → search LEFT
            right = mid - 1
    
    return res


# 🧪 Testing with Detailed Output
print(findMin([3, 4, 5, 1, 2]))       # Output: 1 ✅
print(findMin([4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2])) # Output: 0 ✅
print(findMin([2, 1]))                # Output: 1 ✅ (simple case)

Dry Run

Input: nums = [4,5,6,7,0,1,2]

Iterleftrightmidnums[mid]Checkres
106377≥4 → go RIGHT4→7
246511<0? No, 1≥0 → go RIGHT7→1
344400<2 sorted → break1→0 ⭐

Final Answer: 0 ✅

⏱️ Time: O(log n)
💾 Space: O(1)
3

Binary Search (Lower Bound) ✨ CLEANEST

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Aur bhi clean approach! Sirf rightmost se compare karo! 🎯

Key insight:

  • Agar nums[mid] < nums[right] → minimum LEFT mein hai (including mid)
  • Agar nums[mid] > nums[right] → minimum RIGHT mein hai (excluding mid)
💡 Why compare with right?
Right element always in the "lower sorted half" hota hai (rotation ke baad).
Agar mid < right → mid bhi lower half mein hai → minimum left side mein ho sakta hai.
Agar mid > right → mid higher half mein hai → minimum right side mein hai!

Python Code

# ============================================
# ✨ LOWER BOUND: Cleanest Binary Search Solution
# ============================================
# Sabse elegant approach! Sirf right se compare karo
# Loop end hone pe left automatically minimum pe hoga 🎯

def findMin(nums):
    """
    Lower Bound technique — sabse clean implementation!
    
    💡 Key Insight:
    - nums[mid] < nums[right] → mid "lower half" mein hai
      → minimum LEFT mein hai (mid included)
    - nums[mid] > nums[right] → mid "higher half" mein hai  
      → minimum RIGHT mein hai (mid excluded)
    
    Time: O(log n)
    Space: O(1)
    """
    
    # Two pointers initialize karo
    left = 0
    right = len(nums) - 1
    
    # Jab tak pointers converge nahi karte
    while left < right:   # Note: < NOT <=
        
        # 🛡️ Overflow-safe mid calculation
        # (left + right) // 2 se overflow ho sakta hai large arrays mein
        mid = left + (right - left) // 2
        
        # 🔑 THE KEY COMPARISON: mid vs right
        if nums[mid] < nums[right]:
            # ✅ Mid LOWER half mein hai (smaller values)
            # Minimum left mein ho sakta hai, mid pe bhi ho sakta hai!
            right = mid     # 👈 mid include karo!
            
        else:  # nums[mid] > nums[right]
            # ✅ Mid HIGHER half mein hai (larger values)
            # Minimum definitely right mein hai, mid pe nahi
            left = mid + 1  # 👈 mid exclude karo!
    
    # 🎯 Loop khatam hone pe left = right = minimum index
    return nums[left]


# 🧪 Testing All Cases
print(findMin([3, 4, 5, 1, 2]))       # Output: 1 ✅ (rotated)
print(findMin([4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2])) # Output: 0 ✅ (rotated)
print(findMin([11, 13, 15, 17]))      # Output: 11 ✅ (not rotated)
print(findMin([2, 1]))                # Output: 1 ✅ (simple)
print(findMin([1]))                   # Output: 1 ✅ (single element)

Detailed Dry Run

Input: nums = [3,4,5,1,2]

Iterleftrightmidnums[mid]nums[right]CompareAction
1042525 > 2left = 3
2343121 < 2right = 3
End33---left==rightReturn nums[3]=1 ⭐

Final Answer: 1 ✅

⏱️ Time: O(log n)
💾 Space: O(1)

⚠️ Common Galtiyan (Pitfalls)

❌

Left Se Compare Karna

Lower bound approach mein nums[mid] ko nums[left] se compare karna galat results deta hai (especially non-rotated arrays mein).

✅ Fix: Hamesha nums[right] se compare karo!
❌

Boundary Update Galat

Jab nums[mid] < nums[right], minimum mid pe bhi ho sakta hai! Isliye right = mid (not mid-1).

✅ Remember:
• mid < right → right = mid
• mid >= right → left = mid + 1
❌

Non-Rotated Case Bhoolna

Array agar rotate nahi hua (ya n times rotate hua), toh minimum first element hai. Algorithm handle karna chahiye.

✅ Fix: Lower bound approach automatically handles this! Loop ends with left=0 for sorted array.

📋 Quick Comparison Table

Approach Time Space Notes
Brute Force (min) O(n) O(1) Simple but ignores sorted property
Binary Search O(log n) O(1) Compare with left, track min
Lower Bound BEST O(log n) O(1) Compare with right, cleanest! ⚡
📌 Key Pattern: Rotated sorted array = 2 sorted halves! Binary search mein nums[mid] vs nums[right] compare karke decide karo — minimum LEFT mein hai ya RIGHT mein! 🔍
📚 Problem #21

Search in Rotated Sorted Array

Rotated array mein target dhundho — Binary Search ka asli test! 🎯

🟡 Medium Level

Problem Kya Hai?

Ek sorted array nums hai jo k times rotate kiya gaya hai. Ek target value di gayi hai — tumhe uska index return karna hai. Agar target nahi mila toh -1 return karo.

🎯 Constraint: O(log n) time mein karna hai — matlab Binary Search zaruri hai!
📌 Array mein distinct values hain (koi duplicate nahi)
🔄 Rotation Example: [1,2,3,4,5] → [4,5,1,2,3]

Example 1:

nums = [4,5,6,7,0,1,2], target = 0

Output: 4 — 0 index 4 pe hai!

Example 2:

nums = [4,5,6,7,0,1,2], target = 3

Output: -1 — 3 array mein nahi hai!

Example 3:

nums = [1], target = 0

Output: -1 — Single element, target different!

🔄 Rotated Array Ka Structure Samjho

Original Sorted: [0, 1, 2, 4, 5, 6, 7]

Rotated (by 4):  [4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2]
                  │←──────→│ │←────→│
                  HIGHER ↑   LOWER ↓
                  (Left Half)  (Right Half)
                              ↑
                           PIVOT (minimum)

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│  🎯 KEY INSIGHT:                                     │
│                                                      │
│  Rotated array mein HAMESHA ek half SORTED hoti hai! │
│                                                      │
│  Binary Search mein mid nikalte waqt:                │
│  - Check karo LEFT half sorted hai ya RIGHT half     │
│  - Sorted half mein target ho sakta hai kya?         │
│  - Accordingly left/right pointer move karo!         │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Example: nums = [4,5,6,7,0,1,2], target = 0

Step 1: mid = 3 (value = 7)
        Left half [4,5,6,7] sorted hai (4 ≤ 7)
        Target 0, is range mein nahi (0 < 4)
        → Search RIGHT half!

Step 2: mid = 5 (value = 1)  
        Left half [0,1] sorted hai (0 ≤ 1)
        Target 0, is range mein hai (0 ≤ 0 ≤ 1)
        → Search LEFT half!

Step 3: mid = 4 (value = 0) → FOUND! Return 4 ✅
1

Brute Force Approach

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Sabse simple — ek-ek element check karo! 🔍

Array sorted ho ya rotated ho ya kuch bhi ho — linear scan se target mil hi jaayega (agar hai toh). Lekin yeh O(n) hai, problem O(log n) maang raha hai!

💭 Jaise phone book mein naam dhundhna — ek-ek page dekhte jao! (Sorted hai toh faster ho sakta hai but brute force mein hum ignore karte hain)

Python Code

# ============================================
# 🔍 BRUTE FORCE: Linear Search in Rotated Array
# ============================================
# Sabse simple approach — ek-ek element check karo!
# Rotation ki chinta nahi, bas poora array traverse karo
# ⚠️ O(n) hai — interview mein accept nahi hoga!

def search(nums, target):
    """
    Brute Force Linear Search
    
    🎯 Logic: Har element ko target se compare karo
    - Match mila → index return karo
    - Nahi mila → -1 return karo
    
    Time: O(n) — Poora array traverse
    Space: O(1) — Koi extra space nahi
    """
    
    # 🔄 Har element check karo
    for i in range(len(nums)):
        if nums[i] == target:
            # ✅ Mil gaya! Index return karo
            return i
    
    # ❌ Poora array check kiya, nahi mila
    return -1


# 🧪 Testing
print(search([4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2], 0))   # Output: 4 ✅
print(search([4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2], 3))   # Output: -1 ❌
print(search([1], 0))                      # Output: -1 ❌
print(search([1, 3], 3))                   # Output: 1 ✅
⏱️ Time: O(n)
💾 Space: O(1)

⚠️ Problem mein O(log n) maanga hai — yeh accept nahi hoga interview mein!

2

Binary Search (Two Pass — Pivot Pehle Dhundho)

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Rotated array = Do sorted arrays jode hue! 🔗

Two Pass Strategy:

  • Pass 1: Pivot dhundho (minimum element ka index) — yeh rotation point hai
  • Pass 2: Decide karo target LEFT half mein hai ya RIGHT half mein
  • Phir us half mein normal binary search karo!
💭 Jaise broken ruler — pehle dhundho kahan se tuti hai, phir measure karo!

Algorithm Steps

1
Find Pivot: Binary search se minimum element dhundho (rotation point)
2
Decide Half: Target ka value check karo — [pivot, end] mein hai ya [0, pivot-1] mein
3
Binary Search: Selected half mein normal binary search chala do

Python Code

# ============================================
# 🔍 TWO PASS: Pivot Dhundho + Binary Search
# ============================================
# Pass 1: Pehle minimum element (pivot) dhundho
# Pass 2: Phir correct half mein binary search karo
# 
# 💡 Rotated array = 2 sorted halves joined together!

def search(nums, target):
    """
    Two Pass Binary Search
    
    🎯 Strategy:
    1. Find pivot (index of minimum element)
    2. Decide which half to search
    3. Run standard binary search on that half
    
    Time: O(log n) — 2 binary searches
    Space: O(1)
    """
    n = len(nums)
    
    # ========================================
    # 📍 PASS 1: Find Pivot (Minimum Element)
    # ========================================
    # Pivot = jahan se rotation shuru hui
    # Iske left mein bade elements, right mein chhote
    
    left, right = 0, n - 1
    
    while left < right:
        mid = (left + right) // 2
        
        # Agar mid > right → minimum RIGHT mein hai
        if nums[mid] > nums[right]:
            left = mid + 1
        else:
            # Minimum LEFT mein hai (including mid)
            right = mid
    
    # 🎯 Ab left = right = pivot index
    pivot = left
    
    # ========================================
    # 📍 PASS 2: Decide Which Half to Search
    # ========================================
    # Reset pointers
    left, right = 0, n - 1
    
    # Target kis half mein hai?
    # Right half: [pivot, n-1] mein smallest se largest tak
    if target >= nums[pivot] and target <= nums[right]:
        # ✅ Target RIGHT half mein hai
        left = pivot
    else:
        # ✅ Target LEFT half mein hai
        right = pivot - 1
    
    # ========================================
    # 📍 Standard Binary Search
    # ========================================
    while left <= right:
        mid = (left + right) // 2
        
        if nums[mid] == target:
            # 🎉 Mil gaya!
            return mid
        elif nums[mid] < target:
            left = mid + 1
        else:
            right = mid - 1
    
    # ❌ Nahi mila
    return -1


# 🧪 Testing
print(search([4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2], 0))   # Output: 4 ✅
print(search([4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2], 3))   # Output: -1 ❌
print(search([1], 0))                      # Output: -1 ❌
print(search([1, 3], 1))                   # Output: 0 ✅

Dry Run

Input: nums = [4,5,6,7,0,1,2], target = 0

Pass 1: Find Pivot

Iterleftrightmidnums[mid]nums[right]Action
1063727 > 2 → left = 4
2465121 < 2 → right = 5
3454010 < 1 → right = 4

Pivot = 4 (nums[4] = 0 minimum hai)

Pass 2: Binary Search — target 0 ≥ nums[4] aur ≤ nums[6] → RIGHT half search

Search [4,6], mid = 5 → nums[5]=1 > 0 → right = 4

Search [4,4], mid = 4 → nums[4]=0 = target → Return 4 ✅

⏱️ Time: O(log n)
💾 Space: O(1)
3

Binary Search (One Pass) ✨ OPTIMAL

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Ek hi pass mein kaam khatam! 🚀 Pivot alag se dhundhne ki zarurat nahi!

Key Observation: Rotated array mein mid ke around HAMESHA ek half sorted hoti hai!

  • Left half sorted: nums[left] ≤ nums[mid]
  • Right half sorted: Otherwise

Sorted half mein easily check kar sakte hain ki target wahan hai ya nahi!

💡 Logic:
1. Check karo LEFT sorted hai ya RIGHT sorted
2. Sorted half mein dekho — target us range mein hai kya?
3. Agar hai → us taraf jao, nahi hai → doosri taraf jao!

Algorithm Steps

1
Calculate mid: mid = (left + right) // 2
2
Check target: Agar nums[mid] == target → Return mid
3
If LEFT sorted (nums[left] ≤ nums[mid]):
- Target in range [left, mid]? → Search left
- Else → Search right
4
If RIGHT sorted:
- Target in range [mid, right]? → Search right
- Else → Search left

Python Code

# ============================================
# ✨ ONE PASS: Single Binary Search (OPTIMAL)
# ============================================
# Ek hi pass mein sab kuch — no need to find pivot first!
# 
# 💡 Key Insight: 
# Rotated array mein mid ke around HAMESHA ek half sorted hoti hai!
# Us sorted half mein check karo — target wahan hai kya?

def search(nums, target):
    """
    One Pass Binary Search — OPTIMAL Solution!
    
    🎯 Logic har iteration mein:
    1. Check karo LEFT half sorted hai ya RIGHT half
    2. Sorted half mein dekho — target us range mein fit hota hai?
    3. Accordingly pointer move karo!
    
    Time: O(log n) — Single binary search
    Space: O(1) — No extra space
    """
    
    left, right = 0, len(nums) - 1
    
    while left <= right:
        mid = (left + right) // 2
        
        # 🎉 Target mil gaya!
        if nums[mid] == target:
            return mid
        
        # ========================================
        # 📍 Check: LEFT half sorted hai kya?
        # ========================================
        # nums[left] <= nums[mid] matlab left to mid sorted hai
        if nums[left] <= nums[mid]:
            # ✅ LEFT HALF is SORTED!
            
            # Ab check karo — target is sorted range mein hai?
            # Range: [nums[left], nums[mid]]
            if target > nums[mid] or target < nums[left]:
                # ❌ Target LEFT sorted half mein NAHI hai
                # → RIGHT half mein search karo
                left = mid + 1
            else:
                # ✅ Target LEFT sorted half mein hai
                # → LEFT mein search karo
                right = mid - 1
        
        # ========================================
        # 📍 RIGHT half sorted hai
        # ========================================
        else:
            # ✅ RIGHT HALF is SORTED!
            # Range: [nums[mid], nums[right]]
            
            if target < nums[mid] or target > nums[right]:
                # ❌ Target RIGHT sorted half mein NAHI hai
                # → LEFT half mein search karo
                right = mid - 1
            else:
                # ✅ Target RIGHT sorted half mein hai
                # → RIGHT mein search karo
                left = mid + 1
    
    # ❌ Poora search kiya, nahi mila
    return -1


# 🧪 Testing All Cases
print(search([4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2], 0))   # Output: 4 ✅
print(search([4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2], 3))   # Output: -1 ❌
print(search([4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2], 5))   # Output: 1 ✅
print(search([1], 0))                      # Output: -1 ❌
print(search([1, 3], 3))                   # Output: 1 ✅
print(search([3, 1], 1))                   # Output: 1 ✅ (rotated)
print(search([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], 3))         # Output: 2 ✅ (not rotated)

Detailed Dry Run

Input: nums = [4,5,6,7,0,1,2], target = 5

Iterleftrightmidnums[mid]Sorted HalfTarget in range?Action
10637LEFT [4,5,6,7]5 in [4,7]? ✅right = 2
20215-FOUND!Return 1 ⭐

Final Answer: 1 ✅

Kyun nums[left] <= nums[mid] mein <=?

🤔 Common Question: < ki jagah <= kyun use kiya?

Answer: Edge case jab left == mid ho!
  • Jab array small ho (2 elements), mid aur left same ho sakte hain
  • Us case mein nums[left] == nums[mid] hoga
  • < use kiya toh galat half select ho jayega!
  • <= se single element bhi "sorted" maana jaata hai ✅
⏱️ Time: O(log n)
💾 Space: O(1)

⚠️ Common Galtiyan (Pitfalls)

❌

Strict Inequality (<) Use Karna

One-pass approach mein nums[left] < nums[mid] use karna galat hai jab left == mid. Small arrays mein fail hoga!

✅ Fix: nums[left] <= nums[mid] use karo — equal case handle hoga!
❌

Pivot Finding aur Target Finding Mix Karna

Two-pass approach mein pivot dhundhne ka logic alag hai, target search ka alag. Dono ko mix mat karo!

✅ Fix: Clear separation rakho — pehle pivot, phir search. Ya one-pass use karo!
❌

Non-Rotated Array Handle Na Karna

Array agar rotate nahi hua ([1,2,3,4,5]), tab bhi code work karna chahiye. Pivot index 0 hoga.

✅ Test: Non-rotated arrays pe bhi test karo!
❌

Target Range Check Galat

Sorted half mein target check karte waqt >= aur <= carefully use karo, nahi toh boundary elements miss ho jayenge!

✅ Fix: target >= nums[left] AND target <= nums[mid] — dono bounds check karo!

📋 Quick Comparison Table

Approach Time Space Hinglish Summary
Brute Force O(n) O(1) Ek-ek element check karo 😅
Two Pass (Pivot First) O(log n) O(1) Pehle minimum dhundho, phir search
One Pass BEST O(log n) O(1) Sorted half identify karo, phir decide! ⚡
📌 Key Pattern: Rotated array mein HAMESHA ek half sorted hoti hai! Binary search mein sorted half identify karo → check karo target us range mein hai? → accordingly move karo! 🎯
🔴 Problem #22

Median of Two Sorted Arrays

Do sorted arrays ka median nikalo — Binary Search ka BOSS Level! 🏆

🔴 Hard Level

📋 Problem Statement

Tumhe do sorted arrays diye gaye hain — nums1 (size m) aur nums2 (size n). Tumhe dono arrays ka median return karna hai.

🎯 Median Kya Hai?
• Agar total elements ODD hain → Middle element
• Agar total elements EVEN hain → Average of two middle elements

⚡ Constraint: Time Complexity O(log(m+n)) honi chahiye — Brute Force allowed nahi!

Example 1:

nums1 = [1, 3], nums2 = [2]

Output: 2.00000

Merged = [1, 2, 3] → Median = 2 (middle element)

Example 2:

nums1 = [1, 2], nums2 = [3, 4]

Output: 2.50000

Merged = [1, 2, 3, 4] → Median = (2 + 3) / 2 = 2.5

📌 Constraints:

  • nums1.length == m, nums2.length == n
  • 0 <= m, n <= 1000
  • 1 <= m + n <= 2000
  • -10⁶ <= nums1[i], nums2[i] <= 10⁶

🎭 Real-life Analogy — Samjho Asaan Bhasha Mein!

Scenario — Two Sorted Queues of Students! 🧑‍🎓
Imagine karo do alag-alag classes ke students hain, dono classes mein students already height ke hisaab se sorted khade hain.

Ab tumhe sabko mila ke MIDDLE wala student dhundna hai — but actually merge kiye bina! 🎯

💡 Key Insight: Hum partition dhundhte hain — left half mein kitne elements chahiye, wo dono arrays se smartly choose karte hain! 🧠

📝 Approach 1: Merge & Find (Tumhara Solution!)

🔧 Brute Force — O(m + n)

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                    APPROACH 1: MERGE & FIND MEDIAN                           │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                                              │
│   IDEA: Do sorted arrays ko merge karo, phir median nikalo                   │
│                                                                              │
│   nums1 = [1, 3]                                                            │
│   nums2 = [2]                                                               │
│                                                                              │
│   Step 1: Merge using Two Pointers                                          │
│   ─────────────────────────────────                                          │
│   i=0, j=0:  1 < 2  → temp = [1], i++                                       │
│   i=1, j=0:  3 > 2  → temp = [1,2], j++                                     │
│   i=1, j=1:  j exhausted, append remaining                                  │
│   Final:     temp = [1, 2, 3]                                               │
│                                                                              │
│   Step 2: Find Median                                                       │
│   ─────────────────────                                                      │
│   len = 3 (odd) → median = temp[3//2] = temp[1] = 2                         │
│                                                                              │
│   ⏱️ Time:  O(m + n) — merge ke liye                                        │
│   📦 Space: O(m + n) — temp array ke liye                                   │
│                                                                              │
│   ❌ Problem: Interview mein ye ACCEPT nahi hoga!                            │
│      Constraint hai: O(log(m+n)) time chahiye!                              │
│                                                                              │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
Python Brute Force — O(m+n) ⚠️ 
class Solution:
    def findMedianSortedArrays(self, nums1: List[int], nums2: List[int]) -> float:
        i = 0
        j = 0
        temp = []
        
        # Step 1: Merge both sorted arrays
        while i < len(nums1) and j < len(nums2):
            if nums1[i] <= nums2[j]:
                temp.append(nums1[i])
                i += 1
            else:
                temp.append(nums2[j])
                j += 1
        
        # Remaining elements from nums1
        while i < len(nums1):
            temp.append(nums1[i])
            i += 1
        
        # Remaining elements from nums2
        while j < len(nums2):
            temp.append(nums2[j])
            j += 1
        
        # Step 2: Find median
        n = len(temp)
        if n % 2 == 0:
            mid = n // 2
            ans = (temp[mid] + temp[mid - 1]) / 2
        else:
            ans = temp[n // 2]
        
        return ans

# ⚠️ Time: O(m+n) — Interview mein REJECT ho sakta hai!
# ⚠️ Space: O(m+n)

🚀 Approach 2: Binary Search (Optimal Solution!)

🧠 Binary Search on Partition — O(log(min(m,n)))

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                    OPTIMAL APPROACH: BINARY SEARCH ON PARTITION              │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                                              │
│   KEY INSIGHT:                                                               │
│   ────────────                                                               │
│   Hum MERGE nahi karenge! Instead, hum ye dhundhenge:                        │
│   "Left half mein kitne elements honge?" — Binary search se!                 │
│                                                                              │
│   CONCEPT:                                                                   │
│   ─────────                                                                  │
│   Total elements = m + n                                                     │
│   Left half size = (m + n + 1) // 2                                         │
│                                                                              │
│   Agar nums1 se 'cut1' elements liye, to nums2 se 'cut2' lenge:             │
│   cut2 = leftHalfSize - cut1                                                │
│                                                                              │
│   PARTITION VISUALIZATION:                                                   │
│   ────────────────────────                                                   │
│                                                                              │
│   nums1:    [1, 3, | 8, 9]        cut1 = 2                                  │
│                    ↑                                                         │
│   nums2:    [2, 4, 5, | 7]        cut2 = 3                                  │
│                        ↑                                                     │
│                                                                              │
│   Left Half:  {1, 3, 2, 4, 5}    (elements before cuts)                     │
│   Right Half: {8, 9, 7}          (elements after cuts)                      │
│                                                                              │
│   VALID PARTITION CHECK:                                                     │
│   ──────────────────────                                                     │
│   • L1 <= R2   (nums1 ka left <= nums2 ka right)                            │
│   • L2 <= R1   (nums2 ka left <= nums1 ka right)                            │
│                                                                              │
│   If L1 > R2: cut1 badha diya, move left                                    │
│   If L2 > R1: cut1 chota hai, move right                                    │
│                                                                              │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

📊 Dry Run: nums1 = [1, 2], nums2 = [3, 4]

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                        COMPLETE DRY RUN                                       │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                                              │
│   SETUP:                                                                     │
│   nums1 = [1, 2]  (m = 2)                                                   │
│   nums2 = [3, 4]  (n = 2)                                                   │
│   Total = 4 (even), so we need 2 elements in left half                      │
│   leftHalfSize = (2 + 2 + 1) // 2 = 2                                       │
│                                                                              │
│   Binary Search on nums1 (smaller array):                                    │
│   lo = 0, hi = 2                                                            │
│                                                                              │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│   ITERATION 1:                                                               │
│   ─────────────                                                              │
│   cut1 = (0 + 2) // 2 = 1                                                   │
│   cut2 = 2 - 1 = 1                                                          │
│                                                                              │
│   nums1:    [1 | 2]         L1 = 1, R1 = 2                                  │
│   nums2:    [3 | 4]         L2 = 3, R2 = 4                                  │
│                                                                              │
│   Check: L1 <= R2? → 1 <= 4 ✅                                              │
│   Check: L2 <= R1? → 3 <= 2 ❌  (L2 > R1, cut1 chota hai!)                  │
│                                                                              │
│   Move: lo = cut1 + 1 = 2                                                   │
│                                                                              │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│   ITERATION 2:                                                               │
│   ─────────────                                                              │
│   cut1 = (2 + 2) // 2 = 2                                                   │
│   cut2 = 2 - 2 = 0                                                          │
│                                                                              │
│   nums1:    [1, 2 |]        L1 = 2, R1 = +∞                                 │
│   nums2:    [| 3, 4]        L2 = -∞, R2 = 3                                 │
│                                                                              │
│   Check: L1 <= R2? → 2 <= 3 ✅                                              │
│   Check: L2 <= R1? → -∞ <= +∞ ✅                                            │
│                                                                              │
│   VALID PARTITION FOUND! 🎉                                                  │
│                                                                              │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│   CALCULATE MEDIAN:                                                          │
│   ─────────────────                                                          │
│   Total = 4 (even)                                                          │
│   maxLeft = max(L1, L2) = max(2, -∞) = 2                                    │
│   minRight = min(R1, R2) = min(+∞, 3) = 3                                   │
│                                                                              │
│   Median = (maxLeft + minRight) / 2 = (2 + 3) / 2 = 2.5 ✅                  │
│                                                                              │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
Python Binary Search — O(log(min(m,n))) ⭐ 
class Solution:
    def findMedianSortedArrays(self, nums1: List[int], nums2: List[int]) -> float:
        # Always binary search on smaller array for efficiency
        if len(nums1) > len(nums2):
            nums1, nums2 = nums2, nums1
        
        m, n = len(nums1), len(nums2)
        lo, hi = 0, m
        
        # Left half size (handles both odd and even total)
        leftHalfSize = (m + n + 1) // 2
        
        while lo <= hi:
            cut1 = (lo + hi) // 2  # Partition in nums1
            cut2 = leftHalfSize - cut1  # Partition in nums2
            
            # Edge cases: -inf and +inf for boundary conditions
            L1 = float('-inf') if cut1 == 0 else nums1[cut1 - 1]
            R1 = float('inf') if cut1 == m else nums1[cut1]
            L2 = float('-inf') if cut2 == 0 else nums2[cut2 - 1]
            R2 = float('inf') if cut2 == n else nums2[cut2]
            
            # Valid partition check
            if L1 <= R2 and L2 <= R1:
                # Found correct partition!
                if (m + n) % 2 == 1:
                    # Odd total: median is max of left half
                    return max(L1, L2)
                else:
                    # Even total: average of max(left) and min(right)
                    return (max(L1, L2) + min(R1, R2)) / 2
            
            elif L1 > R2:
                # cut1 is too big, move left
                hi = cut1 - 1
            else:
                # cut1 is too small, move right
                lo = cut1 + 1
        
        return 0.0  # Should never reach here

# ✅ Time:  O(log(min(m, n))) — Binary search on smaller array!
# ✅ Space: O(1) — No extra space!
# ✅ Interview: THIS is what they want! 🎯

🤔 Why Binary Search Works Here?

INTUITION:
──────────

Median divides sorted elements into TWO EQUAL HALVES:
  [smaller elements] | [larger elements]

Instead of actually merging, we PARTITION both arrays:

  nums1:  [....L1 | R1....]
  nums2:  [....L2 | R2....]
          ─────────────────
          Left Half | Right Half

For VALID partition:
  • Every element in Left Half < Every element in Right Half
  • This means: L1 <= R2  AND  L2 <= R1

Binary Search Logic:
  • If L1 > R2: We took too many from nums1, shrink cut1
  • If L2 > R1: We took too few from nums1, expand cut1

Once valid partition found:
  • Odd total:  Median = max(L1, L2)
  • Even total: Median = (max(L1,L2) + min(R1,R2)) / 2

👉 Search space: [0, m] (partition points in smaller array)
👉 Binary search brings us to O(log(min(m,n)))! 🚀

🧪 Edge Cases — Interview Mein Zaroor Discuss Karo!

Case Example Handling
One Empty Array [], [1,2,3] cut1=0, all from nums2
Single Element Each [1], [2] Even total, avg = 1.5
Disjoint Arrays [1,2], [5,6] Partition at boundary
All Same Elements [2,2], [2,2] Any partition works
Very Different Sizes [1], [2,3,4,5,6] Search on smaller array

🎤 Interview Strategy — Kaise Approach Karo?

  1. Pehle Brute Force Batao: "I can merge both arrays in O(m+n) and find median..."
  2. Constraint Point Out Karo: "But the problem asks for O(log(m+n)), so I need binary search..."
  3. Key Insight Share Karo: "Instead of merging, I'll find a partition point where left elements ≤ right elements"
  4. Binary Search Explain Karo: "I'll binary search on the smaller array for efficiency"
  5. Edge Cases Discuss Karo: "For boundaries, I use -∞ and +∞ to handle empty partitions"
🔥 Pro Tip: Ye problem FAANG interviews mein bahut common hai! Binary search on answer wala pattern yaad rakhna! 🏆

📊 Complexity Comparison

Approach Time Space Interview?
Merge & Find O(m + n) O(m + n) ❌ Not Optimal
Binary Search Partition O(log(min(m,n))) O(1) ✅ OPTIMAL!
🎯 Final Takeaway: Ye problem Binary Search ka most difficult application hai! Partition concept samajh gaye to Hard problems easy lagenge! 💪
🔗

Linked List

Pointers aur nodes ka game — interview ka favourite topic!

9 problems
🔗 Problem #23

Reverse Linked List

Linked List ko ulta karo — DSA ka Classic Problem! 🔄

🟢 Easy Level

Problem Kya Hai?

Ek singly linked list ka head diya gaya hai. Tumhe list ko reverse karke new head return karna hai.

🎯 Simple Words Mein: List ulti kar do!
📌 1 → 2 → 3 → 4 → 5 ban jaayega 5 → 4 → 3 → 2 → 1
🔄 Har node ka next pointer peeche wale node ki taraf point karega!

Example 1:

head = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

Output: [5, 4, 3, 2, 1]

Example 2:

head = [1, 2]

Output: [2, 1]

Example 3:

head = []

Output: [] — Empty list remains empty!

🎓 Prerequisites: Linked List Kya Hai? (Basics Samjho Pehle!)

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                    SINGLY LINKED LIST                            │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                                  │
│   Array vs Linked List:                                          │
│   ═══════════════════════                                        │
│                                                                  │
│   Array:  [10][20][30][40][50]  ← Continuous memory blocks       │
│            ↑  ↑  ↑  ↑  ↑                                        │
│            0  1  2  3  4  (index se direct access!)              │
│                                                                  │
│   Linked List:                                                   │
│   ┌─────┐    ┌─────┐    ┌─────┐    ┌─────┐    ┌─────┐           │
│   │ 10  │───→│ 20  │───→│ 30  │───→│ 40  │───→│ 50  │───→ NULL  │
│   └─────┘    └─────┘    └─────┘    └─────┘    └─────┘           │
│    HEAD                                         TAIL             │
│                                                                  │
│   Har "box" = NODE                                               │
│   - val: value store karta hai                                   │
│   - next: agla node ka address (pointer)                         │
│                                                                  │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                                  │
│   🔧 Node Structure:                                              │
│   ┌─────────────────┐                                            │
│   │  ListNode       │                                            │
│   ├─────────────────┤                                            │
│   │  val: int       │  ← Data store hota hai                     │
│   │  next: ListNode │  ← Agla node ka address                    │
│   └─────────────────┘                                            │
│                                                                  │
│   Python mein:                                                   │
│   class ListNode:                                                │
│       def __init__(self, val=0, next=None):                      │
│           self.val = val                                         │
│           self.next = next                                       │
│                                                                  │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

🔄 Reverse Karna Matlab Kya?

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                    REVERSING A LINKED LIST                       │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                                  │
│   BEFORE (Original):                                             │
│   ════════════════════                                           │
│       HEAD                                                       │
│        ↓                                                         │
│   ┌─────┐    ┌─────┐    ┌─────┐    ┌─────┐    ┌─────┐           │
│   │  1  │───→│  2  │───→│  3  │───→│  4  │───→│  5  │───→ NULL  │
│   └─────┘    └─────┘    └─────┘    └─────┘    └─────┘           │
│                                                                  │
│   Direction: 1 → 2 → 3 → 4 → 5 → NULL                           │
│                                                                  │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                                  │
│   AFTER (Reversed):                                              │
│   ═══════════════════                                            │
│                                                     NEW HEAD     │
│                                                        ↓         │
│   NULL ←───┌─────┐    ┌─────┐    ┌─────┐    ┌─────┐    ┌─────┐  │
│            │  1  │←───│  2  │←───│  3  │←───│  4  │←───│  5  │  │
│            └─────┘    └─────┘    └─────┘    └─────┘    └─────┘  │
│                                                                  │
│   Direction: NULL ← 1 ← 2 ← 3 ← 4 ← 5 (New Head = 5)            │
│                                                                  │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                                  │
│   🎯 KEY OBSERVATION:                                             │
│   • Har node ka 'next' pointer peeche wale node ko point karega  │
│   • Jo pehle HEAD tha (1), wo ab TAIL ban gaya                   │
│   • Jo pehle TAIL tha (5), wo ab HEAD ban gaya                   │
│   • Values same hain, sirf ARROWS (pointers) palat gaye!         │
│                                                                  │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
1

Recursion Approach

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Recursion ka logic hai: "Baaki list reverse kar, phir current node fix kar!" 🔄

Step-by-step sochne ka tarika:

  • Jab tum recursively list ke end tak jaate ho, last node new head ban jaata hai
  • Jab recursion unwind hota hai (wapas aata hai), har node apne aage wale node ko apni taraf point karwa deta hai
  • Finally, original head ka next NULL set karo — taaki cycle na bane!
💭 Analogy: Train ke dabbe imagine karo. Recursion mein pehle last dabbe tak jaate ho, phir wapas aate waqt har dabbe ka connection ulta kar dete ho! 🚂

🔄 Recursion Flow Visualized

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│               RECURSION: "Reverse the rest, then fix me!"        │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                                  │
│   List: 1 → 2 → 3 → NULL                                         │
│                                                                  │
│   ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════    │
│   📍 GOING DOWN (Recursive calls):                               │
│   ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════    │
│                                                                  │
│   Call 1: reverseList(1)                                         │
│           head = 1, head.next = 2 (not null)                     │
│           → Call reverseList(2)                                  │
│                                                                  │
│   Call 2: reverseList(2)                                         │
│           head = 2, head.next = 3 (not null)                     │
│           → Call reverseList(3)                                  │
│                                                                  │
│   Call 3: reverseList(3)                                         │
│           head = 3, head.next = NULL ✅                           │
│           → BASE CASE! Return 3 as newHead                       │
│                                                                  │
│   ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════    │
│   📍 COMING BACK UP (Unwinding + Fixing pointers):               │
│   ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════    │
│                                                                  │
│   Back to Call 2: (head = 2, newHead = 3)                        │
│           head.next.next = head  →  3.next = 2                   │
│           head.next = NULL       →  2.next = NULL                │
│                                                                  │
│           Before: 2 → 3 → NULL                                   │
│           After:  2 ← 3          (3 → 2, 2 → NULL)               │
│           Return newHead (3)                                     │
│                                                                  │
│   Back to Call 1: (head = 1, newHead = 3)                        │
│           head.next.next = head  →  2.next = 1                   │
│           head.next = NULL       →  1.next = NULL                │
│                                                                  │
│           Before: 1 → 2   (and 3 → 2)                            │
│           After:  1 ← 2 ← 3      (2 → 1, 1 → NULL)               │
│           Return newHead (3)                                     │
│                                                                  │
│   ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════    │
│   FINAL RESULT:                                                  │
│   NULL ← 1 ← 2 ← 3   (Head = 3)                                  │
│   ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════    │
│                                                                  │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Algorithm Steps

1
Base Case: Agar list empty hai (head == null) toh null return karo
2
Recursive Call: head.next pe function call karo — baaki list reverse ho jaayegi
3
Fix Pointer: head.next.next = head — agla node ab peeche point karega
4
Break Cycle: head.next = null — cycle avoid karo!
5
Return: newHead return karo — jo deepest call se mila

Python Code

# ============================================
# 🔄 RECURSION: Reverse Linked List
# ============================================
# "Baaki list reverse kar, phir current node fix kar!"
# Call stack naturally pointers ko reverse karne mein help karta hai
#
# 💡 Key Insight:
# Recursion mein pehle end tak jaate ho,
# Phir wapas aate waqt har node ka pointer flip karte ho!

# Definition for singly-linked list.
class ListNode:
    def __init__(self, val=0, next=None):
        self.val = val
        self.next = next

class Solution:
    def reverseList(self, head):
        """
        Recursive Approach to Reverse Linked List
        
        🎯 Logic:
        1. Base case: Empty list ya single node → return as is
        2. Recursively reverse the rest of the list
        3. While unwinding, flip the pointers
        4. Set original head's next to None (avoid cycle!)
        
        Time: O(n) — Har node ek baar visit hoti hai
        Space: O(n) — Recursion call stack (n calls)
        """
        
        # ========================================
        # 📍 BASE CASE: Empty list
        # ========================================
        if not head:
            return None
        
        # 🎯 newHead initially current head hai
        # Agar koi next nahi hai, yahi final answer hai
        newHead = head
        
        # ========================================
        # 📍 RECURSIVE CASE: List mein aur nodes hain
        # ========================================
        if head.next:
            # 🔄 Recursively baaki list reverse karo
            # newHead = reversed list ka head (last node of original)
            newHead = self.reverseList(head.next)
            
            # ========================================
            # 📍 FIX POINTER (Magic happens here!)
            # ========================================
            # head.next = agla node (jo pehle se point ho raha hai)
            # head.next.next = us agle node ka next
            # 
            # BEFORE: head → head.next → ???
            # AFTER:  head ← head.next (next now points back!)
            head.next.next = head
        
        # ========================================
        # 📍 BREAK THE CYCLE
        # ========================================
        # Original head ab tail ban gaya, iska next NULL hona chahiye
        # Agar ye nahi karoge → cycle ban jaayega!
        head.next = None
        
        # ✅ Return the new head (jo deepest call se mila)
        return newHead


# 🧪 Testing Helper Functions
def create_linked_list(arr):
    """Array se Linked List banao"""
    if not arr:
        return None
    head = ListNode(arr[0])
    current = head
    for val in arr[1:]:
        current.next = ListNode(val)
        current = current.next
    return head

def linked_list_to_array(head):
    """Linked List se Array banao"""
    result = []
    while head:
        result.append(head.val)
        head = head.next
    return result

# 🧪 Test Cases
sol = Solution()

# Test 1: Normal list
head1 = create_linked_list([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
result1 = sol.reverseList(head1)
print(linked_list_to_array(result1))  # Output: [5, 4, 3, 2, 1] ✅

# Test 2: Two nodes
head2 = create_linked_list([1, 2])
result2 = sol.reverseList(head2)
print(linked_list_to_array(result2))  # Output: [2, 1] ✅

# Test 3: Empty list
head3 = create_linked_list([])
result3 = sol.reverseList(head3)
print(linked_list_to_array(result3))  # Output: [] ✅

# Test 4: Single node
head4 = create_linked_list([1])
result4 = sol.reverseList(head4)
print(linked_list_to_array(result4))  # Output: [1] ✅

Dry Run Example

Input: head = [1, 2, 3]

Callhead.valhead.nextActionReturn
11→2Call reverseList(2)-
22→3Call reverseList(3)-
33NULLBASE CASE!3
2↑2→33.next=2, 2.next=NULL3
1↑1→22.next=1, 1.next=NULL3

Final: 3 → 2 → 1 → NULL, newHead = 3 ✅

⏱️ Time: O(n)
💾 Space: O(n) — Call stack!
⚠️ Space O(n) Kyun? Recursion mein har node ke liye ek function call stack pe jaati hai. n nodes = n calls = O(n) stack space. Iterative approach mein ye nahi hoga! 👇
2

Iteration Approach ✨ OPTIMAL

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Linked list ko iteratively reverse karna matlab ek-ek karke pointers flip karna! 🔄

Hum list mein left se right traverse karte hain, aur har node ka next pointer peeche wale node ki taraf point kara dete hain.

3 Pointers rakhne padte hain taaki list kho na jaaye:

  • curr → Current node jisko hum process kar rahe hain
  • prev → Previous node (jo reverse hone ke baad curr ke aage aayega)
  • temp → Next node ka reference (taaki chain na toote!)
💭 Analogy: Imagine karo tum ek line mein khade logon ko ulta karwa rahe ho. Har aadmi ko bolo "peeche dekho!" — lekin pehle uske aage wale ka address yaad rakho, nahi toh wo kho jaayega! 🧑‍🤝‍🧑

🔄 Iteration Flow Visualized (Step-by-Step)

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│            ITERATION: Flip Pointers One by One                   │
├──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                                  │
│   Initial State:                                                 │
│   ══════════════                                                 │
│   prev = NULL                                                    │
│   curr = 1 → 2 → 3 → NULL                                        │
│                                                                  │
│   ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  │
│   📍 ITERATION 1: (curr = 1)                                     │
│   ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  │
│                                                                  │
│   Step 1: temp = curr.next        →  temp = 2                    │
│           (Agle node ka reference save karo!)                    │
│                                                                  │
│   Step 2: curr.next = prev        →  1.next = NULL               │
│           (Pointer flip! Ab 1 peeche point karta hai)            │
│                                                                  │
│   Step 3: prev = curr             →  prev = 1                    │
│           (prev aage badha do)                                   │
│                                                                  │
│   Step 4: curr = temp             →  curr = 2                    │
│           (curr aage badha do)                                   │
│                                                                  │
│   State After:                                                   │
│   NULL ← 1   2 → 3 → NULL                                        │
│          ↑   ↑                                                   │
│        prev curr                                                 │
│                                                                  │
│   ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  │
│   📍 ITERATION 2: (curr = 2)                                     │
│   ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  │
│                                                                  │
│   Step 1: temp = curr.next        →  temp = 3                    │
│   Step 2: curr.next = prev        →  2.next = 1                  │
│   Step 3: prev = curr             →  prev = 2                    │
│   Step 4: curr = temp             →  curr = 3                    │
│                                                                  │
│   State After:                                                   │
│   NULL ← 1 ← 2   3 → NULL                                        │
│              ↑   ↑                                               │
│            prev curr                                             │
│                                                                  │
│   ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  │
│   📍 ITERATION 3: (curr = 3)                                     │
│   ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  │
│                                                                  │
│   Step 1: temp = curr.next        →  temp = NULL                 │
│   Step 2: curr.next = prev        →  3.next = 2                  │
│   Step 3: prev = curr             →  prev = 3                    │
│   Step 4: curr = temp             →  curr = NULL                 │
│                                                                  │
│   State After:                                                   │
│   NULL ← 1 ← 2 ← 3   NULL                                        │
│                  ↑    ↑                                          │
│                prev  curr                                        │
│                                                                  │
│   ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  │
│   📍 LOOP ENDS: curr = NULL                                      │
│   ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  │
│                                                                  │
│   🎉 FINAL RESULT:                                                │
│   Return prev = 3 (new head!)                                    │
│                                                                  │
│   NULL ← 1 ← 2 ← 3                                               │
│                  ↑                                               │
│              NEW HEAD                                            │
│                                                                  │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Algorithm Steps

1
Initialize: prev = null, curr = head
2
While curr exists:
3
Save next: temp = curr.next (taaki chain na toote!)
4
Flip pointer: curr.next = prev (pointer ulta karo!)
5
Move prev: prev = curr
6
Move curr: curr = temp
7
Return: prev — ye naya head hai!

Python Code

# ============================================
# ✨ ITERATION: Reverse Linked List (OPTIMAL)
# ============================================
# Ek-ek karke pointers flip karo — left to right traverse!
# 
# 💡 Key Insight:
# 3 pointers use karo:
# - prev: peeche wala node (jo reverse ke baad aage aayega)
# - curr: current node jisko process kar rahe ho
# - temp: agle node ka backup (taaki lose na ho!)

# Definition for singly-linked list.
class ListNode:
    def __init__(self, val=0, next=None):
        self.val = val
        self.next = next

class Solution:
    def reverseList(self, head):
        """
        Iterative Approach to Reverse Linked List
        
        🎯 Logic:
        1. Initialize prev = None, curr = head
        2. While curr is not None:
           - Save next node (temp = curr.next)
           - Flip pointer (curr.next = prev)
           - Move prev forward (prev = curr)
           - Move curr forward (curr = temp)
        3. Return prev (new head)
        
        Time: O(n) — Single pass through the list
        Space: O(1) — Only using 3 pointers!
        """
        
        # ========================================
        # 📍 INITIALIZE POINTERS
        # ========================================
        prev = None   # Peeche kuch nahi hai initially
        curr = head   # Start from head
        
        # ========================================
        # 📍 ITERATE THROUGH THE LIST
        # ========================================
        while curr:
            # 🔴 Step 1: SAVE next node (CRITICAL!)
            # Agar ye nahi karoge, chain toot jaayegi!
            temp = curr.next
            
            # 🔴 Step 2: FLIP the pointer
            # Current node ab peeche wale ko point karega
            curr.next = prev
            
            # 🔴 Step 3: MOVE prev forward
            # prev ab current node pe aa gaya
            prev = curr
            
            # 🔴 Step 4: MOVE curr forward
            # curr ab agle node pe aa gaya (jo humne save kiya tha)
            curr = temp
        
        # ========================================
        # 📍 RETURN NEW HEAD
        # ========================================
        # Loop khatam hone pe curr = NULL
        # prev = last node = new head!
        return prev


# 🧪 Testing Helper Functions
def create_linked_list(arr):
    """Array se Linked List banao"""
    if not arr:
        return None
