│   1️⃣  FINAL CARRY BHOOL GAYE                                                │
│       ──────────────────────────                                             │
│       ❌ while l1 or l2:           # WRONG! Last carry miss!                │
│       ✅ while l1 or l2 or carry:  # CORRECT!                               │
│                                                                              │
│       Example: 99 + 1 = 100                                                 │
│       Without carry check: 99 + 01 = 00 (WRONG!)                            │
│       With carry check: 99 + 01 = 001 → 100 ✅                              │
│                                                                              │
│   2️⃣  NULL CHECK BHOOL GAYE                                                 │
│       ──────────────────────────                                             │
│       ❌ val1 = l1.val             # Crashes if l1 is NULL!                 │
│       ✅ val1 = l1.val if l1 else 0                                         │
│                                                                              │
│   3️⃣  POINTER ADVANCE BHOOL GAYE                                            │
│       ──────────────────────────                                             │
│       ❌ Forgot to do l1 = l1.next # Infinite loop!                         │
│       ✅ if l1: l1 = l1.next                                                │
│                                                                              │
│   4️⃣  DUMMY.NEXT RETURN NAHI KIYA                                           │
│       ──────────────────────────                                             │
│       ❌ return dummy              # Returns fake 0 node!                   │
│       ✅ return dummy.next         # Skip the dummy!                        │
│                                                                              │
│   5️⃣  CARRY CALCULATION GALAT                                               │
│       ──────────────────────────                                             │
│       ❌ carry = total / 10        # Python 3 gives float!                  │
│       ✅ carry = total // 10       # Integer division!                      │
│                                                                              │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

🧪 Edge Cases — Interview Mein Puchenge!

Case Example Handle Kaise?
Different Lengths [1,2,3] + [4,5] Short list ke baad 0 treat karo
Final Carry [9,9] + [1] = [0,0,1] while ... or carry
Single Node [5] + [5] = [0,1] Same logic works! ✅
Zeros [0] + [0] = [0] Same logic works! ✅
All 9s [9,9,9] + [9,9,9] Multiple carries, final carry too!

🎤 Interview Mein Kaise Explain Karega?

"This problem is essentially elementary addition that we learned in school.
The key insight is that digits are stored in reverse order, which actually makes it easier — we can traverse left-to-right and add from the ones place.

I use a dummy node to simplify list building, track the carry at each step, and continue until both lists are exhausted AND no carry remains."

🔥 Pro Tip: Mention that reversed order is actually a hint that makes the problem easier!

📊 Complexity Summary

Aspect Value Explanation
Time Complexity O(max(m, n)) Traverse both lists once
Space Complexity O(max(m, n)) New list has max(m,n)+1 nodes
LeetCode Runtime 0 ms Beats 100%! 🚀
🎯 Final Takeaway: Elementary math + Linked List traversal + Dummy node = Clean solution! Ye problem easy hai agar concept clear ho! 💯
29
🎯 Pattern 93: Design - HashMap + DLL

LRU Cache

Least Recently Used Cache — HashMap + Doubly Linked List ka Magic! 🗃️

Medium Linked List Hash Table Design

📋 Problem Statement

Ek LRU (Least Recently Used) Cache design karo jo O(1) average time mein get aur put operations support kare.

Operations:
LRUCache(capacity) — Cache ko given capacity ke saath initialize karo
get(key) — Key ki value return karo (agar nahi hai toh -1)
put(key, value) — Key-value insert/update karo. Agar capacity exceed ho toh least recently used ko evict karo!
Example:
LRUCache cache = new LRUCache(2);
cache.put(1, 1); // cache: {1=1}
cache.put(2, 2); // cache: {1=1, 2=2}
cache.get(1); // returns 1, cache: {2=2, 1=1} (1 most recent)
cache.put(3, 3); // evicts key 2, cache: {1=1, 3=3}
cache.get(2); // returns -1 (not found)

🧠 LRU Concept — Pehle Ye Samjho!

LRU (Least Recently Used) ka matlab kya hai?

  • Cache mein limited slots hote hain (capacity = C)
  • Jo item abhi-abhi use hua (get/put) → Most Recently Used (MRU)
  • Jo item bahut time se use nahi hua → Least Recently Used (LRU)
  • Jab naya item add karna ho aur cache FULL ho → LRU ko evict (nikaalo)!
💡 Real Life Example: Browser tabs! Agar tumhari memory full ho jaaye, toh jo tab tumne sabse purana access kiya wo close ho jaata hai. Recently use kiye gaye tabs safe rehte hain!
WHY HASHMAP + DOUBLY LINKED LIST?
❌ PROBLEM
Only List
get(key) = O(n) 👎
Only HashMap
Recency track kaise? 🤔
✅ SOLUTION — Combine Both!
HashMap
O(1) access
↔
DLL
Recency maintain
📐

Data Structure Design — Internally Kya Store Hoga?

1️⃣ Node Structure

Har cache entry ek Doubly Linked List Node hogi:

NODE STRUCTURE
Previous Node
→
NODE
key
val
prev
next
→
Next Node
⚠️ Important: Node mein key store karna mat bhoolna! Eviction ke time HashMap se delete karne ke liye key chahiye!

2️⃣ HashMap

map[key] = node → O(1) mein node access!

3️⃣ Doubly Linked List with Dummy Head/Tail

DLL STRUCTURE
DUMMY
HEAD
↔
Most Recent
🎯 MRU
↔
...
↔
Least Recent
⚠️ LRU
↔
DUMMY
TAIL
💡 Dummy Nodes Ka Faayda:
• Empty list, single node list, head/tail update... in sab edge cases ka jhanjhat kam!
• Head ke baad = Most Recently Used
• Tail ke pehle = Least Recently Used (evict ye hoga!)
⚡

Operations Ka Logic — LRU Rules!

✅ get(key) Operation

GET OPERATION FLOW
1
get(key)
↓
?
key in map?
No →
return -1
Yes ↓
node = map[key]
↓
Move node to FRONT
↓
return node.val
🔥 Why Move to Front? Kyunki abhi use hua hai! Access karna matlab ye item "recently used" ban gaya!

✅ put(key, value) Operation

PUT OPERATION FLOW
1
put(key, value)
↓
?
key in map?
Yes → KEY EXISTS
node = map[key]
node.val = value
Move to FRONT
No → NEW KEY
Create new node
Add to FRONT
map[key] = node
size > capacity?
Yes → EVICT LRU!
🎬

Visual Example — Step by Step!

Capacity = 2

LRU CACHE OPERATIONS - Capacity = 2
1
put(1, 10)
HEAD
↔
1,10
↔
TAIL
2
put(2, 20)
HEAD
↔
2,20 MRU
↔
1,10 LRU
↔
TAIL
3
get(1) returns 10
HEAD
↔
1,10 MRU
↔
2,20 LRU
↔
TAIL
4
put(3, 30) → EVICT 2!
HEAD
↔
3,30 MRU
↔
1,10
↔
TAIL
5
get(2) returns -1
Key 2 not found! ❌
1

🏆 HashMap + Doubly Linked List (From Scratch!)

Helper Functions

HELPER FUNCTIONS
_remove
get prev, next
↓
link prev to next
_add_to_front
set node pointers
↓
insert after head
_move_to_front
remove
↓
add to front
_pop_lru
get tail.prev
↓
remove it
↓
return lru
Python 🏆 Complete LRU Cache Implementation 
# ============================================
# 🏆 LRU CACHE — HashMap + Doubly Linked List
# ============================================
# Time: O(1) average for get/put
# Space: O(capacity)

class LRUCache:
    
    # 🔲 Node class — DLL ka har node
    class Node:
        __slots__ = ("key", "val", "prev", "next")
        def __init__(self, key=0, val=0):
            self.key = key   # ⚠️ Important for eviction!
            self.val = val
            self.prev = None
            self.next = None

    def __init__(self, capacity: int):
        self.cap = capacity
        self.map = {}  # key → Node

        # 🎭 Dummy head/tail nodes — edge cases easy!
        self.head = self.Node()
        self.tail = self.Node()
        self.head.next = self.tail
        self.tail.prev = self.head

    # ✂️ Remove node from anywhere in DLL
    def _remove(self, node):
        p, n = node.prev, node.next
        p.next = n
        n.prev = p

    # ➕ Add node right after head (MRU position)
    def _add_to_front(self, node):
        node.prev = self.head
        node.next = self.head.next
        self.head.next.prev = node
        self.head.next = node

    # 🔄 Move existing node to front
    def _move_to_front(self, node):
        self._remove(node)
        self._add_to_front(node)

    # 🗑️ Pop LRU node (just before tail)
    def _pop_lru(self):
        lru = self.tail.prev
        self._remove(lru)
        return lru

    # 🔍 GET operation
    def get(self, key: int) -> int:
        if key not in self.map:
            return -1
        
        node = self.map[key]
        # ⚡ Abhi use hua → Most Recent banao!
        self._move_to_front(node)
        return node.val

    # 📝 PUT operation
    def put(self, key: int, value: int) -> None:
        # 🔄 Case 1: Key already exists → Update!
        if key in self.map:
            node = self.map[key]
            node.val = value
            self._move_to_front(node)
            return

        # 🆕 Case 2: New key → Insert!
        node = self.Node(key, value)
        self.map[key] = node
        self._add_to_front(node)

        # ❌ Capacity exceed? → Evict LRU!
        if len(self.map) > self.cap:
            lru = self._pop_lru()
            del self.map[lru.key]  # ⚠️ key stored in node!

Time & Space Complexity

⏱️ get() Time
O(1)
⏱️ put() Time
O(1)
💾 Space
O(capacity)
2

OrderedDict Approach — Short & Interview-Acceptable!

⚠️ Note: Python ka OrderedDict internally same concept use karta hai! Interview mein ye bolo but mention karo ki "from scratch" bhi bana sakte ho! 👆
Python Approach 2: OrderedDict 
# ============================================
# 🔧 LRU CACHE — Using OrderedDict
# ============================================
# Same O(1) complexity, but cleaner code!

from collections import OrderedDict

class LRUCache:
    def __init__(self, capacity: int):
        self.cap = capacity
        self.od = OrderedDict()

    def get(self, key: int) -> int:
        if key not in self.od:
            return -1
        # Move to end (most recent)
        self.od.move_to_end(key, last=False)
        return self.od[key]

    def put(self, key: int, value: int) -> None:
        if key in self.od:
            self.od[key] = value
            self.od.move_to_end(key, last=False)
        else:
            self.od[key] = value
            self.od.move_to_end(key, last=False)
            if len(self.od) > self.cap:
                # Pop least recent (last=True)
                self.od.popitem(last=True)

⚠️ Common Pitfalls — Interview Mein Mat Karo!

  1. Node mein key store nahi kiya:
    ❌ Eviction ke time del map[???] — key nahi pata!
    ✅ Node mein key store karo: del map[lru.key]
  2. get() mein move-to-front bhool gaye:
    ❌ Access kiya but front pe nahi laye → LRU galat calculate hoga!
    ✅ Har access pe _move_to_front(node) zaroor karo!
  3. put(existing) mein update + move bhool gaye:
    ❌ Value update ki but position same → Recency galat!
    ✅ Update + Move both karo!
  4. Dummy nodes nahi use kiye:
    ❌ Edge cases (empty list, single node) mein crash!
    ✅ Dummy head/tail use karo — life easy!

📊 Approach Comparison

Approach get() put() Space Notes
HashMap + DLL ⭐ O(1) O(1) O(cap) From scratch! Interview mein preferred!
OrderedDict O(1) O(1) O(cap) Clean, but mention "from scratch" bhi aata hai!
🎯 Interview Tip: Pehle Approach 1 (HashMap + DLL) explain karo! Ye dikhata hai ki tum data structures properly samjhte ho! 💯

30. LFU Cache

Least Frequently Used Cache — Frequency-Based Eviction! 📊

📋 Problem Statement

LFU Cache design karo jo following operations O(1) average time mein kare:

  • LFUCache(capacity) - Cache initialize karo given capacity ke saath
  • get(key) - Key ka value return karo, nahi hai to -1
  • put(key, value) - Key-value insert/update karo

Eviction Rule (Important!):

  1. Least Frequently Used item pehle nikalo
  2. Agar frequency same ho → LRU within that frequency (oldest wala nikalo)
🔥 Hard Problem — Amazon, Google, Facebook ka favorite! Frequency + Recency dono track karna padta hai!

🧠 LFU ka Matlab Samjho (Intuition)

LRU vs LFU — Kya Difference Hai?

Aspect LRU Cache LFU Cache
Eviction Based On Recency (kitni der se access nahi hua) Frequency (kitni baar access hua)
Track Karte Hain Last access time Access count + recency (tie-breaker)
Example Recent = Safe Zyada used = Safe
🎯 Simple Analogy:
Socho tumhare paas limited shelf space hai:
• LRU: "Ye book bahut din se nahi padhi, hatao!" (recency)
• LFU: "Ye book sirf 1 baar padhi, hatao!" (frequency)
LFU Eviction Example
Key A - used 10 times
↓
✅ SAFE - High Frequency
Key B - used 1 time
↓
❌ EVICTED - Low Frequency
Even if B is more recent, A wins because frequency matters more!

❌ Brute Force Kyu Fail Hota Hai?

Naive Approach Problems

Agar har get() pe:

  • Sab keys ki frequency scan karo
  • Minimum frequency nikalo
  • Phir LRU decide karo (tie-breaker)

❌ Ye sab O(n) ho jaata — Interview reject!

🏗️ O(1) Design — Industry Standard

💡 Core Idea (Samjho Carefully!)

"Har frequency ka apna LRU list hota hai!"

Matlab frequency 1 ke saare keys ek list mein, frequency 2 ke alag, frequency 3 ke alag...

📦 Data Structures Breakdown

Three Key Data Structures
1. key_to_node
HashMap: key → Node
2. freq_to_dll
HashMap: freq → DLL
3. min_freq
Integer: smallest frequency
Data Structures 
# 1. key_to_node: Direct access to node
key_to_node = {
    10: Node(key=10, val=100, freq=3),
    20: Node(key=20, val=200, freq=1)
}

# 2. freq_to_dll: Frequency buckets
#    Each bucket is a DLL (LRU list)
freq_to_dll = {
    1: DLL containing [20],     # freq=1 wale keys
    3: DLL containing [10]      # freq=3 wale keys
}

# 3. min_freq: Eviction ke liye
min_freq = 1  # Sabse chhoti frequency

🔹 Node Structure

LFU Node Structure
key
value
freq
prev
next
🎯 LRU se difference: LFU Node mein freq field extra hai! Ye track karta hai kitni baar access hua.

📊 Frequency Buckets — Visual

LFU Cache State
Frequency = 1 ← min_freq
dummy head
→
key:30
→
dummy tail
Frequency = 2
dummy head
→
key:20
→
key:40
→
dummy tail
Frequency = 3
dummy head
→
key:10
→
dummy tail
🎯 Important Points:
• Har frequency ka apna DLL (LRU list)
• DLL mein front = most recent, tail = least recent
• min_freq directly points to eviction bucket!

⚠️ Golden Rule — Yaad Rakho!

🏆 Every Access = Frequency Increase

Har get() ya existing key pe put() = frequency badho!

  1. Node ko old freq DLL se hatao
  2. freq += 1
  3. New freq DLL mein front pe daalo
  4. Agar old freq empty ho gaya AND wahi min_freq tha → min_freq++

🔧 _touch(node) — Sabse Important Function!

Ye function har access pe call hota hai — frequency update + recency maintain!

_touch(node) Flow
1
_touch(node) called
↓
1
Old freq list se node hatao
↓
?
Old freq == min_freq AND list empty?
Yes →
min_freq++
No →
Skip
↓
3
node.freq += 1
↓
4
New freq DLL mein add_front
↓
5
Done - Freq updated + Recency maintained ✅
_touch() Logic 
def _touch(self, node):
    # Step 1: Old frequency list se hatao
    old_freq = node.freq
    self.freq_to_dll[old_freq].remove(node)
    
    # Step 2: Check if we need to update min_freq
    if old_freq == self.min_freq and self.freq_to_dll[old_freq].empty():
        self.min_freq += 1  # Old bucket empty, move to next
    
    # Step 3: Frequency increase
    node.freq += 1
    new_freq = node.freq
    
    # Step 4: Add to new frequency bucket (front = most recent)
    if new_freq not in self.freq_to_dll:
        self.freq_to_dll[new_freq] = DLL()
    self.freq_to_dll[new_freq].add_front(node)

📖 GET Operation Flow

GET Operation Flow
1
get(key)
↓
?
key in cache?
No → return -1
Yes ↓
↓
3
_touch(node) - freq++
↓
4
return node.value

✏️ PUT Operation Flow

PUT Operation Flow
1
put(key, value)
↓
?
capacity == 0? → return (no-op)
↓
?
key exists?
Yes
Update value
_touch(node)
No
cache full? → EVICT LRU!
Create node (freq=1)
min_freq = 1
Add to freq=1 DLL
↓
!
Done ✅

✅ Approach A: HashMap + Frequency DLLs (Optimal)

O(1) — Interview Standard
⏱️ Time: O(1) avg 💾 Space: O(capacity)
🐍 Python 
class LFUCache:
    """
    LFU Cache - O(1) average time for get() and put()
    Using HashMap + Frequency Buckets (each bucket is a DLL)
    """
    
    class Node:
        """Node for DLL - stores key, value, and frequency"""
        __slots__ = ("key", "val", "freq", "prev", "next")
        
        def __init__(self, key, val):
            self.key = key
            self.val = val
            self.freq = 1  # New nodes start with freq=1
            self.prev = None
            self.next = None
    
    class DLL:
        """Doubly Linked List for LRU within each frequency"""
        
        def __init__(self):
            # Dummy head and tail for easy operations
            self.head = LFUCache.Node(None, None)
            self.tail = LFUCache.Node(None, None)
            self.head.next = self.tail
            self.tail.prev = self.head
            self.size = 0
        
        def add_front(self, node):
            """Add node right after head (most recent position)"""
            node.prev = self.head
            node.next = self.head.next
            self.head.next.prev = node
            self.head.next = node
            self.size += 1
        
        def remove(self, node):
            """Remove a specific node from DLL"""
            node.prev.next = node.next
            node.next.prev = node.prev
            self.size -= 1
        
        def pop_lru(self):
            """Remove and return LRU node (just before tail)"""
            if self.size == 0:
                return None
            node = self.tail.prev  # LRU is at tail
            self.remove(node)
            return node
        
        def empty(self):
            """Check if DLL is empty"""
            return self.size == 0
    
    def __init__(self, capacity: int):
        self.cap = capacity
        self.key_to_node = {}      # key -> Node
        self.freq_to_dll = {}      # freq -> DLL
        self.min_freq = 0          # Smallest frequency in cache
    
    def _touch(self, node):
        """
        Update frequency of node - THE CORE FUNCTION!
        Called on every get() and existing key put()
        """
        # Step 1: Remove from old frequency bucket
        old_freq = node.freq
        self.freq_to_dll[old_freq].remove(node)
        
        # Step 2: Update min_freq if needed
        if old_freq == self.min_freq and self.freq_to_dll[old_freq].empty():
            self.min_freq += 1
        
        # Step 3: Increment frequency
        node.freq += 1
        new_freq = node.freq
        
        # Step 4: Add to new frequency bucket
        if new_freq not in self.freq_to_dll:
            self.freq_to_dll[new_freq] = self.DLL()
        self.freq_to_dll[new_freq].add_front(node)
    
    def get(self, key: int) -> int:
        """Get value by key, return -1 if not found"""
        if key not in self.key_to_node:
            return -1
        
        node = self.key_to_node[key]
        self._touch(node)  # Increase frequency!
        return node.val
    
    def put(self, key: int, value: int) -> None:
        """Insert or update key-value pair"""
        if self.cap == 0:
            return
        
        # Case 1: Key exists - update value and frequency
        if key in self.key_to_node:
            node = self.key_to_node[key]
            node.val = value
            self._touch(node)
            return
        
        # Case 2: New key - check capacity first
        if len(self.key_to_node) >= self.cap:
            # Evict LFU (from min_freq bucket's tail)
            dll = self.freq_to_dll[self.min_freq]
            evict = dll.pop_lru()
            del self.key_to_node[evict.key]
        
        # Insert new node
        node = self.Node(key, value)
        self.key_to_node[key] = node
        
        # New nodes always have freq=1
        self.min_freq = 1
        if 1 not in self.freq_to_dll:
            self.freq_to_dll[1] = self.DLL()
        self.freq_to_dll[1].add_front(node)

🔄 Dry Run Example

Step-by-Step 
# Capacity = 2

put(1, 10)  # cache: {1:10}, freq_to_dll: {1: [1]}
            # min_freq = 1

put(2, 20)  # cache: {1:10, 2:20}, freq_to_dll: {1: [2,1]}
            # min_freq = 1

get(1)      # freq(1) = 2, move 1 from freq=1 to freq=2
            # freq_to_dll: {1: [2], 2: [1]}
            # min_freq = 1 (freq=1 bucket not empty)

put(3, 30)  # capacity full! Evict from min_freq=1
            # Key 2 evicted (LRU in freq=1)
            # Insert key 3 with freq=1
            # freq_to_dll: {1: [3], 2: [1]}
            # min_freq = 1

# Final cache: {1:10, 3:30}
# Key 2 was evicted because:
# - Key 1 had freq=2
# - Key 2 had freq=1 (least frequently used)

📦 Approach B: Heap / Priority Queue

O(log n) — Sub-optimal

⚠️ Important Disclaimer

  • Simpler to implement
  • But NOT strict O(1) — O(log n)
  • Interview mein: "Acceptable but sub-optimal"
⏱️ Time: O(log n) 💾 Space: O(n) + stale entries

💡 Core Idea

Har key ke saath 3 cheezein track karo:

  1. frequency — kitni baar access hui
  2. time / counter — recency tie-breaker
  3. key

Heap mein store: (freq, time, key)
Python ka heapq = min-heap, so pehle lowest freq, phir oldest time!

⚠️ Major Problem: Heap Update

Python heap update support nahi karta!

So jab frequency badhti hai:

  • Hum new entry push kar dete hain
  • Old heap entry stale ho jaati hai

Solution → Lazy Deletion:

Eviction ke time: pop karo, check karo valid hai ya nahi, nahi to ignore & pop next!

🐍 Python 
import heapq

class LFUCache:
    """
    LFU Cache - Heap-based approach
    O(log n) time, simpler but sub-optimal
    Uses lazy deletion for stale entries
    """
    
    def __init__(self, capacity: int):
        self.cap = capacity
        self.time = 0                  # Global timestamp
        self.heap = []                 # (freq, time, key)
        self.key_to_val_freq = {}      # key -> [value, freq]
    
    def get(self, key: int) -> int:
        if key not in self.key_to_val_freq:
            return -1
        
        self.time += 1
        val, freq = self.key_to_val_freq[key]
        
        # Increase frequency
        freq += 1
        self.key_to_val_freq[key] = [val, freq]
        
        # Push new entry (old one becomes stale)
        heapq.heappush(self.heap, (freq, self.time, key))
        
        return val
    
    def put(self, key: int, value: int) -> None:
        if self.cap == 0:
            return
        
        self.time += 1
        
        # Case 1: Key exists - update
        if key in self.key_to_val_freq:
            _, freq = self.key_to_val_freq[key]
            freq += 1
            self.key_to_val_freq[key] = [value, freq]
            heapq.heappush(self.heap, (freq, self.time, key))
            return
        
        # Case 2: New key - check capacity
        if len(self.key_to_val_freq) >= self.cap:
            # Evict LFU using lazy deletion
            while self.heap:
                freq, t, k = heapq.heappop(self.heap)
                
                # Check if this entry is still valid
                if k in self.key_to_val_freq:
                    cur_val, cur_freq = self.key_to_val_freq[k]
                    
                    # Valid only if freq matches current freq
                    if cur_freq == freq:
                        del self.key_to_val_freq[k]
                        break
                    # Else: stale entry, skip and pop next
        
        # Insert new key
        self.key_to_val_freq[key] = [value, 1]
        heapq.heappush(self.heap, (1, self.time, key))

🔄 Dry Run (Quick)

Execution 
# Capacity = 2

put(1, 10)  # heap: [(1, 1, 1)], map: {1: [10, 1]}
put(2, 20)  # heap: [(1, 1, 1), (1, 2, 2)], map: {1: [10, 1], 2: [20, 1]}

get(1)      # freq(1) = 2
            # heap: [(1, 1, 1), (1, 2, 2), (2, 3, 1)]  # old entry stale
            # map: {1: [10, 2], 2: [20, 1]}

put(3, 30)  # capacity full! Pop from heap:
            # Pop (1, 1, 1) - stale! (current freq of key 1 is 2)
            # Pop (1, 2, 2) - valid! freq matches, evict key 2
            # Insert key 3
            # Final: map: {1: [10, 2], 3: [30, 1]}

⏱️ Complexity Reality Check

Operation Approach A (Freq DLL) Approach B (Heap)
get() O(1) O(log n)
put() O(1) O(log n)
Space O(capacity) O(n) + stale
Stale Entries No Yes
⚠️ Heap Warning: Heap can grow beyond capacity because of stale entries!

⚖️ Approach Comparison — Interview Ready!

Feature Approach A (Freq DLL) ⭐ Approach B (Heap)
Time Complexity O(1) strict O(log n)
Code Complexity Complex Simple
Stale Entries No Yes
Interview Score ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ ⭐⭐⭐
Real Systems Redis-like Rare

🎯 When to Use Heap Approach?

  • Quick implementation needed
  • Low constraints / small data
  • Interviewer says: "O(log n) is fine"
  • Whiteboard round with limited time

🆚 LRU vs LFU — Complete Comparison

Aspect LRU Cache LFU Cache
Eviction Logic Least Recently Used Least Frequently Used
Track Kya Karte Hain Recency (last access time) Frequency + Recency (tie-breaker)
Data Structures HashMap + 1 DLL HashMap + Multiple DLLs (per freq)
Extra Tracking - min_freq variable
Complexity Simpler More complex
Use Case Browser cache, OS page cache CDN, Database query cache
LRU Cache
HashMap + 1 DLL
Evict: Tail of DLL
LFU Cache
HashMap + N DLLs (by freq)
Evict: Tail of min_freq DLL

✨ Interview Gold Points

🔥 Key Points to Remember

  • LFU = Frequency Buckets + LRU inside each bucket
  • min_freq is mandatory for O(1) eviction
  • Every access = frequency increase
  • Eviction always from min_freq bucket's tail
  • DLL needed to break frequency ties (LRU within same freq)
  • New nodes always start with freq=1, so min_freq=1 after insert
🎯 One-liner Takeaway (Reel / Interview):

"LFU Cache is HashMap + Frequency Buckets, where each bucket is an LRU list, and min_freq tells you exactly whom to evict in O(1)."

⚠️ Common Pitfalls — Interview Mein Mat Karo!

  1. min_freq update bhool gaye:
    ❌ Old freq bucket empty hua but min_freq same → Wrong eviction!
    ✅ Jab old freq bucket empty ho AND wahi min_freq tha → min_freq++
  2. New insert pe min_freq = 1 nahi kiya:
    ❌ New node insert kiya but min_freq purana → Galat eviction!
    ✅ Har new insert pe min_freq = 1 (kyunki new node ki freq=1)
  3. Node mein freq store nahi kiya:
    ❌ _touch() mein old freq nahi pata!
    ✅ Node structure mein freq field rakho
  4. Same key update pe _touch bhool gaye:
    ❌ Value update ki but frequency same → Galat LFU behavior!
    ✅ Existing key pe put() bhi _touch() call karo

📊 Approach Comparison

Approach get() put() Space Notes
HashMap + Freq DLLs ⭐ O(1) O(1) O(cap) Industry standard! Interview mein ye bolo!
Heap / Priority Queue O(log n) O(log n) O(n)+stale Simpler, but sub-optimal with lazy deletion
🎯 Interview Tip: Pehle Approach A (HashMap + Frequency DLLs) explain karo! Ye dikhata hai ki tum complex data structures properly samjhte ho! 💯
🔗 Problem #31

Merge K Sorted Lists

K sorted linked lists ko ek sorted list mein merge karo — Interview ka BOSS Level Problem! 👑

🔴 Hard Level

📋 Problem Statement

Tumhe k sorted linked lists diye gaye hain. Inhe ek sorted linked list mein merge karo aur return karo.

🎯 Real Life Analogy: Socho k alag-alag queues hain, har queue mein log already sorted hain (height wise). Tumhe sabko ek single queue mein laana hai jahan sab sorted rahein! 🧍🧍‍♂️🧍‍♀️

Example 1:

lists = [[1,4,5], [1,3,4], [2,6]]

Output: [1,1,2,3,4,4,5,6]

Three sorted lists merged into one sorted list!

Example 2:

lists = []

Output: []

Example 3:

lists = [[]]

Output: []

🎨 Visual Understanding — K Lists Ko Kaise Merge Kare?

MERGE K SORTED LISTS — Visual Overview
📝 Input: K = 3 Sorted Lists
List 1:
1 → 4 → 5
List 2:
1 → 3 → 4
List 3:
2 → 6
⬇️ MERGE ⬇️
📤 Output: Single Sorted List

1 → 1 → 2 → 3 → 4 → 4 → 5 → 6
🧠 Challenge: Ye karna easy hai — but EFFICIENTLY kaise karein? Brute force O(N log N), but heap se O(N log K) possible hai! 🔥

🎯 Saare Approaches — Brute Force se Optimal Tak!

Approach Time Space Difficulty Interview Value
1. Brute Force (Collect All) O(N log N) O(N) ⭐ ❌ Baseline
2. Iteration (Find Min) O(N × K) O(1) ⭐⭐ ❌ Too slow
3. Merge One by One O(N × K) O(1) ⭐⭐ ⚠️ Suboptimal
4. Heap / Priority Queue ⭐ O(N log K) O(K) ⭐⭐⭐ ✅ Interview Favorite!
5. Divide & Conquer (Recursive) O(N log K) O(log K) stack ⭐⭐⭐⭐ ✅ Shows DS mastery!
6. Divide & Conquer (Iterative) O(N log K) O(1) ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ ✅ Best Space!

📌 Approach 1: Brute Force — Collect All Values

💡 Idea (Sabse Simple)

  1. Saari lists traverse karo, saare values ek array mein collect karo
  2. Array ko sort karo
  3. Sorted array se nayi linked list banao
BRUTE FORCE APPROACH
Step 1: Lists = [1→4→5], [1→3→4], [2→6]
⬇️
Step 2: Collect → [1,4,5,1,3,4,2,6]
⬇️
Step 3: Sort → [1,1,2,3,4,4,5,6]
⬇️
Step 4: Build List → 1→1→2→3→4→4→5→6
Python ❌ Approach 1: Brute Force 
# 🔴 Approach 1: Brute Force — O(N log N)
# Sabse simple but inefficient

class ListNode:
    def __init__(self, val=0, next=None):
        self.val = val
        self.next = next

def mergeKLists(lists):
    # Step 1: Saare values collect karo
    values = []
    for head in lists:
        while head:
            values.append(head.val)
            head = head.next
    
    # Step 2: Sort karo
    values.sort()
    
    # Step 3: Nayi linked list banao
    dummy = ListNode(0)
    curr = dummy
    for val in values:
        curr.next = ListNode(val)
        curr = curr.next
    
    return dummy.next

# ⏱️ Time: O(N log N) — sorting dominates
# 💾 Space: O(N) — storing all values
# ❌ Problem: Lists ki sorted property USE nahi ki!
❌ Why Not Optimal? Ye approach ye fact ignore karti hai ki lists already sorted hain! Hum ye property ka faayda uthana chahte hain! 🎯

📌 Approach 2: Iteration — Har Step Pe Min Find Karo

💡 Idea

  1. Har step pe saari K lists ke heads compare karo
  2. Minimum value wala node result mein add karo
  3. Us list ka head aage badhao
  4. Jab tak koi list bachi ho, repeat karo
ITERATION APPROACH — Har Step Pe K Comparisons
Step 1:
Compare [1, 1, 2]
Min = 1 (List 1 or 2)
Pick → 1
Step 2:
Compare [4, 1, 2]
Min = 1 (List 2)
Pick → 1
Step 3:
Compare [4, 3, 2]
Min = 2 (List 3)
Pick → 2
Step N:
Continue...
Each step = O(K) comparisons!
Python ⚠️ Approach 2: Iteration 
# 🟠 Approach 2: Iteration — O(N × K)
# Simple but slow for large K

def mergeKLists(lists):
    # Filter out empty lists
    lists = [l for l in lists if l]
    if not lists:
        return None
    
    dummy = ListNode(0)
    curr = dummy
    
    while lists:
        # Find minimum among all heads — O(K)
        min_idx = 0
        for i in range(1, len(lists)):
            if lists[i].val < lists[min_idx].val:
                min_idx = i
        
        # Add minimum to result
        curr.next = lists[min_idx]
        curr = curr.next
        
        # Move that list's head forward
        lists[min_idx] = lists[min_idx].next
        
        # Remove if list became empty
        if lists[min_idx] is None:
            lists.pop(min_idx)
    
    return dummy.next

# ⏱️ Time: O(N × K) — N nodes, K comparisons each
# 💾 Space: O(1) — no extra space
# ❌ Problem: K comparisons har node ke liye expensive!
❌ Why Not Optimal? Har node insert karne ke liye K comparisons lage! Agar K = 1000 aur N = 10000, to ye 10 million comparisons! 💀

📌 Approach 3: Merge Lists One by One

💡 Idea

  1. Pehle do lists ko merge karo → Result L1
  2. L1 ko teesri list se merge karo → Result L2
  3. L2 ko chauthi list se merge karo...
  4. Aise hi sabko ek-ek karke merge karo
MERGE ONE BY ONE — Sequential Merging
L1: 1→4→5
+
L2: 1→3→4
=
Merged: 1→1→3→4→4→5
⬇️
Merged: 1→1→3→4→4→5
+
L3: 2→6
⬇️
Final: 1→1→2→3→4→4→5→6
Python ⚠️ Approach 3: Merge One by One 
# 🔵 Approach 3: Merge One by One — O(N × K)
# Uses 2-list merge as building block

def mergeTwoLists(l1, l2):
    """Classic merge two sorted lists"""
    dummy = ListNode(0)
    curr = dummy
    
    while l1 and l2:
        if l1.val <= l2.val:
            curr.next = l1
            l1 = l1.next
        else:
            curr.next = l2
            l2 = l2.next
        curr = curr.next
    
    curr.next = l1 or l2
    return dummy.next

def mergeKLists(lists):
    if not lists:
        return None
    
    # Merge one by one
    result = lists[0]
    for i in range(1, len(lists)):
        result = mergeTwoLists(result, lists[i])
    
    return result

# ⏱️ Time: O(N × K) — Pehla merge: n, doosra: 2n, teesra: 3n...
# 💾 Space: O(1) — in-place merge
# ❌ Problem: Result list bar bar traverse hoti hai!
⚠️ Problem: Jab hum 3rd list merge karte hain, puri merged list (size 2n) traverse hoti hai. 4th ke liye 3n... Ye redundant traversals hain! 🔄

⭐ Approach 4: Heap / Priority Queue — INTERVIEW FAVORITE! 🏆

💡 Key Insight — Why Heap?

Problem: Har step pe K values mein se minimum find karna hai.
Solution: Min-Heap exactly ye karta hai — O(log K) mein minimum de deta hai!

  1. Sabhi K lists ke heads ko heap mein daalo
  2. Heap se minimum node pop karo → result mein add karo
  3. Agar us node ka next exists, use heap mein push karo
  4. Jab tak heap empty nahi, repeat!
MIN-HEAP APPROACH — O(log K) per operation!
📥 Initial State

Heap: [1, 1, 2] (K heads)
Result: empty
📊 Heap Property

Always gives minimum in O(1)
Insert/Delete in O(log K)
Step 1:
Pop: 1
Push: 4
Heap: [1,2,4]
Step 2:
Pop: 1
Push: 3
Heap: [2,3,4]
Step 3:
Pop: 2
Push: 6
Heap: [3,4,6]
Continue...
Heap size ≤ K
Always O(log K)!
Python ⭐ Approach 4: Min-Heap — OPTIMAL! 
# ⭐ Approach 4: Min-Heap — O(N log K) ✨
# Interview mein ye approach sabse zyada impress karti hai!

import heapq

class ListNode:
    def __init__(self, val=0, next=None):
        self.val = val
        self.next = next

def mergeKLists(lists):
    # Min-heap: (value, index, node)
    # Index needed for tie-breaking (Python heapq requirement)
    heap = []
    
    # Step 1: Push all K heads into heap
    for i, head in enumerate(lists):
        if head:
            heapq.heappush(heap, (head.val, i, head))
    
    # Dummy node for result
    dummy = ListNode(0)
    curr = dummy
    
    # Step 2: Pop min, push next (if exists)
    while heap:
        val, idx, node = heapq.heappop(heap)  # O(log K)
        
        # Add to result
        curr.next = node
        curr = curr.next
        
        # Push next node from same list
        if node.next:
            heapq.heappush(heap, (node.next.val, idx, node.next))  # O(log K)
    
    return dummy.next

# ⏱️ Time: O(N log K) — N nodes, each push/pop is O(log K)
# 💾 Space: O(K) — heap size at most K
# ✅ Optimal for interviews! Shows heap mastery! 🏆

🔍 Detailed Dry Run — Heap Approach

Input: lists = [[1,4,5], [1,3,4], [2,6]]

Initial:
  Heap: [(1,0,node1), (1,1,node2), (2,2,node3)]
  Result: dummy

Step 1: Pop (1,0,node1)
  Result: 1
  Push (4,0,next1)
  Heap: [(1,1,node2), (2,2,node3), (4,0,next1)]

Step 2: Pop (1,1,node2)
  Result: 1→1
  Push (3,1,next2)
  Heap: [(2,2,node3), (4,0,next1), (3,1,next2)]

Step 3: Pop (2,2,node3)
  Result: 1→1→2
  Push (6,2,next3)
  Heap: [(3,1,next2), (4,0,next1), (6,2,next3)]

Step 4: Pop (3,1,next2)
  Result: 1→1→2→3
  Push (4,1,next2)
  Heap: [(4,0,next1), (6,2,next3), (4,1,next2)]

Step 5: Pop (4,0,next1)
  Result: 1→1→2→3→4
  Push (5,0,next1)
  Heap: [(4,1,next2), (6,2,next3), (5,0,next1)]

Step 6: Pop (4,1,next2)
  Result: 1→1→2→3→4→4
  No next, don't push
  Heap: [(5,0,next1), (6,2,next3)]

Step 7: Pop (5,0,next1)
  Result: 1→1→2→3→4→4→5
  No next, don't push
  Heap: [(6,2,next3)]

Step 8: Pop (6,2,next3)
  Result: 1→1→2→3→4→4→5→6
  No next, heap empty!

Final: 1→1→2→3→4→4→5→6 ✅
🏆 Interview Gold: Ye approach dikhata hai ki tum heaps properly samjhte ho! Interviewer ko batao: "Mujhe har step pe K elements mein minimum chahiye, so heap is perfect here!" 💯

🔥 Approach 5: Divide & Conquer — Recursive

💡 Key Insight — Merge Sort Wala Pattern!

Instead of merging one-by-one (linear), pairs mein merge karo (tree structure)!

  1. K lists ko do halves mein divide karo
  2. Left half ko recursively merge karo
  3. Right half ko recursively merge karo
  4. Dono results ko merge karo (2-list merge)
DIVIDE & CONQUER — Tree Structure
Final Merged List
1→1→2→3→4→4→5→6
⬆️ merge ⬆️
Left Half
1→1→3→4→4→5
Right Half
2→6
⬆️ merge ⬆️                  ⬆️ base case ⬆️
L1
1→4→5
L2
1→3→4
L3
2→6
Height = log₂(K) levels → Each node traversed log K times!
Python 🔥 Approach 5: Divide & Conquer (Recursive) 
# 🔥 Approach 5: Divide & Conquer — O(N log K)
# Shows understanding of merge sort pattern!

def mergeTwoLists(l1, l2):
    """Merge two sorted lists — O(n1 + n2)"""
    dummy = ListNode(0)
    curr = dummy
    
    while l1 and l2:
        if l1.val <= l2.val:
            curr.next = l1
            l1 = l1.next
        else:
            curr.next = l2
            l2 = l2.next
        curr = curr.next
    
    curr.next = l1 or l2
    return dummy.next

def mergeKLists(lists):
    if not lists:
        return None
    
    def divideAndConquer(start, end):
        # Base case: single list
        if start == end:
            return lists[start]
        
        # Divide
        mid = (start + end) // 2
        
        # Conquer (recursive)
        left = divideAndConquer(start, mid)
        right = divideAndConquer(mid + 1, end)
        
        # Combine
        return mergeTwoLists(left, right)
    
    return divideAndConquer(0, len(lists) - 1)

# ⏱️ Time: O(N log K) — log K levels, each level processes N nodes
# 💾 Space: O(log K) — recursion stack depth
# ✅ Shows merge sort pattern understanding!
🎯 Key Point: Ye approach Merge Sort jaisi hai! Interviewer ko bolo: "Same as merge sort — divide into halves, solve recursively, merge results!" 📊

💎 Approach 6: Divide & Conquer — Iterative (Best Space!)

💡 Idea — Bottom-Up Merging

Instead of recursion (top-down), bottom-up merge karo! Pairs merge karo, then pairs of pairs...

  1. Adjacent pairs merge karo: (L1, L2), (L3, L4), ...
  2. Result pairs ko phir merge karo
  3. Jab tak ek list bache, repeat!
ITERATIVE D&C — Bottom-Up Approach
Round 1 (interval=1): Merge adjacent pairs

L1 + L2 → Merged1
L3 + L4 → Merged2
L5 alone → L5
⬇️
Round 2 (interval=2): Merge pairs of merged lists

Merged1 + Merged2 → Merged3
L5 alone → L5
⬇️
Round 3 (interval=4): Final merge → Result! 🎉
Python 💎 Approach 6: Iterative D&C — Best Space! 
# 💎 Approach 6: Iterative Divide & Conquer — O(N log K), O(1) space!
# No recursion stack, constant extra space!

def mergeTwoLists(l1, l2):
    """Merge two sorted lists"""
    dummy = ListNode(0)
    curr = dummy
    
    while l1 and l2:
        if l1.val <= l2.val:
            curr.next = l1
            l1 = l1.next
        else:
            curr.next = l2
            l2 = l2.next
        curr = curr.next
    
    curr.next = l1 or l2
    return dummy.next

def mergeKLists(lists):
    if not lists:
        return None
    
    k = len(lists)
    interval = 1
    
    # Merge pairs, then pairs of pairs...
    while interval < k:
        for i in range(0, k - interval, interval * 2):
            lists[i] = mergeTwoLists(lists[i], lists[i + interval])
        
        interval *= 2  # Double the interval
    
    return lists[0] if k > 0 else None

# ⏱️ Time: O(N log K) — same as recursive
# 💾 Space: O(1) — no recursion stack! 🏆
# ✅ Best space efficiency!
💎 Space Optimization: Recursion stack avoid kiya! Agar interviewer space optimization pooche, ye approach mention karo! 🎯

📊 Final Complexity Comparison

Approach Time Space Best For
1. Brute Force O(N log N) O(N) ❌ Never use
2. Iteration O(N × K) O(1) ❌ Small K only
3. Merge One by One O(N × K) O(1) ❌ Suboptimal
4. Heap ⭐ O(N log K) O(K) ✅ Interview default!
5. D&C Recursive O(N log K) O(log K) ✅ Shows DS mastery
6. D&C Iterative 💎 O(N log K) O(1) ✅ Best space!
WHEN TO USE WHICH APPROACH?
🏆 Interview Default
Heap / Priority Queue
Clean, intuitive, O(N log K)
💎 Space Optimized
D&C Iterative
O(1) space, no heap

✨ Interview Gold Points

🔥 Key Points to Remember

  • Brute force = O(N log N) — wastes sorted property!
  • Heap = O(N log K) — perfect for "find min among K elements"
  • D&C = O(N log K) — like merge sort, shows recursion mastery
  • Follow-up: "Can you do O(1) space?" → D&C Iterative!
  • Python heapq needs tie-breaker for custom objects
🎯 Interview Script:

"I'll use a min-heap approach. Since we need the minimum among K list heads at each step, a heap gives us this in O(log K). We push all K heads initially, then repeatedly pop minimum and push its next. Total: O(N log K) time, O(K) space."

⚠️ Common Pitfalls — Interview Mein Mat Karo!

  1. Empty lists handle nahi kiya:
    ❌ lists = [[], [1,2], None] pe crash!
    ✅ Push karne se pehle if head: check karo
  2. Heap mein ListNode directly daal diya:
    ❌ Python can't compare ListNode objects!
    ✅ Tuple use karo: (val, index, node)
  3. D&C mein base case wrong:
    ❌ start > end return None → Infinite recursion!
    ✅ start == end pe single list return karo
  4. Iterative D&C mein interval update bhool gaye:
    ❌ interval += 1 — wrong!
    ✅ interval *= 2 — double karo!
🔗 Related Problems to Practice:

  • 📌 Merge Two Sorted Lists — Building block (Easy)
  • 📌 Kth Smallest Element in BST — Heap pattern
  • 📌 Ugly Number II — Multiple pointers merge
  • 📌 Smallest Range Covering K Lists — Advanced heap
📅

Intervals

Overlapping ranges, merging, and scheduling — Google's favorite topic! 🔥

1 Problem

32. Merge Intervals 🔥 GOOGLE

🎯 Pattern 53: Interval Merging (Greedy)

Overlapping intervals ko merge karo — Sorting + Greedy ka classic example! 📅

MEDIUM

📋 Problem Statement

Tumhe ek array diya gaya hai intervals jisme har element [start_i, end_i] ek interval represent karta hai. Tumhe saare overlapping intervals ko merge karke ek naya array return karna hai jisme sirf non-overlapping intervals ho jo puri input range cover kare.

Simple bhasha mein: Jo intervals ek dusre ke upar chadh rahe hain (overlap kar rahe hain), unhe combine karke ek bada interval bana do!

Example 1:
Input: intervals = [[1,3],[2,6],[8,10],[15,18]]
Output: [[1,6],[8,10],[15,18]]

Explanation: 
- [1,3] aur [2,6] overlap karte hain (2 toh 1 se 3 ke beech mein hai!)
- Toh dono ko merge karke [1,6] ban gaya
- [8,10] aur [15,18] kisi se overlap nahi karte, toh waise hi rahenge
Example 2:
Input: intervals = [[1,4],[4,5]]
Output: [[1,5]]

Explanation: 
- [1,4] aur [4,5] edge pe touch kar rahe hain (4 pe)
- Touch karna bhi overlap maana jata hai!
- Toh merge karke [1,5] ban gaya
Example 3:
Input: intervals = [[1,4],[0,4]]
Output: [[0,4]]

Explanation: 
- [0,4] poora [1,4] ko contain kar leta hai
- [1,4] toh [0,4] ke andar hi aa gaya!
- Toh merge karke [0,4] hi rahega
Constraints:
  • 1 ≤ intervals.length ≤ 10⁴ (maximum 10,000 intervals ho sakte hain)
  • intervals[i].length == 2 (har interval mein exactly 2 numbers - start aur end)
  • 0 ≤ start_i ≤ end_i ≤ 10⁴ (start hamesha end se chota ya equal hoga)

🧠 Problem Ka Real Intuition — Socho Meeting Rooms Ka Example!

🎯 Real Life Scenario Samjho: Socho tum office manager ho aur tumhare paas aaj ki meetings ki list hai:

  • 📅 Meeting A: 9:00 AM - 11:00 AM (Team standup)
  • 📅 Meeting B: 10:00 AM - 12:00 PM (Client call) — Ye A ke saath overlap kar rahi hai!
  • 📅 Meeting C: 2:00 PM - 4:00 PM (Project review) — Ye alag hai, koi overlap nahi

Question: "Actually conference room kitne time ke liye booked rahega?"

→ Meeting A aur B overlap karti hain, toh effectively room blocked hai: 9:00 AM - 12:00 PM (3 ghante)
→ Meeting C alag time pe hai: 2:00 PM - 4:00 PM (2 ghante)

Final Answer: Room 2 time slots ke liye booked hai: [[9:00, 12:00], [14:00, 16:00]]
Yehi hai Merge Intervals! Overlapping time slots ko combine karke non-overlapping slots banana!

🏠 Real Life Mein Kahan Use Hota Hai?
  • 📅 Google Calendar: Jab tumhari multiple events overlap karti hain, Calendar unhe visually merge karke dikhata hai
  • 🎮 Game Development: Collision detection mein overlapping hitboxes ko merge karna hota hai
  • 📊 Data Analytics: Time series data mein overlapping periods ko consolidate karna, jaise user sessions
  • 🚗 GPS/Maps: Road construction pe multiple blocked sections ko ek mein merge karna
  • 🏥 Hospital Systems: Doctor ki available slots calculate karte waqt busy intervals merge karna
  • 📺 Video Streaming: Buffered video segments ko merge karke seamless playback dena

🔑 Sorting Kyun Zaruri Hai? — Ye Samajhna Bahut Important!

💡 Bina sorting ke ye problem bahut mushkil ho jati hai! Socho kyun:

Agar intervals random order mein hain:
[[8,10], [1,3], [2,6], [15,18]]

Toh har interval ke liye tumhe poori list check karni padegi ki kaun overlap kar raha hai!
[8,10] ke liye check: [1,3]? No. [2,6]? No. [15,18]? No.
[1,3] ke liye check: [8,10]? No. [2,6]? YES! [15,18]? No.
... aur aage bhi aise hi → Time Complexity: O(n²) 🐢 Bahut slow!

But agar sort kar lo start time ke hisaab se:
[[1,3], [2,6], [8,10], [15,18]]

Ab MAGIC dekho! Sorting ke baad sirf adjacent (paas wale) intervals hi overlap kar sakte hain!
Kyun? Because agar [1,3] [8,10] se overlap nahi karta (kyunki 3 < 8), toh [1,3] uske baad wale [15,18] se bhi overlap nahi karega!
Toh sirf ek linear scan chahiye → Time Complexity: O(n) ⚡ Bahut fast!

📊 Sorting Se Problem Kitni Easy Ho Jati Hai!
❌ Bina Sort Ke — O(n²)
[8,10] 😵
[1,3] 🤔
[2,6] 😰
[15,18] 😫

Har pair check karna padega! 🐢
n*(n-1)/2 comparisons!

✅ Sort Ke Baad — O(n)
[1,3] ✅
[2,6] ✅
[8,10] ✅
[15,18] ✅

Sirf adjacent check karo! ⚡
n-1 comparisons only!

🤝 Do Intervals Kab Overlap Karte Hain? — Golden Rule!

Ye MOST IMPORTANT concept hai! Do intervals [a, b] aur [c, d] (jahan sorting ke baad a ≤ c):

✅ OVERLAP hai agar:

b >= c

Matlab pehle interval ka END >= doosre ka START

Example: [1,5] aur [3,7] → 5 >= 3 ✅

❌ NO OVERLAP agar:

b < c

Matlab pehle interval ka END < doosre ka START (gap hai!)

Example: [1,3] aur [8,10] → 3 < 8 ❌

⚠️ Important: Edge touch bhi overlap hai! [1,4] aur [4,5] mein 4 = 4, toh ye overlap hai aur merge hoga [1,5] mein!

🔍 4 Types of Overlap — Sab Cases Samjho!
Case 1: Partial Overlap (Thoda Overlap)
A: 1━━━━3
B: 2━━━━━━6
→ Merged: [1, 6]
3 >= 2 hai, toh overlap! Max(3,6)=6
Case 2: Complete Contain (Ek Doosre Ke Andar)
A: 1━━━━━━━━6
B: 2━━4
→ Merged: [1, 6]
B poora A ke andar hai! Max(6,4)=6
Case 3: Edge Touch (Kinare Pe Touch)
A: 1━━━4
B: 4━━5
→ Merged: [1, 5]
4 >= 4 hai (equal!), toh ye bhi overlap!
Case 4: No Overlap (Gap Hai!)
A: 1━3
B: 8━━10
→ Dono alag rahenge
3 < 8 hai, beech mein gap hai!

✅ Approach A: Sort + Linear Merge (Best Approach - Interview Mein Ye Batao!)

O(n log n) O(n)

💡 Algorithm Steps — Step by Step Samjho!

  1. Step 1: Sort Karo — Intervals ko unke start time ke hisaab se sort karo. Ye sabse important step hai!
  2. Step 2: Result Initialize Karo — Pehla interval result mein daal do (ye toh merge ho hi gaya consider karo)
  3. Step 3: Loop Chalao — Baaki har interval ke liye:
    • Agar current interval result ke last interval se overlap karta hai → Last interval ka end extend kar do
    • Agar overlap nahi karta (gap hai) → Current interval ko result mein add kar do
  4. Step 4: Return Karo — Merged result array return kar do!
🔄 Algorithm Ka Flow — Visual
1. Sort by start
→
2. result = [first]
→
3. Loop: har interval
↓
current.start <= last.end?
YES → Extend!
last.end = max(last.end, current.end)
NO → Add new!
result.append(current)
↓
4. Return merged result

📺 Visual Dry Run — Poora Example Dekho!

Input: [[1,3], [2,6], [8,10], [15,18]] (already sorted hai)

🎬 Step-by-Step Merge Process
1
Pehla interval [1,3] result mein daalo
result = [[1,3]]
2
Check [2,6]: Kya 2 ≤ 3? HAAN! Overlap hai!
Extend karo: end = max(3, 6) = 6 → result = [[1,6]]
3
Check [8,10]: Kya 8 ≤ 6? NAHI! Gap hai!
Naya interval add karo → result = [[1,6], [8,10]]
4
Check [15,18]: Kya 15 ≤ 10? NAHI! Gap hai!
Naya interval add karo → result = [[1,6], [8,10], [15,18]] ✅
🔍 Detailed Dry Run Table
Step Current Interval Result Ka Last Overlap Check Kya Kiya? Updated Result
Init [1,3] - - Pehla hai, seedha add [[1,3]]
1 [2,6] [1,3] ✅ 2 ≤ 3 (Overlap!) Extend: max(3,6)=6 [[1,6]]
2 [8,10] [1,6] ❌ 8 > 6 (Gap!) Naya add kiya [[1,6],[8,10]]
3 [15,18] [8,10] ❌ 15 > 10 (Gap!) Naya add kiya [[1,6],[8,10],[15,18]]
Python - Approach A (Sort + Merge) — Interview Ready Code! 
class Solution:
    def merge(self, intervals: List[List[int]]) -> List[List[int]]:
        """
        Merge Overlapping Intervals - Google Favorite Problem!
        
        Approach: Sort by start time, fir linear merge karo
        
        KEY INSIGHT (Ye interview mein bolo!):
        - Sorting ke baad sirf ADJACENT intervals hi overlap kar sakte hain
        - Do intervals [a,b] aur [c,d] overlap karte hain agar b >= c
        
        Time: O(n log n) - Sorting ki wajah se
        Space: O(n) - Result array ke liye
        """
        
        # Edge case: Agar empty ya sirf ek interval hai
        if len(intervals) <= 1:
            return intervals
        
        # STEP 1: Sort by start time - YE SABSE IMPORTANT STEP HAI!
        # Lambda function: x[0] matlab first element (start time)
        intervals.sort(key=lambda x: x[0])
        
        # STEP 2: Result mein pehla interval daal do
        result = [intervals[0]]
        
        # STEP 3: Baaki har interval process karo
        for i in range(1, len(intervals)):
            current = intervals[i]      # Abhi wala interval
            last = result[-1]           # Result ka last interval
            
            # OVERLAP CHECK: current.start <= last.end?
            if current[0] <= last[1]:
                # OVERLAP HAI! Last interval ko extend karo
                # max() isliye kyunki:
                # - Partial overlap: [1,3], [2,6] → end = max(3,6) = 6
                # - One inside other: [1,6], [2,4] → end = max(6,4) = 6
                last[1] = max(last[1], current[1])
            else:
                # NO OVERLAP - Gap hai beech mein
                # Current ko naya interval ki tarah add karo
                result.append(current)
        
        return result


# ============ USAGE EXAMPLES ============
if __name__ == "__main__":
    sol = Solution()
    
    # Example 1: Partial overlap
    print(sol.merge([[1,3],[2,6],[8,10],[15,18]]))
    # Output: [[1,6],[8,10],[15,18]]
    
    # Example 2: Edge touch (ye bhi merge hoga!)
    print(sol.merge([[1,4],[4,5]]))
    # Output: [[1,5]]
    
    # Example 3: One contains other
    print(sol.merge([[1,4],[2,3]]))
    # Output: [[1,4]]
    
    # Example 4: Unsorted input (sort kar lega automatically)
    print(sol.merge([[8,10],[1,3],[2,6]]))
    # Output: [[1,6],[8,10]]

📚 Approach B: Stack-Based Merge

O(n log n) O(n)

💡 Stack Approach Idea

Same logic, but stack use karo result ke liye:

  • Sort intervals
  • Push first interval to stack
  • For each interval: peek stack top, merge or push

Same complexity, different style — useful if interviewer asks for variation!

Python - Approach B (Stack) 
class Solution:
    def merge(self, intervals: List[List[int]]) -> List[List[int]]:
        """
        Stack-based approach for merging intervals.
        
        Same logic as Approach A, but uses stack explicitly.
        Useful for interview variation questions.
        """
        
        if not intervals:
            return []
        
        # Sort by start time
        intervals.sort(key=lambda x: x[0])
        
        # Use list as stack
        stack = [intervals[0]]
        
        for i in range(1, len(intervals)):
            top = stack[-1]  # Peek stack top
            current = intervals[i]
            
            if current[0] <= top[1]:
                # Overlap - modify top of stack
                stack[-1][1] = max(top[1], current[1])
            else:
                # No overlap - push new interval
                stack.append(current)
        
        return stack

🔧 Approach C: In-Place Merge (Space Optimized)

O(n log n) O(1) extra

💡 In-Place Idea

Extra result array mat banao! Input array ko hi modify karo:

  • Use a write pointer j
  • Merge in place and track valid length
  • Return only the merged portion

⚠️ Note: Sorting still takes O(n) space internally in Python, but this saves the extra result array!

Python - Approach C (In-Place) 
class Solution:
    def merge(self, intervals: List[List[int]]) -> List[List[int]]:
        """
        In-place merge - no extra result array needed.
        
        Uses write pointer to overwrite input array.
        Returns slice of original array.
        
        Space: O(1) extra (ignoring sort's internal space)
        """
        
        if len(intervals) <= 1:
            return intervals
        
        # Sort in place
        intervals.sort(key=lambda x: x[0])
        
        # j = write pointer (points to last merged interval)
        j = 0
        
        for i in range(1, len(intervals)):
            # If current overlaps with intervals[j]
            if intervals[i][0] <= intervals[j][1]:
                # Merge: extend intervals[j]
                intervals[j][1] = max(intervals[j][1], intervals[i][1])
            else:
                # No overlap: move write pointer and copy
                j += 1
                intervals[j] = intervals[i]
        
        # Return merged portion (0 to j inclusive)
        return intervals[:j + 1]

🎤 Google Follow-up Questions

🔥 Google loves these follow-ups:

  • 📌 "What if intervals are coming as a stream?"
    → Use a balanced BST (like TreeMap) to maintain sorted order, O(log n) per insert
  • 📌 "Can you handle very large data that doesn't fit in memory?"
    → External merge sort + streaming merge
  • 📌 "What if you need to support insert AND query?"
    → Interval Tree data structure
  • 📌 "What if you need to find overlapping intervals for a given query?"
    → Interval Tree or Segment Tree

🔗 Related Interval Problems (Google Favorites)

Problem Difficulty Key Idea
Insert Interval Medium Insert new interval and merge
Non-overlapping Intervals Medium Min removals to make non-overlapping
Meeting Rooms Easy Can attend all meetings?
Meeting Rooms II Medium Min meeting rooms needed
Employee Free Time Hard Find free slots across schedules

⚠️ Common Pitfalls — Avoid These!

❌ Pitfall 1: Forgetting to sort
# WRONG!
def merge(self, intervals):
    result = [intervals[0]]
    for i in range(1, len(intervals)):
        # Without sorting, this logic fails!
        # [[8,10], [1,3], [2,6]] → wrong answer
❌ Pitfall 2: Using < instead of <=
# WRONG!
if current[0] < last[1]:  # Misses edge case!
    # [[1,4], [4,5]] should merge to [[1,5]]
    # But 4 < 4 is False, so they won't merge!

Fix: Use <= to handle touching intervals!

❌ Pitfall 3: Not using max() for end
# WRONG!
last[1] = current[1]  # Overwrites without checking!
# [[1,6], [2,4]] → becomes [[1,4]] instead of [[1,6]]

Fix: Always use max(last[1], current[1])

📊 Complexity Summary

Approach Time Space Notes
Sort + Merge ⭐ O(n log n) O(n) Best for interviews! Clean and readable
Stack-Based O(n log n) O(n) Same complexity, different style
In-Place O(n log n) O(1)* *Ignoring sort's internal space

* Sorting is the bottleneck - O(n log n). The merge step is O(n).

🔥 Google Interview One-liner

"Sort intervals by start time, then linearly merge adjacent overlapping intervals by extending the end point — the key insight is that after sorting, only adjacent intervals can possibly overlap!"

🌳

Trees

Binary Trees, Recursion, BFS, DFS — Tree traversal mastery!

1 Problem

33. Invert Binary Tree Easy

Binary tree ko mirror karo — Recursion ki power! 🪞🌳

📚 Prerequisites — Yeh Pehle Samjho!

  • Binary Trees — Tree node structure with left and right children
  • Breadth-First Search (BFS) — Level-by-level traversal using a queue
  • Depth-First Search (DFS) — Recursive traversal of tree structures
  • Stack-based Iteration — Converting recursive DFS to iterative form

📋 Problem:

Given the root of a binary tree, invert the tree, and return its root.

Example 1:

Input: root = [4,2,7,1,3,6,9]
Output: [4,7,2,9,6,3,1]

        4                    4
       / \                  / \
      2   7      →        7   2
     / \ / \              / \ / \
    1  3 6  9            9  6 3  1

Example 2:

Input: root = [2,1,3]
Output: [2,3,1]

      2              2
     / \     →      / \
    1   3          3   1

Example 3:

Input: root = []
Output: []

🎯 Hinglish Explanation — Kya Karna Hai?

Invert = Mirror Image banana! Soch ek mirror ke saamne tree rakh diya. Jo left mein tha woh right mein aa gaya, jo right mein tha woh left mein! 🪞

Real-life example: Apna photo selfie mode mein dekho vs normal camera se — sab kuch ulta dikhai deta hai! Yahi karna hai tree ke saath.

Key Insight: Har node pe jaake uske left aur right children ko swap karo. Recursively yahi karo sabke saath — tree automatically invert ho jayega! 💡

🪞 Invert Binary Tree — Visual

Before
        4
       / \
      2   7
     / \ / \
    1  3 6  9
Swap
Har node pe:
left ↔ right
swap karo!
After
        4
       / \
      7   2
     / \ / \
    9  6 3  1

▶ Approach 1: Breadth First Search (BFS) O(n) O(n)

💡 Intuition — BFS Kaise Kaam Karta Hai?

BFS = Level-by-level chalo! Queue use karo. Har level pe jao, har node ka left-right swap karo, phir uske children queue mein daalo.

Soch: Building ke floors clean karna — pehle ground floor, phir first floor, phir second... Aise hi tree ke levels process karo! 🏢

📝 Algorithm Steps:

  1. Agar tree empty hai → None return karo
  2. Queue banao aur root daalo
  3. Jab tak queue khali nahi:
    • Front node nikalo
    • Uske left aur right children SWAP karo
    • Agar left child hai → queue mein daalo
    • Agar right child hai → queue mein daalo
  4. Root return karo — tree invert ho gaya!

🔄 BFS Dry Run

Step 1

Queue: [4]

Process 4 → swap(2,7)

Step 2

Queue: [7, 2]

Process 7 → swap(6,9)

Step 3

Queue: [2, 9, 6]

Process 2 → swap(1,3)

Done!

Process leaves (9,6,3,1)

No children to swap

Python - BFS Approach 
# Definition for a binary tree node.
# class TreeNode:
#     def __init__(self, val=0, left=None, right=None):
#         self.val = val
#         self.left = left
#         self.right = right

from collections import deque

class Solution:
    def invertTree(self, root: Optional[TreeNode]) -> Optional[TreeNode]:
        if not root:
            return None
        
        queue = deque([root])  # Queue mein root daalo
        
        while queue:
            node = queue.popleft()  # Front node nikalo
            
            # ⭐ SWAP left and right children
            node.left, node.right = node.right, node.left
            
            # Children ko queue mein daalo (agar exist karte hain)
            if node.left:
                queue.append(node.left)
            if node.right:
                queue.append(node.right)
        
        return root

⏱️ Time & Space Complexity:

  • Time: O(n) — Har node ek baar visit
  • Space: O(n) — Worst case: last level mein n/2 nodes queue mein

▶ Approach 2: Depth First Search (Recursive) ⭐ RECOMMENDED O(n) O(h)

💡 Intuition — Recursion Ki Magic!

Recursive thinking: Har node pe:

  1. Left aur right children SWAP karo
  2. Left subtree ko invert karo (recursive call)
  3. Right subtree ko invert karo (recursive call)

Key insight: Recursion automatically handle karega sabko! Base case: null node pe kuch mat karo, None return karo.

🤔 Yeh Kaam Kyun Karta Hai?

Soch: Agar mujhe poora tree invert karna hai, toh:

  • Root ke children swap kar diye ✓
  • Ab left subtree bhi ek tree hai — use bhi invert karo
  • Right subtree bhi tree hai — use bhi invert karo

Recursion: Chhoti problem solve karo, badi automatically solve ho jayegi! 🎯

🔄 DFS Recursive Dry Run

Call 1

invert(4)

swap(2,7) → 4 ke children: 7,2

Call 2

invert(7)

swap(6,9) → 7 ke children: 9,6

Call 3

invert(9)

Leaf node → return

Backtrack

Calls return hoti hain

Tree inverted! ✓

Python - DFS Recursive (Cleanest!) ⭐ 
# Definition for a binary tree node.
# class TreeNode:
#     def __init__(self, val=0, left=None, right=None):
#         self.val = val
#         self.left = left
#         self.right = right

class Solution:
    def invertTree(self, root: Optional[TreeNode]) -> Optional[TreeNode]:
        # Base case: empty tree
        if not root:
            return None
        
        # ⭐ SWAP children first
        root.left, root.right = root.right, root.left
        
        # Recursively invert subtrees
        self.invertTree(root.left)
        self.invertTree(root.right)
        
        return root

⚠️ Common Pitfall — Swap PEHLE Karo!

GALAT: Agar swap BAAD mein karte ho: 

# ❌ WRONG - swap after recursion undoes the inversion!
self.invertTree(root.left)
self.invertTree(root.right)
root.left, root.right = root.right, root.left  # Ulta kaam!

SAHI: Swap PEHLE karo, phir recurse karo! Kyunki agar pehle subtrees invert karo phir swap karo, toh wapas original position pe aa jayenge! 🔄

⏱️ Time & Space Complexity:

  • Time: O(n) — Har node ek baar visit
  • Space: O(h) — Recursion stack, h = height of tree
    • Balanced tree: O(log n)
    • Skewed tree (worst): O(n)

▶ Approach 3: Iterative DFS (Stack) O(n) O(h)

💡 Intuition — Stack Se DFS!

Same logic as recursive DFS — but instead of using function call stack, we use our own stack data structure! 📚

Kab use karein?

  • Jab recursion depth bahut zyada ho sakti hai (stack overflow risk)
  • Interview mein interviewer iterative solution maange
  • Explicit control chahiye traversal pe

📝 Algorithm Steps:

  1. Agar root null → return None
  2. Stack banao, root push karo
  3. Jab tak stack empty nahi:
    • Top node pop karo
    • Left-Right SWAP karo
    • Left child push karo (agar hai)
    • Right child push karo (agar hai)
  4. Return root

📚 Iterative DFS with Stack

Step 1

Stack: [4]

Pop 4 → swap(2,7)

Push: 7, 2

Step 2

Stack: [7, 2]

Pop 2 → swap(1,3)

Push: 3, 1

Step 3

Stack: [7, 3, 1]

Pop leaves...

Done!

Stack empty

All swapped! ✓

Python - Iterative DFS (Stack) 
# Definition for a binary tree node.
# class TreeNode:
#     def __init__(self, val=0, left=None, right=None):
#         self.val = val
#         self.left = left
#         self.right = right

class Solution:
    def invertTree(self, root: Optional[TreeNode]) -> Optional[TreeNode]:
        if not root:
            return None
        
        stack = [root]  # Apna stack use karo
        
        while stack:
            node = stack.pop()  # Top node nikalo (LIFO)
            
            # ⭐ SWAP children
            node.left, node.right = node.right, node.left
            
            # Push children to stack
            if node.left:
                stack.append(node.left)
            if node.right:
                stack.append(node.right)
        
        return root

🔍 BFS vs Iterative DFS — Fark Kya Hai?

Feature BFS (Queue) DFS (Stack)
Data Structure Queue (FIFO) Stack (LIFO)
Traversal Order Level by level Depth first
Result Same — Tree Inverted! ✓

⏱️ Time & Space Complexity:

  • Time: O(n) — Har node ek baar visit
  • Space: O(h) — Stack size = tree height
    • Better than BFS for wide trees!
    • Worst case (skewed): O(n)

📊 Approach Comparison — Interview Mein Kaunsa Batao?

Approach Time Space Best For
BFS (Queue) O(n) O(n) Level-wise processing needed
DFS Recursive ⭐ O(n) O(h) Cleanest code, interviews!
DFS Iterative (Stack) O(n) O(h) Deep trees, explicit control

🎯 Fun Fact — Famous Interview Story!

Max Howell (Homebrew banane wale) Google interview mein fail ho gaye kyunki yeh problem solve nahi kar paaye! 😱

"Google: 90% of our engineers use the software you wrote (Homebrew), but you can't invert a binary tree on a whiteboard so f*** off."

Lesson: DSA practice important hai — chahe kitne bhi experienced ho! Toh chalo practice karte raho! 💪

🎯 Interview One-liner

"Invert Binary Tree by recursively swapping left and right children at every node — the key insight is that after swapping a node's children, the subtrees themselves need to be inverted too, making it a perfect recursive problem!"
